Functions description for the CGPS class to decode data that the modules send



|| ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
|| To use this file in your project, you need to have PHP 4.3 or greater installed.
|| Contains the following classes:
|| - CGPS:: Decoding of module transmitted data, generating proper acknowledge response and command/data upload to the module.
|| - CGPSsettings:: For creating/reading/modifying settings data for the module to comply to (like the settings application).
|| - CGPSCODE:: Helper class for constructing/validating code like an LCD-menu.
|| ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
====



|| ########################################################################
|| ########################################################################
|| ########################################################################
|| ####################################### CGPS class members and functions
|| ########################################################################
|| ########################################################################
|| ########################################################################
|| Class to decode the data that is created and transmitted by a module to your server and to construct
|| a proper response to return as acknowledge back to the module that transmitted to your server.
|| Together with this response you can also include tasks and data to be performed by the module.
|| Usage example:

||
||     <?php
    //The cgpsexample server does basically the same as this example, but it
    //contains various additional info and code for easy experimenting.
    //This example assumes that your module is programmed to send HTTP server
    //compatible transmissions to this script.
    require('cgps.php'); //We are using the CGPS classes in this script.
    $pcGPS=new CGPS(); //Create an object of the CGPS class.
    $ProcessedDataParts=0; //New variable set to 0, that we will increment for every part of the incoming data that we process.
    //Here we check if the caller of this script (=transmitting module) has
    //included data as we expect it.
    if(    isset($_GET['YourVariableName']) //Did we receive data? (e.g. called as http://server.com/ThisScript?YourVariableName=data)
        && $pcGPS->SetHttpData($_GET['YourVariableName']) ) //then put that in the class object and check for a Boolean TRUE result.
    {
        //The received data is now in the class object and was accepted.
        //So now let's check it out.
        $ExtraModuleData=@file_get_contents('php://input'); //Get extra included data if any. (e.g. JPEG picture from camera).
        $Imei=$pcGPS->GetImei(); //Extract the transmitting module's unique identification number.
        //Now we loop through all data parts of the received transmission,
        //increasing the $ProcessedDataParts variable for every processed data
        //part. (In the cgpsexample program, this is done in the
        //StoreInDatabase() and ForwardData() functions).
        while ( $ProcessedDataParts < $pcGPS->GetDataPartCount() )
        {
            if( $pcGPS->SelectDataPart($ProcessedDataParts)==true ) //Select the (next) part of the data to work with.
            {
                //This data part is valid, so extract whatever you need from
                //it, for example:
                $CreationDateTime=$pcGPS->GetUtcTime(); //Extract the creation date and time of the current data part.
                $Switch=$pcGPS->GetSwitch(); //Extract the Switch value of this data part which tells what info is actually encoded in this data part.
                if ( $pcGPS->CanGetLatLong()==true ) //Does this data part contain valid GPS latitude/longitude information?
                {
                    $Longitude=$pcGPS->GetLongitudeFloat(); //Extract the longitude position as floating point value.
                    $Latitude=$pcGPS->GetLatitudeFloat(); //Extract the latitude position as floating point value.
                } else $Longitude=$Latitude='No valid GPS information available in this data part (usually other info available instead)';

                //At this point, you will want to do something with all info
                //you extracted from the current data part, like storing it on
                //your server.
                //Do *NOT* abort the script or generate output or script
                //errors/warnings, because then the module will not receive a
                //proper acknowledge.
                //Do *NOT* take a long time to store each data part (there can
                //be many in a transmission), because otherwise the module will
                //time out waiting for the acknowledge to continue with its
                //required other duties.
                //When the module does not receive a proper acknowledge or not
                //in time, it will resend the same data again later and
                //eventually make a primary/secondary server settings switch.
            } else WriteErrorMessageToYourLogFile( $pcGPS->GetLastError() ); //Text message of the last error.
            $ProcessedDataParts=$ProcessedDataParts+1; //Increment our counter and continue the loop to the next data part.
        }
        if ( $pcGPS->IsForwardedByGateway()==false ) //Did we receive this data transmission directly from the module?
        {
            //At this point we are sure that our response will be returned to a
            //module and not to a gateway that forwarded the data.
            //If you want, you can include extra tasks that you want the module
            //to perform together with your server response back to the module.
            //Identifying the module by its IMEI code, you can determine if you
            //have some pending actions on your server for this specific module.
            //You can request one or more tasks via the response action class
            //members for the transmitting module to perform.
            //Some examples:
            $pcGPS->mFirmware=123; //Instruct module to download a firmware version 123 file from the root directory of you HTTP server of your server.
            $pcGPS->mSettings=@file_get_contents('SettingsFileName.tms'); //Upload settings in this file. See also CGPSsettings::GetSettingsData().
            $pcGPS->mGpsLog=true; //Instruct module to record its current GPS position in the log.
            $pcGPS->mPhoto=RACD_Photo_LoRes; //Instruct module to take a picture in low resolution.
            $pcGPS->mDigitalOutput2=RACD_DigitalOutput_Enable; //Instruct module to enable digital output #2.
            $pcGPS->mSerialPort3='Some serial data'; //Instruct module to send some data via serial port #3.
            $pcGPS->mActionID=3; //Instruct module to call "SMS-Alert phone number 3" for open voice connection.
        }
    }
    //Build and return a response to the transmitting module that contains:
    // - The acknowledge for the processed data parts (so the module will
    //  delete them from the log and not re-send those again).
    // - The task requests that you have set via the response action member
    //  variables of the class.
    print($pcGPS->BuildResponseHTTP($ProcessedDataParts)); //Build the response and send it to the module.
    ?>
||
||

====

  • mSettings// For uploading new settings data to the module (like from CGPSsettings::GetSettingsData() or from disk file e.g. $pcGPS->mSettings=@file_get_contents('SettingsFileOnDisk.tms');). The module will generate a SV_SettingsAccepted or SV_SettingsRejected record.

  • mFirmware// For requesting the module to perform a HTTP download attempt of a newer firmware file version from the root of your HTTP server directory specified in the current settings. (e.g. $pcGPS->mFirmware=380; //Request to do a download attempt of firmware version 380). Note that the module will ignore the request if it is not about a download attempt for a newer firmware version than it is already running on. Only upgrades are possible and no automatic retry attempts are performed by the module. See also CGPS::GetVersion().

  • mFirmwareManufacturer// Rev8:152 Same usage and functionality as CGPS::mFirmware, but attempts to download the specified firmware version from the manufacturer's server instead. Therefore *ALWAYS CONFIRM FIRST* with your dealer/distributor which firmware version is available to safely upgrade to from that server. *NEVER SIMPLY TRY SOME NUMBERS*, because result may vary from noting happening up to rendering the module completely useless.

  • mSerialPort1// For requesting the module to send bytes via its serial port. You can set up to 250 bytes (e.g. $pcGPS->mSerialPort1='Hello world';) to be sent to the module which will output them them via its serial ports for which you have set SETTING_ModulePortMode... to driver mode MPM_SerialOut or MPM_SerialInOut with the protocol and baud rate you have set for that port with SETTING_ModulePortProtocol... and SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate...

  • mSerialPort2// For requesting the module to send bytes via its serial port. You can set up to 250 bytes (e.g. $pcGPS->mSerialPort1='Hello world';) to be sent to the module which will output them them via its serial ports for which you have set SETTING_ModulePortMode... to driver mode MPM_SerialOut or MPM_SerialInOut with the protocol and baud rate you have set for that port with SETTING_ModulePortProtocol... and SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate...

  • mSerialPort3// For requesting the module to send bytes via its serial port. You can set up to 250 bytes (e.g. $pcGPS->mSerialPort1='Hello world';) to be sent to the module which will output them them via its serial ports for which you have set SETTING_ModulePortMode... to driver mode MPM_SerialOut or MPM_SerialInOut with the protocol and baud rate you have set for that port with SETTING_ModulePortProtocol... and SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate...

  • mSerialPort4// For requesting the module to send bytes via its serial port. You can set up to 250 bytes (e.g. $pcGPS->mSerialPort1='Hello world';) to be sent to the module which will output them them via its serial ports for which you have set SETTING_ModulePortMode... to driver mode MPM_SerialOut or MPM_SerialInOut with the protocol and baud rate you have set for that port with SETTING_ModulePortProtocol... and SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate...

  • mGpsLog// Request to write GPS fix, module I/O and other status information to the log as a SV_Position... record (type depends on SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType and GPS signal quality for which the GPS receiver will be turned+kept on an waited for until timeout). Set with boolean TRUE to activate (e.g. $pcGPS->mGpsLog=true;)

  • mCountersLog// Request to log the current reading of the counters (e.g. $pcGPS->mCountersLog=true;). See CGPS::GetCounter...() functions for examining the generated records.

  • mPhoto// Request to take a picture with attached camera. Use RACD_Photo_... definitions. (e.g. $pcGPS->mPhoto=RACD_Photo_LoRes; //Module will take a low resolution picture).

  • RACD_Photo_No// Do not take a picture.
  • RACD_Photo_LoRes// Take and send low resolution picture if GPRS connection is available.
  • RACD_Photo_HiRes// Take and send high resolution picture if GPRS connection is available.

  • mTransmitLog// Request to start the transfer of the current contents of the log to the server (e.g. $pcGPS->mTransmitLog=true;).

  • mResetTimer1// Reset timer 1. Set with boolean TRUE to activate. (e.g. $pcGPS->mResetTimer1=true; //Set runtime timer count back to 0 to delay its next event trigger).

  • mResetTimer2// Reset timer 2. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mResetTimer3// Reset timer 3. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mResetTimer4// Reset timer 4. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mResetTimer5// Reset timer 5. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mResetTimer6// Reset timer 6. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mResetTimer7// Reset timer 7. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mResetTimer8// Reset timer 8. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mSmsAlert1// Request to send an SMS text message to the phone number already set for SETTING_SmsAlertPhone1. Set with boolean TRUE to activate. (e.g. $pcGPS->mSmsAlert1=true; //Send SMS to phone #1).

  • mSmsAlert2// Request to send an SMS text message to the phone number already set for SETTING_SmsAlertPhone2. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mSmsAlert3// Request to send an SMS text message to the phone number already set for SETTING_SmsAlertPhone3. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mSmsAlertCalledBy1// Request to send an SMS text message to the phone number already set for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mSmsAlertCalledBy2// Request to send an SMS text message to the phone number already set for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy2. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mSmsAlertCalledBy3// Request to send an SMS text message to the phone number already set for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy3. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mActionID// Request to perform an ActionID. When used, all mSmsAlert... class member variables are ignored, so no SMS text message will be sent). (e.g. $pcGPS->mActionID=13; //Activate 'Virtual output 1')

  • mRebootModule// <=- ***DEPRECATED*** Do !NOT! use this one anymore. Use CGPS::mActionID with ActionID 64.

  • mClearLog// Request to erase the full FLASH memory in the module, clearing the log *AND* LCD/source-code and then do an unconditinal reboot (like ActionID 64). Set with boolean TRUE to activate. NOTE: Use ActionID 77 instead for clearing only the records in the log (e.g. $pcGPS->mActionID=77;).

  • mClearGPSConfig// Request to clear configuration of the GPS receiver, resulting in a "cold start" position determination of the GPS receiver. Set with boolean TRUE to activate.

  • mSyncTime// [Rev8:192] Synchronize module's software clock with current server date/time. Set with boolean TRUE to activate the sync (e.g. $pcGPS->mSyncTime=true;). Useful projects in which the module does not have a GPS receiver/antenna and this can never sync the date and time of the internal software clock automatically from the GPS satellites. You could for example do a sync from the server when receiving a SV_PowerUp record and maybe periodically after that since the software clock can have 0.5% deviation.

  • mDigitalOutput1// Request to change status of digital output1. Set it to a RACD_DigitalOutput_... definition (e.g. $pcGPS->mDigitalOutput1=RACD_DigitalOutput_Enable; //Enable digital output port #1).

  • mDigitalOutput2// Request to change status of digital output2. Set it to a RACD_DigitalOutput_... definition (e.g. $pcGPS->mDigitalOutput1=RACD_DigitalOutput_Disable; //Disable digital output port #2).

  • mDigitalOutput3// Request to change status of digital output3. Set it to a RACD_DigitalOutput_... definition (e.g. $pcGPS->mDigitalOutput1=RACD_DigitalOutput_Toggle; //Toggle digital output port #3 from enabled to disabled or vice versa).

  • mDigitalOutput4// Request to change status of digital output4. Set it to a RACD_DigitalOutput_... definition (e.g. $pcGPS->mDigitalOutput1=RACD_DigitalOutput_Enable; //Enable digital output port #4).

  • RACD_DigitalOutput_NoChange// Do not change digital output state.
  • RACD_DigitalOutput_Enable// Activate digital output.
  • RACD_DigitalOutput_Disable// Deactivate digital output.
  • RACD_DigitalOutput_Toggle// Toggle digital output state from active to inactive and vice versa.

  • mBuzzer// Request to change enable TXD on buzzer port (see MPM_Buzzer/SETTING_ModulePortMode...). Value 0=short "bib", 1 up to 99=time in 100ms units. (e.g. $pcGPS->mBuzzer=8; //Beep for 0.8 secs).

  • mSourceCode// Upload LCD/source-code source code to be executed, preferrably properly corrected and formatted from CGPSCODE::GetSourceCode() or if needed even directly from disk file like $pcGPS->mSourceCode=file_get_contents("sourcecode.src");.

  • mOmitIdentification// [Rev5:469 / Rev8:100] Request module not to include identification data when next time transmitting data over the same connection so your server code will have to remember and add that part to future data strings the module will transmits.

  • mAcknowledgeCRC// [Rev8/9:280] Include a CRC of the received data that was previously put in the CGPS class in the acknowledge of the server response.

  • mReserved// Reserved for special purposes.

function CGPS()
Class constructor
Notes:
    Function is automatically executed when a new instance of the class is created.
    This function automatically calls internal method functions CGPS::Clear()
    and CGPS::ClearResponseActionMembers().
function Clear()
Clear data that was previously set into the class
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - None
Notes:
- This function clears internal data and memory in use by
      previous use of a method function like CGPS::SetTcpData(),
      CGPS::SetHttpData(), CGPS::SetHexData(), CGPS::SetBinaryData()
      and additionally possibly other internal space allocated by
      a message set for CGPS::GetLastError() and things like that.
      There is no reason why you must do that, but cases where you
      have many objects of the class continuously created but not
      in use (like with a socket server running them in parallel
      processes), then this can save you memory resources.
- This function does not reset/clear the CGPS::m... action members
      of the class.
      To do that, use CGPS::ClearResponseActionMembers().
function GetLastError()
Get the last error that occurred in the class as a text string.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with error message.
Notes:
    - This function is only useful directly after another function
        of the same class returned a failure result and the
        documentation of that says that last error information can be
        retrieved with this function.
    - When using the resulting text string in HTML/XML output, it is
        recommended to use a HTML/XML safe conversion function of the
        programming language that you are using like htmlspecialchars().
function IsValid()
Check if the currently selected data part contains any anomalies.
Function input:
    - None.
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE if no anomalies were detected in the currently
        selected data part in the CGPS class.
    - Boolean TRUE if an anomalies was detected in the currently
        selected data part in the CGPS class in which case you
        you can retrieve a description with CGPS::GetLastError().
Note:
    The result value (and possible error description of the
    anomaly that was detected) is set by CGPS::SelectDataPart()
    which CGPS::SetHttpData(), CGPS::SetTcpData(),
    CGPS::SetHexData() or CGPS::SetBinaryData() with valid
    automatically use to select the first (#0) data part for you.
    Even if any anomalies are detected in a data part, you can
    still retrieve information from it and should still be
    acknowledged to the module that you received it.
    But of course some information you can retrieve from the
    data part may be affected by the anomaly and possibly useless.
function GetSwitch()
Switch value type that tells what information is encoded in the currently selected record.
Function input:
    - None.
Function result:
    - The type of the currently selected record as one of the following Switch Value definitions:
        *** "Switch Value" definitions ***

  • SV_LowestPositionSwitch// Not a real Switch Value, but the lowest Switch Value that contains a probably accurate GPS information.
  • SV_Position// A record that you made the module write to the log (like commanded from the settings ACTION_GpsLog, or from your server with CGPS::mGpsLog or your LCD/Source-code with the SACT command). You can retrieve various info from this record with functions like CGPS::GetEventID(), CGPS::GetShake(), CGPS::GetGpsStatus(), CGPS::GetLatitudeSmall(), CGPS::GetFix(), CGPS::GetMaxDB(), CGPS::GetSpeedKPH(), CGPS::GetHeading(), CGPS::GetTemperatureCelcius(), CGPS::GetIndex(), CGPS::GetAccu(), CGPS::GetIO(), CGPS::GetReset()...
  • SV_PositionMotionUnknown// As SV_Position, but the GPS speed and heading info in the record are likely invalid because GPS receiver did not have that available when you logged the record or that you had the information invalidated by the module via SETTING_GpsSpeedInvalidateSeconds.
  • SV_PositionCompact// Small transmission size record (when SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType is set to GLST_PositionCompact) that only contains Date/Time/Lon/Lat/Speed/Heading/IO and not various other information that is available in SV_Position records.
  • SV_PositionMotionUnknownCompact// As SV_PositionCompact, but the GPS speed and heading info in the record are likely invalid because GPS receiver did not have that available when you logged the record or that you had the information invalidated by the module via SETTING_GpsSpeedInvalidateSeconds.
  • SV_PositionTripMeters// As SV_Position, but contains trip meters counter (see CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters()) instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset.
  • SV_PositionTravelledMeters// As SV_Position, but contains travelled meters counter (see CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters()) instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset.
  • SV_PositionAcceleration// As SV_Position, but contains acceleration X/Y/Z (11/11/10bit see CGPS::GetAcceleration...()) instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset.
  • SV_PositionAnalogInputs// As SV_Position, but contains analog inputs 1,2,3 and 4 (8bit see CGPS::GetAnalogInput...()) instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset.
  • SV_PositionCustom// As SV_Position, but contains additional custom data (see CGPS::GetCustomPositionData()) instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset.
  • SV_PositionTravelledMetersFuel// As SV_Position, but contains travelled meters counter (see CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters()) instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset and also a fuel level (see CGPS::GetFuel()).
  • SV_HighestPositionSwitch// Not a real Switch Value, but the highest Switch Value that contains a probably accurate GPS information.
  • SV_PowerUp// Status record the module creates automatically at (re)start-up (unless suppressed with SETTING_PowerUpRecordHandling) from which CGPS::GetPowerUpReason() may get you a useful reason. The date/time used in this record is the last recorded time at shutdown +10seconds because the actual time (and position) will only be known after the GPS receiver has determined it's first usable fix on a number GPS satellites.
  • SV_InternalStatus1// Status record telling that the internal GSM modem has been reset because no records from the log could have been transferred to the server for 15 minutes resulting in a proper acknowledge reply from your server in return. Check the result of CGPS::GetGsmCREG() of such a record for the latest status known of the modem before the reset and especially from a few records if you get them every 15 minutes which might tell you if there was some problem with the network provider of your SIM-card at that time. But of course when you are in an area where there is not enough signal available (or GSM antenna not properly connected/placed/working) for data communication or not supported by the network in a region, you get exactly the same symptoms. Also if the data to/from your server gets lost on the internet connection from your network provider to your internet provider or cabling to your server you get the same symptoms. And of course if you disconnect or power down your server or your server does not returns an accurately required response or too long delayed, you will of course get the same symptoms too. (this record type can be disabled with SETTING_DoNotSendInternalStatusMessages but is not advisable in most cases).
  • SV_Counters// Module counter readings. See CGPS::GetCounter...() functions. Logged from the ACTION_CountersLog of an event in the settings or CGPS::mCountersLog action commanded from your server. The logging of this record can be disabled with SETTING_DoNotLogCounters for if you only need other SV_Counters... record(s) that come together with this one.
  • SV_CountersHighestSpeed// Comes together with SV_Counters (unless disabled with SETTING_DoNotLogHighestSpeedWithCounters). Contains the same information as SV_Position, but the GPS info in the record is of the location where GPS derived speed was the highest during the trip since the last "Start Moving" trigger (see CGPS::GetShake() for more information).
  • SV_CountersAnalogInputs// Comes together with SV_Counters if enabled with SETTING_AnalogInputLoggingWithCounters. Contains readings of analog inputs, see CGPS::GetAnalogInput...() functions.
  • SV_CountersUser// Contains "User Counters" that were logged by executing ActionID 76. See CGPS::GetUserCounter() for retrieval and description.
  • SV_Network// This is the first record that the module transmits to the server over a new created data session on the network that the SIM-card was already registered onto. This record is transmitted asynchronously bypassing the log and the contents of the log afterward. So from this record, you can see over which network the records and from the timestamp even since when the network was usable again like after a period of network problems or the network being out of range to open a session and transfer data to the server.
  • SV_InternalStatus2// Internal status info 2 info. Normally you should not see many of these. If you which you can disable them with SETTING_DoNotSendInternalStatusMessages.
  • SV_RestartAnnouncement// Module is going to shut down for a restart later. Usually related to running on Li-ion backup battery power which can not be sustained anymore because of "problems" like battery too low or temperature too high.
  • SV_ReceivedSMS// Report record that the SIM-card in the module received an SMS text message. The sender's phone number can usually be retrieved from this record with CGPS::GetPhoneNumber(). From your LCD/source-code you can react/respond to certain contents of log it via system variable %S43. In that case you do not need report records for received SMS text messages, you can disable them with SETTING_DoNotLogReceivedSmsEvent. You can also have the SMS text recorded into the log with SETTING_LogReceivedSmsText.
  • SV_CalledByUnknownPhoneNumber// Report record that the SIM-card in the module received an incoming phone call but no "Caller ID" information was detected from the caller. In case you do not need these report records, you can disable them with SETTING_DoNotLogCalledByEvent.
  • SV_CalledByKnownPhoneNumber// Report record that the SIM-card in the module received an incoming phone call with additional "Caller ID" information that you can retrieve with CGPS::GetPhoneNumber(). In case you do not need these report records, you can disable them with SETTING_DoNotLogCalledByEvent.
  • SV_SettingsAccepted// Report from the module that it succesfully received the settings data you have uploaded from your server via the CGPS::mSettings action response member. The new settings will be used immediately by the module and if they contain a different server to transmit data to, then also this report record is also sent there (not to the server you uploaded the settings from). With CGPS::GetSettingsCrc(), you can retrieve the CRC of the settings you uploaded for verification purposes.
  • SV_SettingsRejected// Report from the module that it did receive the settings data you have uploaded from your server via the CGPS::mSettings action response member but, has refused it and is continuing with the settings it was already running on. With CGPS::GetSettingsError() you can retrieve the reason why the module rejected the settings data it received from your server.
  • SV_Acknowledge// Acknowledge as triggered by ACTION_ActionID or CGPS::mActionID filled with ActionID value 37 (asynchronous transmission).
  • SV_KeepAlive// As SV_Position, but because the GPS receiver could not determine a valid GPS fix at the position record was supposed to be logged, the last known GPS receiver info was used instead. The date/time used in this record is also from the used GPS information and not the time when this record was logged.
  • SV_TimeAlive// As SV_Position, but because the GPS receiver could not determine a valid GPS fix at the position record was supposed to be logged, the last known GPS receiver info was used instead. The date/time used in this record is from the module's software clock and not from used GPS information.
  • SV_KeepAliveTripMeters// As SV_KeepAlive, but contains trip meters counter instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters().
  • SV_TimeAliveTripMeters// As SV_TimeAlive, but contains trip meters counter instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters().
  • SV_KeepAliveTravelledMeters// As SV_KeepAlive, but contains travelled meters counter instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters().
  • SV_TimeAliveTravelledMeters// As SV_TimeAlive, but contains travelled meters counter instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters().
  • SV_KeepAliveAcceleration// As SV_KeepAlive, but contains Acceleration X and Y instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetAcceleration...().
  • SV_TimeAliveAcceleration// As SV_TimeAlive, but contains Acceleration X and Y instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetAcceleration...().
  • SV_KeepAliveAnalogInputs// As SV_KeepAlive, but contains analog inputs 1,2,3 and 4 (8bit) instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetAnalogInput...().
  • SV_TimeAliveAnalogInputs// As SV_TimeAlive, but contains analog inputs 1,2,3 and 4 (8bit) instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetAnalogInput...().
  • SV_KeepAliveCustom// As SV_KeepAlive, but contains additional custom data instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetCustomPositionData().
  • SV_TimeAliveCustom// As SV_TimeAlive, but contains additional custom data instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset. See CGPS::GetCustomPositionData().
  • SV_KeepAliveTravelledMetersFuel// As SV_KeepAlive, but contains travelled meters counter instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset and fuel level info from external source. See CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters() and CGPS::GetFuel().
  • SV_TimeAliveTravelledMetersFuel// As SV_TimeAlive, but contains travelled meters counter instead of Altitude/Temperature/Reset and fuel level info from external source. See CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters() and CGPS::GetFuel().
  • SV_PowerDownBackup1// A record logged by the module as internal status backup when it powers down or restarts by self decision by the settings or on command (unless disabled with SETTING_DoNotLogPowerDownBackupRecords). This record is omitted from transfer from the contents of the log to the server (unless enabled with SETTING_TransmitPowerDownBackupRecords). That is because the record is only used by the module itself when it (re)starts for last know timestamp and last known GPS fix details.
  • SV_ServerDataUploadAccepted// The data block you uploaded from the server was accepted. Usually this means that binary data that you uploaded to be written in the non volatile FLASH memory was successful.
  • SV_ServerDataUploadRejected// The data block you uploaded from the server was NOT accepted. Usually this means that the binary that you uploaded did not arrive/process in tact, so you will want to retry uploading the data again.
  • SV_Photo// Picture taken with camera (jpeg data included with this asynchronous transmission as extra binary data). See function CGPS::GetExtraDataSize().
  • SV_PhotoLog// Picture announcement (jpeg data is stored in following SV_PhotoLogData transmissions from the log). See function CGPS::GetPhotoLogDataSize().
  • SV_PhotoGpsLog// As SV_PhotoLog, but also includes the position of a recent GPS fix. See function CGPS::GetPhotoGpsTimeDifference().
  • SV_PhotoGps// As SV_Photo, but also includes the position of a recent GPS fix. See function CGPS::GetPhotoGpsTimeDifference().
  • SV_PhotoLogData// Picture data part that follows SV_PhotoLog and SV_PhotoGpsLog records. See function CGPS::GetPhotoLogDataBytes().
  • SV_LogDataHeader// Announcement header of data that was stored in the log (actual data is stored in additional SV_LogData records). See function CGPS::GetLogDataBytes() for a background description.
  • SV_LogData// Binary data part that follows the SV_LogDataHeader record. See function CGPS::GetLogDataBytes() for a background description.
  • SV_1WireDetached// Report record that an 1-Wire device was detached or active-RFID or RF-tag device went out of signal range. See CGPS::CanGetIButton() documentation for example. If you do not want this record logged, then you can disable them with SETTING_DoNotLog1WireDetach.
  • SV_iButton// Report record that an iButton device was attached/detached or 1-Wire device attached or a active-RFID / RF-tag device got inside/outside signal range. See CGPS::CanGetIButton() documentation for example. If you do not want this record logged, then you can disable them with SETTING_DoNotLog1WireAttach.
  • SV_Port1DataExtra// Module received data via serial port. (data included as extra binary data. see CGPS::GetExtraDataSize() function).
  • SV_Port2DataExtra// Module received data via serial port 1 or 2 [Rev8:125]. (data included as extra binary data. see CGPS::GetExtraDataSize() function).
  • SV_Port3DataExtra// Module received data via serial port. (data included as extra binary data. see CGPS::GetExtraDataSize() function).
  • SV_Port4DataExtra// Module received data via serial port 1, 2, 3 or 4 [Rev5 & Rev8:<125]. (data included as extra binary data. see CGPS::GetExtraDataSize() function).
  • SV_Port1Data// This record contains data bytes which the module received via serial port 1. See CGPS::GetPortDataBytes() for retrieving the data from this record and background information why the data in the record could actually be received by a different physical external serial port connector pins of the module than the record suggests.
  • SV_Port2Data// This record contains data bytes which the module received via serial port 2. See CGPS::GetPortDataBytes() for retrieving the data from this record and background information why the data in the record could actually be received by a different physical external serial port connector pins of the module than the record suggests.
  • SV_Port3Data// This record contains data bytes which the module received via serial port 3. See CGPS::GetPortDataBytes() for retrieving the data from this record and background information why the data in the record could actually be received by a different physical external serial port connector pins of the module than the record suggests.
  • SV_Port4Data// This record contains data bytes which the module received via serial port 4. See CGPS::GetPortDataBytes() for retrieving the data from this record and background information why the data in the record could actually be received by a different physical external serial port connector pins of the module than the record suggests.
  • SV_DigTach1// Various info received from a digital tachograph (speed/driver/distance/trip info). See CGPS::GetDigTach1...() functions.
  • SV_DigTachVIN// Vehicle Identification Number data from a digital tachograph. See CGPS::GetDigTachDataBytes() / CGPS::GetDigTachDataSize().
  • SV_DigTachVRN// Vehicle Registration Number data from a digital tachograph. See CGPS::GetDigTachDataBytes() / CGPS::GetDigTachDataSize().
  • SV_DigTachCARD1// Binary data from a digital tachograph. See CGPS::GetDigTachDataBytes() / CGPS::GetDigTachDataSize().
  • SV_DigTachCARD2// Binary data from a digital tachograph. See CGPS::GetDigTachDataBytes() / CGPS::GetDigTachDataSize().
  • SV_LcdData1// Part 1 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData2// Part 2 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData3// Part 3 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData4// Part 4 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData5// Part 5 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData6// Part 6 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData7// Part 7 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData8// Part 8 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData9// Part 9 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData10// Part 10 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData11// Part 11 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData12// Part 12 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData13// Part 13 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData14// Part 14 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData15// Part 15 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_LcdData16// Part 16 of data generated by a Type 2 LCD/source-code instruction slot. See CGPS::GetLcdData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData1// Part 1 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData2// Part 2 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData3// Part 3 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData4// Part 4 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData5// Part 5 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData6// Part 6 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData7// Part 7 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData8// Part 8 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData9// Part 9 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData10// Part 10 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData11// Part 11 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData12// Part 12 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData13// Part 13 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData14// Part 14 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData15// Part 15 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_1WireData16// Part 16 of data read from 1-Wire (e.g. iButton) device. See CGPS::Get1WireData...() functions.
  • SV_GsmCellScan// Contains MMC+MNC/LAC/CellID/Power results of the GSM cells detected during a scan with internal Quectel modem initiated by ActionID 145 or 151. All cells found during the scan no matter if they belong to the network of the used SIM card or even accessible to the SIM card are recorded in this record and whatever does not fit is recorded in a next record of the same type unlike with SV_GsmCellScanStrip records.
  • SV_GsmCellScanStrip// Contains MMC+MNC/LAC/CellID/Power results of the GSM cells detected during a scan with internal Quectel modem initiated by ActionID 156. GSM cells detected during the scan that do not belong to the network of the used SIM card or are not accessible to the SIM card are stripped and from remaining cell's also those that do not fit in together in a single record are stripped and not recorded in another record of the same type as with SV_GsmCellScan records.
  • SV_LowestInaccuratePositionSwitch// Not a real Switch, but the lowest Switch value that probably contains inaccurate GPS information.
  • SV_InaccuratePosition// As SV_Position, but GPS information is probably inaccurate.
  • SV_InaccuratePositionCompact// As SV_PositionCompact, but GPS information is probably inaccurate.
  • SV_InaccuratePositionTripMeters// As SV_PositionTripMeters, but GPS information is probably inaccurate.
  • SV_InaccuratePositionTravelledMeters// Like SV_PositionTravelledMeters, but GPS information is probably inaccurate.
  • SV_InaccuratePositionAcceleration// Like SV_PositionAcceleration, but GPS information is probably inaccurate.
  • SV_InaccuratePositionAnalogInputs// Like SV_PositionAnalogInputs, but GPS information is probably inaccurate.
  • SV_InaccuratePositionCustom// As SV_PositionCustom, but GPS information is probably inaccurate.
  • SV_InaccuratePositionTravelledMetersFuel// Like SV_PositionTravelledMetersFuel, but GPS information is probably inaccurate.
  • SV_HighestInaccuratePositionSwitch// Not a real Switch, but the highest Switch value that probably contains inaccurate GPS information.
  • SV_Invalid// Invalid switch value. Is returned if no valid data has been supplied to the class.

Notes:
    The module writes all information in its internal log as records
    and these records can be transmitted to the server (some are
    transmitted asynchronously bypassing the log like SV_Network).
    Because of the many different kinds of information that can be recorded,
    every record has a Switch Value, from which you can tell what kind of
    record it is and what information is stored in it.
    Therefore it is useful to store the Switch Value of every record in
    your database on the server too in which you store all records.
    That way, you can easily and quickly search for records with a specific
    Switch Value that contain the specific information that you are looking for.
    The Switch Value can be stored in a MySQL UNSIGNED TINYINT (=1 unsigned byte).
    On your server, you will also specifically want to know which info
    is available in a record with a certain Switch Value.
    For that you can use the CGPS::GetValidSwitchData() function which returns
    a string that contains a flag for each available info in a record.
    But instead you will probably want to make use of the various CGPS::CanGet...()
    functions which conveniently return a Boolean TRUE or FALSE depending
    if the info that they represent is available or not in the current record.
    The example server has an additional "view available info per Switch Value"
    feature built in, that generates a table from this info that gives you an
    idea of the info and usable extraction functions per Switch Value record type.
    http://qontrol-vision.com/cgpsexample.php?ShowSwitchTable

******
****** Background information on module data storage and transmissions
******
    The module packs all information into records and stores them into
    its internal log (except for a few asynchronous record types like
    SV_Network, SV_Acknowledge, SV_Photo and SV_PhotoGps that
    are attempted to be transmitted bypassing the log, so no retries
    either if for any reason the transmission attempt fails or for any
    reason does not reach the server properly or even at all).
    There are many different kind of records with a different Switch
    value, from which you can tell what kind of record it is and what
    information it contains.
    Therefore it is useful to store the Switch Value of every record in
    your database on the server too in which you store all records
    (1 unsigned byte value that fits in a MySQL UNSIGNED TINYINT).
    That way, your client application can easily and quickly find back
    records with a specific Switch Value that contain the information
    that you are looking for.
    On your server, you will also specifically want to know which info
    is available in a record with a certain Switch Value.
    For that you can use the CGPS::GetValidSwitchData() function which
    returns a string that contains a flag for each available info in a
    record.
    But instead you will probably want to make use of the various
    CGPS::CanGet...() functions which conveniently return a Boolean
    TRUE or FALSE depending if the info that they represent is
    available or not in the current record.
    The example server has an additional "view available info per
    Switch Value" built in, that generates a table from this info that
    gives you an idea of the info and usable extraction functions per
    Switch Value record.
    http://qontrol-vision.com/cgpsexample.php?ShowSwitchTable

    Under optimal conditions, the GPS antenna delivers the GPS
    receiver sufficient signal strength from multiple GPS satellites
    to determine a new reliable GPS-fix position from it every second.
    Therefore the action of logging a position record with GPS will
    wait until a usable position fix becomes available.
    If none becomes available within reasonable time, then instead of
    a SV_Position... record, a SV_KeepAlive... or SV_TimeAlive...
    record is created instead (depending your choice with
    SETTING_UseSystemTimeForKeepAlive or in section 54 of the
    settings application).
    (not recommended to do so, but the firmware default wait time
    length can be overridden with SETTING_KeepAliveTimeOutSecs
    for the normal mode and with
    SETTING_KeepAliveTimeOutSecsPowerSaving for the
    power-saving mode because then the GPS receiver is only
    temporarily switched on every time a GPS fix is required and
    then it will take longer to get one (also possible in Advanced
    section 50 of the settings application)).

    Transmission of the contents of the log is usually triggered by the
    SETTING_GprsTransmitInterval (transmission settings mentioned
    here are also possible via the settings application in section 60).
    When a transmission of the log contents is triggered, and there are
    one or more records in the log, then the module will automatically
    combine them as a batch (up to SETTING_MaxBatchTransmission
    ("Maximum batch size" in section 60 of the settings application)
    and sends them batched together in a single transmission to the
    server.
    This really saves a lot of network data usage compared to a single
    record per transmission, so you may want to do transmissions to the
    server less frequently than you store records in the log (possibly
    combined with transmitting the log contents its it reached a number
    of records SETTING_TransmitLogWhenGpsRecordsReaches).
    In case you have one or more events (EVENT_...) that are special
    to you and want of which you want a record created by them
    specifically want to be delivered to the server without any delay,
    then specifically *ONLY* for those special events activate the
    action "Transmit log" (ACTION_TransmitLog).
    That triggers a transmission of the log contents to the server
    immediately (independent from the automatic transmission interval
    SETTING_GprsTransmitInterval and even if that is disabled by
    setting logging mode to "Data logging with GSM on"
    (SETTING_ModuleDataLogging set to MDL_DataLoggingGsmOn)).

    For the first transmission (like after a power-up, getting new
    settings or a restart (things like updating firmware and erasing
    the log causes that too), the module will try to open a GPRS
    session via your SIM card and open a socket connection to the
    server using the IP and port supplied in the settings for the
    primary server (SETTING_PrimaryServerIP and
    SETTING_PrimaryServerTcpPort) and transmits the record(s)
    there in a format that you supplied yourself
    (SETTING_PrimaryTcpDataFormat).
    Then the module waits for an acknowledge from the server as a sign
    that it received and stored the data.
    Only then the module deletes the transmitted record(s)
    and continues transmitting possible other records until the log.
    But if no proper server response is received, the module will of
    course not delete the records and re-transmit them again after
    about a minute.
    If that continues for about five minutes without proper response,
    then the module will switch to the settings that are supplied for
    the secondary server settings and do the whole process there.
    So do not forget to enter settings for the secondary server too,
    because if you leave those blank, it will use the defaults of the
    manufacturer's evaluation server.
    Convenient while performing tests when have no proof yet that both
    your server and settings are correct and successful data transfer
    are possible with them and you want to find out if a switch is
    made to that evaluation server from where you can upload new
    settings again.
    Of course for real use you will *ALWAYS* enter both primary and
    secondary server settings.
    If you have only one server, then simply enter the same settings
    as you use for the primary server.
    It does not matter of course if the module switches between two
    different servers or the same server.
    As soon as using one of the two server settings results in a proper
    acknowledge being returned, it will stay there and only start
    switching servers again when that stops.
    Having two different servers can of course increase accessibility
    for the module and not to forget your customers.
    You will of course want to make your servers synchronize their
    received data with each other, having all records transmitted by
    the modules on both of them.

    All data over the internet is of course IP based which you
    provide with SETTING_PrimaryServerIP/SETTING_SecondaryServerIP.
    But since Rev8:109, you can optionally supply a domain name in the
    settings for the primary and/or secondary server
    (SETTING_PrimaryServerDomain / SETTING_SecondaryServerDomain).
    If your server's IP is also registered to a domain name like
    www.blablabla.com, then you could additionally enter that too in
    the settings.
    If supplied, then at module (re)start it will send that to the DNS
    server that is specified on the SIM-card for translation to IP.
    If an IP address is returned, then that IP address will be used.
    But if that does not result in an IP address returned or one to
    which transfer attempts keep failing, then the IP address you
    provided will be used instead.
    It depends completely on the availability and quality of the
    database on the DNS server of your SIM card provider if it
    knows about your domain name and IP you registered to it.
    But if all is OK there, then after an IP change of your server,
    the modules would eventually automatically end up on your (new)
    server if you do supply the domain name you registered it to.
    Logically you will have extra power+data+time consumption when
    you provide a domain name which you likely do not want for
    example with a project in which you make the module wake-up
    from power-down mode once a day to determine and transmit a
    position or something and go into power-down mode again when
    when finished to keep it running as long as possible on a battery.
    But in any other project where multiple to infinite subsequent
    transmissions after module (re)start are normal,

    Of course to be able to use the a GSM network, one must be found
    first that allows registering onto it with the used SIM-card and
    is all done automatically when you turn on the GSM modem.
    When that is done, in and outgoing SMS text messages and phone
    calls are already possible.
    But to use that for data transfer over the internet, a data
    session needs to be opened and is done automatically as soon
    as a transfer of contents in the log is initiated which
    SETTING_GprsTransmitInterval does.
    Directly when a new data session is opened, a socket connection
    request is sent over that data session to the IP address of
    your server.
    And when accepted, over the opened socket connection the an
    asynchronous SV_Network record, so you can see when a session
    was opened and the records that follow after that
    are transmitted over.
    To every transmission you receive, you must immediate return
    a proper acknowledge to let the module know that the just
    transmitted data was received at the server and is to be deleted
    by the module, otherwise it retry send the same data again
    after a minute until it does receive an immediate proper response.

    The module keeps re-using the same socket connection to the
    server to save network data usage and data+power+time
    consumption to set up an new socket connection.
    But when no immediate proper response is received to any
    transmission and it will discard the socket connection and
    request a new one from the server.
    So you will want to make your server not to close the socket
    connection or stop listening to it or not immediately return
    a proper acknowledge.
    Server applications like HTTP servers usually have a
    "Socket Timeout" feature that closes an open socket after a number
    of seconds has passed without data going over the connection.
    Setting that higher than the frequency that you make the module
    transmit data to the server, would result in a connection never
    being closed by the server application, saving you network data
    usage and time for connections not being opened and closed every
    time.
    For HTTP server applications such a setting is usually called
    something like: "keep-alive(-timeout)".
    If you set the "Socket timeout in seconds" (SETTING_SocketTimeout)
    at the module side 5 seconds higher than the frequency at which
    you make it transfer something new to the server and your server
    5 seconds on top of that, then both sides should already
    keep a socket connection open for continuous re-use.
    Since a HTTP server only supports HTTP protocol commands like
        GET <FilePathName> HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: www.MyHost.com\r\n\r\n
    to request the contents of the <FilePathName>  file, you can make
    the module transmit such data to your server.
    Use a "TCP data format" (SETTING_PrimaryTcpDataFormat) like:
        GET /MyScript.php?MyVariable=%s HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: www.MyHost.com\r\n\r\n
    And a "TCP extra data format" (SETTING_PrimaryTcpExtraDataFormat) like:
        POST /MyScript.php?MyVariable=%s HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: www.MyHost.com\r\nContent-Type: application/octet-stream\r\nContent-Length: %d\r\n\r\n%x
    Of course the <FilePathName> in the above example is not some
    static "/MyFile.html" file but something like a .php script file
    which when properly configured is detected from the extension and
    instead of the contents of a file, PHP started to execute the
    contents of the "/MyScript.php" file with arguments "MyVariable=%s"
    and the output of that used and returned by the HTTP server as
    if it was the contents of a static file.
    The %s used above tells the module where to insert the actual
    data that you wanted to transfer to your server in the first place.
    For %s the module will encode the data to be sent into a text
    string existing only of characters that are allowed in the
    HTTP protocol.
    So effectively your script gets executed with MyVariable set
    to a textual data string which you in your script put into
    the CGPS class using CGPS::SetHttpData(MyVariable) and after
    retrieving and storing information from the data in the CGPS
    class, you use CGPS::BuildResponseHTTP() and use the result of
    as (the only) text output of your script so the HTTP server
    will return that to the module which will then receive an
    immediate proper acknowledge in return which tells it that
    the just transmitted data is received and stored properly on at
    the server and to be deleted from the log.
    Without a immediate proper response in return, the module will
    close the socket, open a new one and resend the data again after
    a minute and keep retrying as long as needed, accumulating
    additional records you make record in the log in the meantime.
    Together with that response you can upload things from your server
    at times that you want to, like new settings that control the
    behavior of the module, firmware update, commands, LCD/source-code
    to execute, ...

    Since with the above HTTP server method example the module
    transmissions are just like that of a web browser in which you
    enter an URL or click a link, it should work on even the cheapest
    shared host account servers or server running on a NAS device,
    but of course you can also install a free HTTP server on a computer.
    And usually even work cheap contract SIM-cards that support
    browsing the web but having other kinds of data or ports blocked.
    But since a HTTP server requires and returns quite a lot of
    overhead (use server tester and notice the data colored red
    instead of green in the report) in the form of data/info to/from
    web browsers, you may want to create your own socket server and
    run that for your modules to transfer data to your server.
    That will save you the data usage of that overhead and also allows
    you two way communication over the open socket, since a HTTP server
    only allows sending data as a response to incoming data.
    So you could the upload commands and such to the module from your
    server whenever you which over the open socket connection.
function GetValidSwitchData()
Retrieve Valid Switch Markers for all the info that is available in
the currently selected record.
Function input:
    - None.
Function result:
    - A string containing one or more of the following definitions:
        *** "Valid Switch Marker" definitions ***

  • VSM_LatLong// CGPS::CanGetLatLong() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_LatLongInaccurate// CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_LatLongMargin// CGPS::CanGetLatLongMargin() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Altitude// CGPS::CanGetAltitude() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_AltitudeMargin// CGPS::CanGetAltitudeMargin() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Speed// CGPS::CanGetSpeed() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Heading// CGPS::CanGetHeading() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Accu// CGPS::CanGetAccu() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_GsmNetworkID// CGPS::CanGetGsmNetworkID() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Temperature// CGPS::CanGetTemperature() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Reset// CGPS::CanGetReset() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Index// CGPS::CanGetIndex() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Shake// CGPS::CanGetShake() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_HDOP// CGPS::CanGetHDOP() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_MaxDB// CGPS::CanGetMaxDB() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_View// CGPS::CanGetView() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Fix// CGPS::CanGetFix() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Fstr// CGPS::CanGetFstr() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Version// CGPS::CanGetVersion() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_IMSI// CGPS::CanGetIMSI() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_IO// CGPS::CanGetIO() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_GpsFirmwareCRC// CGPS::CanGetGpsFirmwareCrc() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_PhoneNumber// CGPS::CanGetPhoneNumber() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_SettingsCRC// CGPS::CanGetSettingsCrc() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_EventID// CGPS::CanGetEventID() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_CGACT// CGPS::CanGetGsmCGACT() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_CGATT// CGPS::CanGetGsmCGATT() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_CREG// CGPS::CanGetGsmCREG() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_GpsHighestMaxDB// CGPS::CanGetGpsHighestMaxDB() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_RestartCause// CGPS::CanGetRestartCause() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Counters// CGPS::CanGetCounters() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_CounterTripMeters// CGPS::CanGetCounterTripMeters() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_CounterTravelledMeters// CGPS::CanGetCounterTravelledMeters() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_ExtraDataSize// CGPS::CanGetExtraDataSize() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_PortData// CGPS::CanGetPortData() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_HardwareStatus// CGPS::CanGetHardwareStatus() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_iButton// CGPS::CanGetIButton() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_LcdData// CGPS::CanGetLcdData() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_1WireData// CGPS::CanGet1WireData() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_PhotoGpsTimeDiff// CGPS::CanGetPhotoGpsTimeDifference() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_AnalogInputs// CGPS::CanGetAnalogInputs() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_GpsStatus// CGPS::CanGetGpsStatus() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_AdditionalIO// CGPS::CanGetAdditionalIO() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_MiscStatus// CGPS::CanGetMiscStatus() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_SettingsError// CGPS::CanGetSettingsError() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_AccelerationX// CGPS::CanGetAccelerationX() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_AccelerationY// CGPS::CanGetAccelerationY() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_AccelerationZ// CGPS::CanGetAccelerationZ() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_PhotoLogDataSize// CGPS::CanGetPhotoLogDataSize() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_PhotoLogDataBytes// CGPS::CanGetPhotoLogDataBytes() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_CustomPositionData// CGPS::CanGetCustomPositionData() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_LogDataType// CGPS::CanGetLogDataType() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_LogDataGpsTimeDiff// CGPS::CanGetLogDataGpsTimeDifference() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_LogDataSize// CGPS::CanGetLogDataSize() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_LogDataBytes// CGPS::CanGetLogDataBytes() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_GsmFirmwareCrc// CGPS::CanGetGsmFirmwareCrc() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_SimPin// CGPS::CanGetSimPin() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_PhotoPort// CGPS::CanGetPhotoPort() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_Fuel// CGPS::CanGetFuel() gives boolean result: TRUE
  • VSM_UserCounter// CGPS::CanGetUserCounter() gives boolean result: TRUE

Notes:
    You will probably want to use the various CGPS::CanGet...()
    functions instead.
    They conveniently return a Boolean TRUE or FALSE depending if the
    info that they represent is available or not in the current record.
    To make that decision, they automatically check the valid Switch
    markers for you.
function GetDataPartCount()
Retrieve the number of data parts that are available in the class.
Function input:
    - None.
Function result:
    - Value of number of data parts.
Notes:
    After using functions like CGPS::SetHttpData(), CGPS::SetTcpData
    CGPS::SetBinaryData() or CGPS::SetHexData() to set module data
    into the class, this function can be used to determine the number of
    parts that the data consists of.
    Use function CGPS::SelectDataPart() to select a part if more that
    one is available.
function SelectDataPart(DataPartNumber)
Select one of the data parts that are available in the class.
Function input:
    - DataPartNumber: Value of the data part that is to be selected.
        Where value 0 means the first data part.
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE or FALSE.
Notes:
    - On FALSE result, the class detected an anomaly in the currently
        selected data part, of which you can retrieve a description
        with CGPS::GetLastError().
        You can still use all Get...() functions to retrieve
        information from the data in the class, but of course some of
        their results may be affected by the detected anomaly.
    - With this function you select the data part of the total number
        of parts that you want to have all Get...() functions of the
        class to extract the information from of which part number 0
        (which is the first part and is already automatically selected
        after putting new module data in the class with functions like
        CGPS::SetHttpData(), CGPS::SetHexData(), CGPS::SetBinaryData()
        and CGPS::SetTcpData()).
    - With CGPS::GetDataPartCount() you can retrieve the total
        number of data parts in the class which you can select with
        this function.
        Suppose that function returns 10, then with this function you
        can select them individually from the first part 0, to the
        last part 9.
function SetHttpData(HttpData)
Initialize the class with an HTTP encoded data string as received directly from a module.
Function input:
    - HttpData: TCP data string that was received from a module.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPS::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
- The class automatically clears itself before initializing itself
      with the new data you set, so no need to call CGPS::Clear() first.
      Though the CGPS:m... action response members are only automatically
      cleared by the constructor of the class at the time you create
      an object of it.
      Call CGPS::ClearResponseActionMembers() yourself first to reset/clear
      them first from any settings or data you (or the class itself)
      put in them at previous use.
- After the initialization with the data that you have set into the
      class, use CGPS::GetDataPartCount() to retrieve the number of
      records that were found in the data and use CGPS::SelectDataPart()
      to select the record (the first record #0 is already selected for you
      and the result of that can be retrieved with CGPS::IsValid()) that
      you want to get info from with the other method functions of the CGPS
      class.
- See CGPS::GetBinaryData() about database storage information.
function GetHttpData()
Retrieve the currently selected data part encoded as a text string.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    Text string that contains case sensitive ASCII characters
    (HTTP-URL safe).
Notes:
    When storing the data in a database, it is advisable to store the
    full data string instead of separate information items that you
    extract from it.
    That way, you will always store ALL available information in a
    small compressed form from which you can always extract all
    information with the CGPS class.
    The data string that is returned by this function can be stored in
    a MySQL TINYBLOB field.
    See CGPS::GetBinaryData() function for a compacter storage
    of the same data.
    See CGPS::SelectDataPart() function for selecting a data part.
function SetTcpData(Imei, TcpData)
Initialize the class with data that was received via a TCP socket server
Function input:
    - Imei: Text string with the IMEI number of the module, which
        if the provided BinaryData already includes an IMEI in
        which case the IMEI string you provide is allowed to be bogus.
        Since the first transmission over a new socket connection
        always includes the IMEI, you can retrieve that with
        CGPS::GetImei() and use that result for subsequent
        transmissions over the same socket which depending on your
        CGPS::mOmitIdentification use do not include the IMEI
        because you know it already from the first transmission.
    - BinaryData: Binary bytes received from the module via a socket server.
Function result:
    >0 to signal how many bytes of the provided data were succesfully
        read into the CGPS class of a "TCP data format"
        (SETTING_PrimaryTcpDataFormat and
        SETTING_SecondaryTcpDataFormat) of "%b" or the format
        "%s\n" for modules older than Rev8/9:438 which do not support %b.
        Any additional bytes after that in the provided data were part
        of the same transmission of the module, so you will want to put
        in the remaining data again from that point after you are
        finished extracting info from the data that you have already put
        into the CGPS class now.
    =0 to signal that the provided data was not accepted, use
        CGPS::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
    <0 to signal how many bytes of the provided data were succesfully
        read into the CGPS class of a "TCP extra data format"
        (SETTING_PrimaryTcpExtraDataFormat and
        SETTING_SecondaryTcpExtraDataFormat) of "%s\r%d\r%x\n".
        The value is intentionally negative though (so make it positive,
        for example simply multiplying it by -1), to let you know that
        more bytes follow after that being extra module data that is
        part of the same transmission in the following format:
        "<decimal length as ASCII text>\r<the extra data bytes>\n".
        So from the offset returned by the CGPS class, simply read the
        first bytes up-to the "\r" (carriage return byte) and you have
        the length of the extra data bytes in ASCII text that follows
        after that as the extra module data.
        The CGPS::GetSwitch() result of the CGPS class will tell you
        what that extra module data contains.
        The "\n" (new line byte) that follows at the end is part of the
        same transmission, but not part of the extra module data block.
        Any additional bytes after that in the provided data were part
        of the same transmission of the module, so you will want to put
        in the remaining data again from that point after you are
        finished extracting info from the data that you have already put
        into the CGPS class now.
Notes:
- The class automatically clears itself before initializing itself
      with the new data you set, so no need to call CGPS::Clear() first.
      Though the CGPS:m... action response members are only automatically
      cleared by the constructor of the class at the time you create
      an object of it.
      Call CGPS::ClearResponseActionMembers() yourself first to reset/clear
      them first from any settings or data you (or the class itself)
      put in them at previous use.
- After the initialization with the data that you have set into the
      class, use CGPS::GetDataPartCount() to retrieve the number of
      records that were found in the data and use CGPS::SelectDataPart()
      to select the record (the first record #0 is already selected for you
      and the result of that can be retrieved with CGPS::IsValid()) that
      you want to get info from with the other method functions of the CGPS
      class.
- See CGPS::GetBinaryData() about database storage information.
function SetHexData(Imei, HexData)
Initialize the class with data that was previously decoded with CGPS::GetHexData()
Function input:
    - Imei: Text string with the IMEI number of the module.
    - Hex: Text string with hexadecimal representation of the binary data.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPS::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
- The class automatically clears itself before it gets initialized
      with the new data you set, so no need to call CGPS::Clear() first.
      Though the CGPS:m... action response members are only automatically
      cleared by the constructor of the class at the time you create
      an object of it.
      Call CGPS::ClearResponseActionMembers() yourself first to reset/clear
      them first from any settings or data you (or the class itself)
      put in them at previous use.
- The class automatically selects the record you entered so you do not
      have to call CGPS::SelectDataPart(0) to select the one and only
      record you set in the class, you can use CGPS::IsValid() to receive
      the result of that automatic selection.
- See CGPS::GetBinaryData() about database storage information.
function GetHexData()
Retrieve the currently selected data part a hexadecimal ASCII text string.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with hexadecimal representation of the binary data.
Notes:
    When storing data in a database, it is advisable to store the full
    data string instead of separate information items that you extract
    from it.
    That way, you will always store ALL available information in a
    small compressed form from which you can always extract all
    information with the CGPS class.
    The data string that is returned by this function can be stored in
    a MySQL TINYBLOB field.
    See CGPS::GetBinaryData() for a binary string of the same data.
    See CGPS::SelectDataPart() for selecting a data part.
function SetBinaryData(Imei, BinaryData)
Initialize the class with data that was already decoded by CGPS::GetBinaryData()
Function input:
    - Imei: Text string with the IMEI number of the module.
    - BinaryData: Binary bytes of the module data.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPS::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
- The class automatically clears itself before it gets initialized
      with the new data you set, so no need to call CGPS::Clear() first.
      Though the CGPS:m... action response members are only automatically
      cleared by the constructor of the class at the time you create
      an object of it.
      Call CGPS::ClearResponseActionMembers() yourself first to reset/clear
      them first from any settings or data you (or the class itself)
      put in them at previous use.
- The class automatically selects the record you entered so you do not
      have to call CGPS::SelectDataPart(0) to select the one and only
      record you set in the class, you can use CGPS::IsValid() to receive
      the result of that automatic selection.
- See CGPS::GetBinaryData() about database storage information.
function GetBinaryData()
Retrieve the currently selected data part as binary data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Binary bytes.
Notes:
    The returned data of this function is the selected data part in its
    smallest form.
    When storing data in a database, this is the advisable storage form,
    instead of many separate information items because it already
    contains them.
    That way, you will really always store ALL available information in
    a small compressed form from which you can always extract all
    information with the CGPS class.
    The only thing this data does not contain is the IMEI code, which
    you must retrieve separately with the CGPS::GetImei() function.
    The binary data can be stored in a MySQL TINYBLOB field.
    With CGPS::SetBinaryData() you can put the data back into the
    CGPS class which you have previously stored in your database.
    See CGPS::GetHexData() for the same data as hexadecimal ASCII
    string.
    See CGPS::SelectDataPart() for selecting a data part.
function GetUtcTime()
UTC date/time of the data as a timestamp.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    TimeStamp as double precision floating point value.
    To get a date/time text as text, you wil probably want to use:
    - With PHP use the timestap with functions like date() and gmdate().
        date_default_timezone_set('UTC');
        print(date($pcGPS->GetUtcTime()));
    - With .NET you will probably want to use the GetUtcDateTime
      method instead that returns a DateTime object directly:
        Console.Write(cGPS.GetUtcDateTime().ToString());
        Console.Write(cGPS.GetUtcDateTime().ToLocalTime().ToString());
    - With JavaScript you will probably want to use this method:
        var cDate=new Date(cGPS.GetUtcTime()*1000);
        document.write(CGPShelper.htmlspecialchars(cDate.toLocaleString()));
Notes:
    The date/time is in UTC (so including proper leap seconds
    calculation which CGPS::GetGpsTime() does not do).
    It normally reflects the date/time when the record was recorded
    in the log by the module and for SV_Position... records it is
    of the actual GPS position information that is in the record.
    There are only a few records with exceptions:
        - SV_KeepAlive... : Since there was no GPS fix when one was
            requested to be logged, together with the last fix
            available at that time also the date/time of that fix was used.
        - SV_TimeAlive... : Since there was no GPS fix when one was
            requested to be logged, together with the last fix
            available at that time the date/time of system clock at logging
            time was used.
        - SV_PhotoGps/SV_PhotoGpsLog/SV_LogDataHeader : System
            time and GPS info can be different from the included
            picture's or logged data location.
            See also CGPS::GetPhotoGpsTimeDifference() and
            CGPS::GetLogDataGpsTimeDifference().
        - SV_CountersHighestSpeed : The GPS fix information from the
            point during the trip where the highest speed was measured
            and the date/time of that fix was used.
        - SV_PowerUp(/SV_Network) : The date/time of the system clock
            is used as normal, but if the unit was just switched on
            (and thus the GPS receiver too) it usually did not
            establish a fix sync the system clock with.
            For projects where the module will be rendered powerless,
            you will want to us a module type that has an internal
            backup battery.
Info:
    The module's system clock of the module starts at GPS time January
    1st 2000 midnight on power-up or reboot (so with leap seconds
    correction that would be seventeen seconds earlier in UTC time).
    If at that time a record with a newer date/time is found in the log
    (even if it was already sent to the server) that date/time plus 10
    seconds is used instead.
    On every GPS fix, the system clock is automatically synchronized
    with the date/time derived from the GPS satellites.
    This normally happens every second when the GPS receiver is turned
    on, which the module automatically does continuously while the
    "Power saving mode" of the module is not active.

    Because some records like SV_PowerUp is logged directly when the
    module restarts, the "plus 10" seconds method will still make such
    records have the correct date/time even though the GPS receiver has
    not had the time to establish the first GPS fix yet after it was
    powered on by the module.
    But of course when you remove the power from the module for some,
    the date/time of these records will also be old until the system
    clock gets synced by the first GPS-fix becomes available.
    The module will automatically turn on the GPS receiver while the
    "Power saving mode" is not active.
    And at times when there is no GPS fix, the system clock is
