    automatically incremented to keep track of the current date/time.

    For projects in which there is never is a GPS antenna/signal or
    even a GPS receiver, you can synchronize the system clock of the
    module yourself to your current server's date/time by setting
    CGPS::mSyncTime to boolean true.
    You will want to do that for example whenever you receive the first
    above mentioned SV_PowerUp (or SV_Network) record.
    (e.g. if($pcGPS->GetSwitch()==SV_Network) $pcGPS->mSyncTime=true; )
    And then afterward sync the clock from the server about once a day
    because the system clock can have a deviation of about 1 percent.
function GetUtcTimeMySQL()
UTC date/time of the data in SQL query format (yyyymmddhhmmss text).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - ASCII text string in yyyymmddhhmmss format (year/month/day/hour/minute/second).
Notes:
    The text string is generated from the UTC time of the CGPS::GetUtcTime() function,
    which is adjusted with leap seconds unlike the CGPS::GetGpsTimeMySQL() function.
    See CGPS::GetUtcTime() function notes for additional information.
function GetImei()
International Mobile Equipment Identification number of the module.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - A text string with the 15 digit IMEI number.
Notes:
    This number should be used if you need to identify a specific module.
    The IMEI code consists of 15 decimal digits and can be stored in a MySQL BIGINT field (=8 bytes).
function IsForwardedByGateway()
Check if the data was forwarded by a gateway and not received directly from a module.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE if data was forwarded by a gateway.
Notes:
    A gateway forwards module data as if the module directly transmits to your server.
    You can still use the CGPS::BuildResponse...() functions to create a proper server
    response.
    But if you use any of the response action class members, the commands will not
    be send to a module, but to the gateway that is only forwarding the data.
function CanGetEventID()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetEventID()
ID code value of the event(s) that triggered the module to log the GPS position.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - The 16bit Event ID code (see explanation of the code values below).
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetEventID()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    You make the module log the current GPS position by activating the
    action to do so for the various events you want (e.g. have
    ACTION_GpsLog executed when EVENT_... triggers).
    The SV_Position... records created by that do not only contain
    the GPS position but also an event ID value indicating the event(s)
    that triggered the GPS position to be logged.

    Because it is possible that more than one event triggered the GPS
    position to be logged before one becomes available to be logged,
    the ID code used in the record can be overwritten by multiple
    events and then will not always be able to determine which events
    triggered.
    Therefore if you rely on the EventID in your server application to
    determine event occurrences, then will want have the EventID
    records separated with SETTING_SeparateEventIdTransmissions
    (or in section 54 of the settings application make sure "Do not
    separate EventID logs" is not activated").
    That way a separate record will be created in the log with the
    same GPS position, but with their own ID code for you to always
    be able to determine the individual triggers of the events.
   
    Special note:
        When an action to log the current GPS position is initiated
        while there is no current GPS information available, then after
        a timeout a SV_KeepAlive.../SV_TimeAlive... record
        is created instead of the requested SV_Position... record.
        This record will contain the actual event ID, but will have
        last known GPS information.
        If then within reasonable time the GPS receiver does provide
        a position based on a fix, the an additional SV_Position...
        record is logged intentionally having an event ID value 0
        (meaning "undefined" with all bits cleared), so you will still
        have a GPS position for the original event without having it
        seem like the actual event triggered twice.
        For Rev5 series where this is more common, you can disable the
        creation of such records with undefined event ID value with
        SETTING_NoGpsLogsWithUndefinedEventId (or in section 54
        of the settings application).

The example server source code contains an example to convert the
event ID value that this function returns into readable text.
Search for the text: //Create text from the event(s) in EventID

Below is a textual description of the 16 bits event ID value itself:

The bits in the event ID value:
    - Bit 15: Timer 1 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_1
    - Bit 14: Timer 2 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_2
    - Bit 13: Timer 5 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_5
    - Bit 12: Timer 6 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_6
    - Bit 11: Multiple non identical events occurred and overwrote each other
    - Bit 10: Multiple identical events occurred and overwrote each other
    - Bit 9..0: Event value (see event value descriptions below).
    (NOTE: If bit 10 and/or bit 11 is set, you know that you actually
    have lost the information how many and/or which multiple events
    occurred and together triggered the record to be logged and will
    not happen if you have all events separated in separated records
    as mentioned earlier).

The event in (bit 9..0) of the ID value:

    Special logging
    ---------------
    0 = Undefined or an additional automatic logging of the module,
    when a GPS-fix becomes available shortly after a previous logging
    with which it was forced to use a SV_TimeAlive... or
    SV_KeepAlive... record instead of the requested SV_Position...
    record because no GPS-fix available within the timeout period for
    the logging. So the event is intentionally set to 0/undefined for
    the automatic additional logging to update the server of the GPS
    location to not make it think the previous event occurred twice.

    Digital Input / Output
    ----------------------
    11 = EVENT_IO_1A (equivalent of 1st event line in section 11 of the settings application).
    21 = EVENT_IO_1B (equivalent of 2nd event line in section 11 of the settings application).
    12 = EVENT_IO_2A (equivalent of 3rd event line in section 11 of the settings application).
    22 = EVENT_IO_2B (equivalent of 4th event line in section 11 of the settings application).
    13 = EVENT_IO_3A (equivalent of 5th event line in section 11 of the settings application).
    23 = EVENT_IO_3B (equivalent of 6th event line in section 11 of the settings application).
    14 = EVENT_IO_4A (equivalent of 7th event line in section 11 of the settings application).
    24 = EVENT_IO_4B (equivalent of 8th event line in section 11 of the settings application).

    Timer
    -----
    32768 = Timer 1 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_1. NOTE: Timer 1 is recorded a separate bit (15) in the EventID and not by this value.
    16384 = Timer 2 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_2. NOTE: Timer 2 is recorded a separate bit (14) in the EventID and not by this value.
    33 = Timer 3 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_3.
    34 = Timer 4 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_4.
    8192 = Timer 5 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_5. NOTE: Timer 5 is recorded a separate bit (13) in the EventID and not by this value.
    4096 = Timer 6 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_6. NOTE: Timer 6 is recorded a separate bit (12) in the EventID and not by this value.
    37 = Timer 7 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_7.
    38 = Timer 8 expired and restarted EVENT_TIMERS_8.

    Miscellaneous
    -------------------
    40 = Stopped moving EVENT_StopMoving
    41 = Started moving EVENT_StartMoving
    42 = Travelled distance trigger EVENT_DISTANCE_1
    43 = Changed direction EVENT_HEADING_Degrees
    44 = While moving EVENT_WhileMoving
    45 = While not moving EVENT_WhileNotMoving
    48 = While roaming EVENT_WhileRoaming
    50 = Unknown or missing number for incoming call EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone
    51 = Matching number for incoming call #1 EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1
    52 = Matching number for incoming call #2 EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy2
    53 = Matching number for incoming call #3 EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy3
    54 = Unknown or missing number for incoming SMS EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone
    55 = Matching number for incoming SMS #1 EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1
    56 = Matching number for incoming SMS #2 EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy2
    57 = Matching number for incoming SMS #3 EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy3
    60 = Module will power-down within 3 minutes EVENT_PowerDown
    61 = Successful GPRS transmission EVENT_ServerTransmitSuccess
    62 = Module (re)started EVENT_RestartModule
    63 = While in power-saving mode EVENT_PowerSaving
    64 = Power supply above EVENT_VOLTAGE_Above
    65 = Power supply below EVENT_VOLTAGE_Below
    66 = Received GPS-fix EVENT_ReceivedGpsFix
    67 = Output(s) changed EVENT_OutputsStatusChange
    68 = Above speed limit EVENT_SPEED_Above
    69 = Below speed limit (after being above limit) EVENT_SPEED_Below
    70 = Custom (non standard specific projects)
    71 = iButton/1-Wire device attach EVENT_AttachIButton
    72 = iButton/1-Wire device detach EVENT_DetachIButton
    75 = GPS current out of range start EVENT_GpsCurrentOutOfRangeStart
    76 = GPS current out of range end EVENT_GpsCurrentOutOfRangeEnd
    77 = While GPS current out of range EVENT_GpsCurrentWhileOutOfRange
    78 = Received serial data EVENT_ReceivedSerialData
    81 = Daily time a EVENT_TIME_1
    82 = Daily time b EVENT_TIME_2
    85 = Input pattern 1 EVENT_InputPattern1
    86 = Input pattern 2 EVENT_InputPattern2
    87 = Input pattern 3 EVENT_InputPattern3
    88 = Hardware pulse counter measured pulses per second (Hertz) above condition value set for EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterAbove
    89 = Hardware pulse counter measured pulses per second (Hertz) below or equal to condition value set for EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterBelowOrEqual
    91 = Between times a EVENT_TIMES_1
    92 = Between times b EVENT_TIMES_2
    95 = Action option executed via LCD/source-code instruction slot Type 10
    96 = Action initiated by module command SACT(=1,...)
    97 = Used for SMS only, transmission triggered by module command POS or acknowledge to incoming call/SMS.
    98 = SMS initiated action, triggered by the 8 digit "action option" code delivered by a SMS from <Alert-SMS phone number 1>.
    99 = Server initiated action via action members (CGPS::m...) of the CGPS class.

    Acceleration/Deceleration
    ----------------------------
    100 = Accel +X max EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmax
    101 = Accel +X min EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmin
    102 = Accel -X max EVENT_ACCELERATION_XNmax
    103 = Accel -X min EVENT_ACCELERATION_XNmin
    104 = Accel Y max EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymax
    105 = Accel y min EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymin
    106 = Accel Z max EVENT_ACCELERATION_Zmax
    107 = Accel Z min EVENT_ACCELERATION_Zmin

    Tachograph
    -------------
    110 = Received valid tachograph data EVENT_DigTachReceivedValidData
    111 = While tachograph ignition active EVENT_DigTachWhileIgnitionActive
    112 = Tachograph status changes EVENT_DigTachStatusChanges
    113 = Tachograph speed above KMPH EVENT_SPEED_DigTachAbove
    114 = Tachograph speed below KMPH (after being above limit) EVENT_SPEED_DigTachBelow

    Accident recording
    -------------
    122 = Accident recording timer 1 EVENT_AccidentRecording1
    123 = Accident recording timer 2 EVENT_AccidentRecording2

    Serial port
    -------------
    78 = Logged serial data EVENT_LoggedSerialData
    130 = Received serial data EVENT_ReceivedSerialData

    ActionID batch
    -----------------
    150 = First action of SETTING_ActionID91
    151 = Second action of SETTING_ActionID91
    152 = Third action of SETTING_ActionID91
    153 = Fourth action of SETTING_ActionID91
    154 = First action of SETTING_ActionID92
    155 = Second action of SETTING_ActionID92
    156 = Third action of SETTING_ActionID92
    157 = Fourth action of SETTING_ActionID92
    158 = First action of SETTING_ActionID93
    159 = Second action of SETTING_ActionID93
    160 = Third action of SETTING_ActionID93
    161 = Fourth action of SETTING_ActionID93
    162 = First action of SETTING_ActionID94
    163 = Second action of SETTING_ActionID94
    164 = Third action of SETTING_ActionID94
    165 = Fourth action of SETTING_ActionID94

    Regions
    -------
    2xx = While inside region xx (xx = 01...50) REGION_EVENT_Inside
    3xx = While outside region xx (xx = 01...50) REGION_EVENT_Outside
    4xx = Entering region xx (xx = 01...50) REGION_EVENT_Entering
    5xx = Leaving region xx (xx = 01...50) REGION_EVENT_Leaving
function CanGetAccu()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetAccu()
Power supply voltage of the module.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Voltage as floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAccu()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The returned voltage is that of the external power supply.
    Unless there is no external power supply connected or below
    the minimum specification, because then for a module running
    internal back-up battery you get the voltage of that battery
    instead.
    But if you have SETTING_OnlyLogInternalPowerSupplyVoltage
    in use in the module, then the returned voltage is in all
    cases of the internal back-up battery.

******
****** Background information on (battery) power supply usage, detection and reaction
******
    In many cases the module will be powered by some kind of power
    accumulating device ranging from a vehicle battery to an internal
    Li-ion power pack.
    All of them are charged of course, which happens with a higher
    voltage than they provide themselves.
    A standard car battery for example is a 12Volt battery and when you
    measure its voltage, you will measure somewhere between 11.5V and
    12.5Volt (even lower when empty and higher when brand new and fully
    charged).
    But when the engine is running, you will measure a voltage of about
    13.5 Volt instead.
    That is because it is being charged when the engine is running.
    Since the voltage is measured by the module (this function returns
    such a measuring result encoded in a record), you could make use of
    the above charging / not charging difference for motion detection.
    You can for example set a voltage range of 13.2 and 16.0 Volt to
    switch into "moving mode" with SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween
    or SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween2 (or in settings
    application section 57).
    For power accumulators working on another voltage, you can expect
    the same but of course with different voltage levels.
    For 24Volt battery systems like in trucks, you could use a range of
    26.5 and 29.9 Volt.
    Be aware that the electrical cigarette lighter sockets in vehicles
    always deliver 12Volt, even on a 24Volt system like in a truck and
    is therefore powered by a converter and never directly connected to
    the vehicle's battery.
    And often the cigarette lighter voltage does not come directly from
    the circuits that are connected to the battery, but from a converter
    instead which may even be disabled when the engine is not running.
    In such a case there is of course no way to do motion detection from
    the cigarette lighter other than measuring for external power being
    available or not.
    But not suitable of course to power the module with, unless you have
    a type which comes with its own backup power pack on which it
    safely continues when its external power supply is discontinued.
    That would of course give you a voltage level of the backup power
    pack which is different than that of your vehicle, so that
    difference can also be used for motion detection.
    (see CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on
    motion detection).
   
    The capacity left in a power accumulator can be estimated from the
    measured voltage it delivers.
    A 12Volt car battery won't exactly deliver 12.0Volt, but a voltage
    range like 12.5Volt when it is charged, down to 11.5 when it is
    empty (exact range depends on its internal chemical compounds and
    of course lifespan condition).
    You can for example set the module to enter a power saving mode
    when a voltage is measured below 11.8 Volt with
    SETTING_PowerSavingVoltage (this setting and the ones mentioned
    below are also available in section 57 of the settings application).
    Even to power down the module with SETTING_PowerDownVoltage
    when the voltage is below a level and power it up again with
    SETTING_PowerUpVoltage when the voltage becomes above a level
    again.
    (Module types with Li-ion hardware require their included Li-ion
    backup pack to be connected and automatically start using this
    backup power pack for uninterrupted functionality. For that backup
    power pack these settings are available too as
    SETTING_PowerSavingVoltageBackup, SETTING_PowerDownVoltageBackup
    and SETTING_PowerUpVoltageBackup, but you are advised to keep
    those set to the default settings to have the firmware control
    their suitable levels).
    But for automatically powering down, be aware that a car battery is
    also used by the start motor to start the engine and that a major
    drop in voltage occurs during that process.
    When the battery gets older and also in winter time its capacity
    decreases and the power drop level gets worse.
    A quick switch of the module into power saving mode and then back
    out of it again caused by that usually won't affect the data you
    make the module log.
    But a power down of the module when you start the engine can of
    course give undesired effects ranging from the built in GPS
    receiver that need time to determine the date/time and its first
    position again to the logic you expect from records that you make
    the module log based on motion detection related events like
    EVENT_StartMoving and EVENT_StopMoving.

    For Rev8 module series that come with a Li-ion backup power pack
    there is a charger circuit and protection circuit built-in for the
    battery to which the battery MUST always be connected for the
    module to function properly, even with external power attached.
    (you have to manually connect the included Li-ion pack to the
    internal connector when you start using the module, because it is
    intentionally not connected and charged to preserve the battery
    from power being drained without having its first real charge).
    When external power is supplied, the attached Li-ion battery is
    also automatically charged at 600mA which effectively adds an
    average of 500mAh capacity per charging hour between empty and 95%
    full (so an empty 1000mAh pack charges from empty to 95% in about 2
    hours).
    Just like external power accumulators, the energy left in the
    backup power Li-ion pack can be estimated from the voltage that it
    delivers too.
    Although it depends on the temperature, here are some rough voltage
    vs capacity left percentage estimates:
    - 3.5Volt: Completely exhausted.
        Do not use power anymore or the battery will be damaged.
        By default the module will power-down at this voltage unless
        you override it with SETTING_PowerDownVoltageBackup.
        In power-down mode, the power consumption of the module is
        very low but a Li-ion battery has its internal drain too (1 to 5
        percent per day of the available capacity), so you will always
        want to charge the battery as soon as possible to preserve its
        normal life span.
    - 3.6Volt: Battery very low, about 2% of its capacity is left.
        At this level, larger currents like during transmissions via the
        internal GSM/GPRS get critical especially on low capacity
        batteries, so if you want to send something like an SMS message
        with a warning text that the backup battery is almost empty,
        you should do it now or else you won't be able anymore.
    - 3.7Volt: About 10% to 15% capacity left.
    - 3.8Volt: About 30% capacity left.
    - 3.9Volt: About 60% capacity left.
    - 4.0Volt: About 80% capacity left.
    - 4.1Volt: About 95% capacity left.
    Now how to send an alert SMS to warn that the battery is almost
    empty at 3.6Volt.
    Well, the easiest way is to measure its voltage with one of the
    input ports.
    To do that, you can for example simulate the Li-ion power pack to
    be connected to Input1 with SETTING_Input1BehaviorSimulationType
    or an equivalent for Input 2, 3 or 5 (or in section 51 of the
    settings application) which is of course simpler than physically
    wiring the battery to the Input port for the same effect.
    Then even logging the voltages of the input (e.g. with ActionID 58
    or by logging the counters while having
    SETTING_AnalogInputLoggingWithCounters enabled) will
    create records with the battery voltage on the input that you
    simulated it on.
    For sending an SMS when the battery is low, you will want of course
    make the module itself monitor and react to the voltage measured on
    that input.
    Because the voltage of a power source (temporarily) drops a little
    bit when suddenly more energy is drawn from it, you will want to
    use a hysteresis voltage additionally to a voltage level
    determination.
    Just suppose you decide to send an SMS message when the voltage is
    3.6V or below and the battery is discharged near that voltage.
    Then its voltage could drop below that level when power is drawn
    for making a transmission with the modem and afterward rises again
    above this voltage level.
    In this case you will of course not want additional triggers
    anymore when this happens and especially not if sending your
    "Battery almost empty" SMS message from this occurrence generates
    yet another voltage drop that could lead to an endless loop of SMS
    messages until the battery is discharged far enough to not raise
    above the level again.
    With a hysteresis set to at least 0.1Volt and a voltage level set
    to 3.6Volt, a drop below 3.6Volt can only trigger a second time if
    the voltage first comes above 3.6Volt+0.1Volt=3.7Volt.
    And then a voltage drop less than 0.1Volt of the battery can't lead
    to undesired effects like in the worst case scenario example with
    lots of SMS messages.
    So set hysteresis voltage to 0.1Volt with
    SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput1 (or equivalent
    for Input 2, 3, 4 or 5).
    And then of course set the Input to a 3.6Volt with
    SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1 (or equivalent for
    Input 2, 3, 4 or 5).
    Now the Input is set to switch to inactive state when it reaches
    the switch level and switches back to active state when it is above
    the level+hysteresis.
    Set EVENT_IO_1A to type IOES_InputActivated with
    CGPSsettings::SetEventIO() and enable action ACTION_SmsAlert1
    to send an SMS to get the Event -> Action result:
    "When Input 1 becomes active -> Send Alert-SMS" (or in section 11
    of the settings application).
    Background info on inputs in general can be found at
    CGPS::CanGetAnalogInputs().
    Generic information on Li-ion:
    http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery
function CanGetTemperature()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
When TRUE is returned, the temperature can be extracted with
CGPS::GetTemperatureCelcius() and CGPS::GetTemperatureFahrenheit().

******
****** Background information on measuring temperature
******
    The available sensor(s) for measuring the temperature depends on
    the used module type.
    The module itself does not need a temperature sensor, unless it
    it is a type with internal Li-ion charger circuitry to which a
    a special battery pack must be connected.
    A temperature sensor is in that case used as part of a full
    protection mechanism which is partially integrated in the module
    and partially in the special battery pack and both specifically
    designed to work closely together.
    For temperature part of the protection the sensor is used to
    monitor the temperature because a chemical Li-ion compound can for
    example only be charged within a range of approximately 0 to 40
    degrees Celsius and power can be drawn from it up to about
    60 degrees Celsius.
    The module plus battery pack combination automatically protect
    battery usage out of temperature ranges that could otherwise lead
    to fire and explosion hazards.

    For module types that have a dedicated temperature sensor on board
    (instead of the battery pack side), the module itself will also
    derive temperature readings from that sensor (for such module
    types the hardware info like via the settings application will tell
    you it contains a temperature sensor).
    The other module types will automatically extract a temperature
    reading from a sensor the internal GSM modem instead at low
    interval.
    The last determined temperature from these methods is the one that
    is used every time you make the module record data in the log that
    contains a temperature reading that is retrievable via
    CGPS::GetTemperatureCelcius() and CGPS::GetTemperatureFahrenheit()
    (and also features like "System Variable" %S06 in your own
    LCD/Source-code programming).
    But you can even replace that temperature by a reading of an
    external 1-Wire bus temperature sensor device via
    SETTING_SubstituteTemperatureWithExternalDS18B20 (or in
    settings application section 54).
    Of course none of the above mentioned methods used for retrieving
    the temperature reading used in the log and system variables will
    disturb the one actually used in the protection mechanism for
    Li-ion battery packs.
   
    The above mentioned 1-Wire temperature sensor device method
    mentioned above requires a module type that support generating a
    1-Wire bus, which can be activated on serial port 4 with the
    MPM_1WireBus driver mode (or in settings application section 59).
    Supported 1-Wire sensors like the DS18B20/DS18S20/DS1822 can be
    connected to the 1-Wire bus that is then provided via the
    connector pins of the module (pre-made cables can be supplied if
    you which).
    With ActionID 17 you make the module read the temperature from
    such a 1-Wire device attached to the 1-Wire bus and write the
    temperature reading in the log as a SV_1WireData1 record, from
    which you can retrieve the temperature with the
    CGPS::Get1WireDS18B20celcius() and
    CGPS::Get1WireDS18B20fahrenheit() functions (and of course also
    the above mentioned replace/substitute method is possible).
    It is recommended to execute ActionID 17 at an interval of at
    least 30 seconds otherwise the temperature sensor may heat up
    by itself from the work you make it do and then of course result
    in an increase in temperature readings.
    Since the 1-Wire bus supports up to 30 of such temperature
    devices simultaneous connected, you will in projects where you
    use more than one need do be able to tell them apart.
    For that, each sensor has a unique serial number which you can
    can retrieve from the same SV_1WireData1 record as mentioned
    above with CGPS::GetIButtonSerialNumberText().
    Also in your own LCD/Source-code the temperatures and serial
    number readings of the last time you executed ActionID 17 are
    available via system variables %SA0...%SF9.
function GetTemperatureCelcius()
Temperature of the built in (or external substitute) sensor in degrees Celsius
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Temperature in degrees Celsius as floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetTemperature()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The resulting temperature reading is from a sensor inside the
    module casing or substitute sensor outside the module casing
    set with SETTING_SubstituteTemperatureWithExternalDS18B20
    (or in settings application section 54).
    See CGPS::CanGetTemperature() for background information on
    measuring temperature.
    See also CGPS::GetTemperatureFahrenheit().
function GetTemperatureFahrenheit()
Temperature of the built in (or external substitute) sensor in degrees Fahrenheit
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Temperature in degrees Fahrenheit as floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetTemperature()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The resulting temperature reading is from a sensor inside the
    module casing or substitute sensor outside the module casing
    set with SETTING_SubstituteTemperatureWithExternalDS18B20
    (or in settings application section 54).
    See CGPS::CanGetTemperature() for background information on
    measuring temperature.
    See also CGPS::GetTemperatureCelcius().
function CanGetReset()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetReset()
Number of seconds since the module was powered-up (or reset)
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Number of seconds since the module was powered-up (or reset)
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetReset()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The resolution of the returned value is rather small, so it is only
    increased when the next step is reached and not every second.
    Therefore this value should only be used as an indication and not
    for precise calculations.
    For precise counters, see CGPS::GetCounterSecondsActive()
    and CGPS::GetCounterSecondsMoving().
function CanGetIndex()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetIndex()
Module log index number of the data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Index number value of 0 up-to 255.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetIndex()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    The majority of SV_... record types are always written to the log
    when you have the module create them and from there are transmitted
    to your server (or exported from the log otherwise).
    They all have an Index number that is related to the order that
    they were created in the log.
    This Index number starts at 0 and is incremented with each record
    in the log up-to 255 and then restarts at 0 again.
    Many record types actually have this Index value internally encoded
    together with the other information they contain.
    Some do not because their internal data space is already fully used
    up by the other information info they contain.
    But if you look at the Index value of a series of records from the
    module in the order that they were created, transmitted and
    received, then you should notice that their Index value counts
    round from 0 up-top 255 and then starts at 0 again.
    And you will for example notice if records are missing, which is
    the purpose of the Index value.

    There are a few record types that are asynchronously transmitted
    to the server therefore do not influence the Index counter because
    they are never stored in the log.
    Asynchronously transmitted records are: SV_Network, SV_Photo,
    SV_PhotoGps, SV_Acknowledge, SV_SettingsAccepted and
    SV_SettingsRejected.
function CanGetShake()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetShake()
Minimum number of seconds left for the module to return to the "Not Moving" mode.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - The value of the internal Shake timer at the time that
        the record was created in the log.
        A zero value means the "Not moving mode" is active.
        A non zero value means "Moving mode" active and is
        the minimum number of seconds it will take at least
        before the "Not moving mode" can become active.
Notes:
    - Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetShake()
        function returns a boolean TRUE.
    - The maximum result value depends on the timeout you used in the
        module SETTING_MotionDetectionSecondsTimeout.
        But even if you have have set it to a timeout higer than 255,
        this function will at maximum return 255.
        Since Rev9:415 you can use this function for SV_TimeAlive...
        and SV_KeepAlive... variant records too, but for those the
        the maximum result value will then be 1.

******
****** Background information on motion detection
******
    Shake is the name of an internal timer of the module for motion
    detection purposes.
    If the Shake timer is zero, then "Not Moving Mode" is active.
    If the Shake timer is not zero, then the "Moving mode" is active
    and will be for at least the number of seconds left in the timer.
    The Shake timer is decremented every second towards zero and can
    trigger one of the following events (which can also be found in
    section also available in section 14 of the settings application):
    - EVENT_StopMoving, once when the timer reaches 0.
    - EVENT_WhileNotMoving, every second while the timer was already 0.
    - EVENT_StartMoving, once when the timer is "reset" to the full
        timeout value while it had already reached 0.
        (even if you do not set actions for this event, every
        occurrence automatically resets internal trip counters and
        comparing data for trip info that is used with
        SV_PositionTripMeters, CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters()
        and SV_CountersHighestSpeed).
    - EVENT_WhileMoving, every second as long as the counter is not 0.

    You can use (a combination of) the following motion detection
    methods to every time that they occur "reset" the Shake timer back
    to the SETTING_MotionDetectionSecondsTimeout value that
    you have set in the module's settings to keep the Shake timer
    from reaching 0 (or in section 57 of the settings application):
    - ActionID 48, every time you execute this action from an event
        generate a motion trigger.
    - SETTING_MovingInputDetection, every second as long as the
        specified input is active.
    - SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween, every second as long as
        the power supply voltage is inside a defined range.
    - SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween2, every second as long as
        the power supply voltage is inside a defined range.
    - SETTING_MovingVoltageChange, (Rev5 only) every second
        after the power supply voltage raised by at least this level
        (stops when drops again by at least this level).
        (see CGPS::GetAccu() for more information on power supply
        voltage measuring and settings).
    - SETTING_MovingOnVibrationSensorDetect, every time when
        the (optional) internal vibration sensor detects motion.
    - SETTING_MovingOnSensorDetect, every time when the
        (optional) internal sensor detects motion.
        For Rev5 this is the optional shake detection sensor.
        For Rev8/9 this is the optional accel/Gforce-sensor.
    - SETTING_MovingOnGpsDelta, every time when the GPS
        receiver determines a speed high enough to trigger this.

    The motion detection settings above are somewhat sorted in order
    of reliability, of which detection via GPS is the least reliable.
    If the GPS receiver is switched off (automatically switched off
    when power saving mode is active) or there is no sufficient signal
    from enough GPS satellites available, then motion is never detected.
    Parking in a location where there is little or no GPS signal
    available for some time (e.g. a garage) a GPS-fix is not possible
    anymore, which will eventually be established again when you leave,
    but because of you are then moving with changing scenery and
    direction changes from the road making signals from various
    satellites appear and disappear, this can take quite a long time
    which of course cause a motion detection late in your actual trip,
    or even not at all for short trips.

    When GPS info is available, even a stationary object will
    appear to be constantly moving, caused by constant changes in the
    atmosphere, reflections from the surrounding and other disturbances
    which could generate false motion triggers.
    For that reason:
    - The SETTING_MovingOnGpsDelta when enabled for motion detection
        will deliver triggers at speeds above 10 kilometers per hour.
        (this minimum speed level can be changed with
        SETTING_MinimumGpsSpeedForMotionDetection).
    - The internal travelled distance counters
        (CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters()/CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters())
        and events EVENT_DISTANCE_1 / EVENT_HEADING_Degrees are
        only incremented/triggered while in "Moving mode" at speeds
        above 5 kilometers per hour of which the minimum speed level
        can be changed with SETTING_MinimumGpsSpeedForTravelling).
    - The GPS determined speed used in position logs (e.g. CGPS::GetSpeed...())
        usually is not 0.0 even for a stationary object, but if you which, you
        can have the speed while in "Not moving mode" patched to 0.0 with
        SETTING_ForceSpeedToZeroWhenNotMoving (or in
        section 54 of the settings application).
function CanGetVersion()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetVersion()
Firmware version of the module
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Firmware version of the module at the time it generated the record
        that you are examining.
Notes:
    - Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetVersion()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    - Records in the log of Rev8/9 modules generated while still running
    a firmware version older than 256/512 but transferred from there
    with a newer version will give incorrect version results (even with
    CGPS classes files and settings applications that actually do
    support the firmware versions from before and after the upgrade).
function CanGetRev()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetRev()
Revision series number of the module for firmware requirement identification
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    Integer value:
    - 0: Unknown
    - 5: Requires Rev5 series firmware
    - 8: Requires Rev8 series firmware
    - 9: Requires Rev9 series firmware
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetRev()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
function CanGetSettingsError()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetSettingsError()
Error code of the uploaded settings data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Error code (8 bit value)
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetSettingsError()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    With a SV_SettingsRejected response from the module after
    uploading new settings from your server, this error code explains
    why the received settings data was rejected.
    Error codes:
    0: No error
        This is normal for SV_SettingsAccepted records.
    2: Invalid size
        The number of settings data bytes that were received was
        incorrect.
        If you are sure the settings data that you uploaded is correct,
        then you will want to re-upload the settings until you get a
        SV_SettingsAccepted result.
    3: RS232 only
        The uploaded settings are considered too dangerous to be
        remotely uploaded (e.g. switching the GSM modem off).
        If you are sure you want to make use of these settings, then
        upload them into the module via a cable connection to your
        computer.
    33...255: CRC error
        The "Cyclic Redundancy Check" of the received data does not
        match, so the data did not arrive/process correctly (for
        example caused by signal/network loss during transmission).
        You will want to re-upload the same settings data again until
        you get a SV_SettingsAccepted result.
function CanGetSettingsCrc()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetSettingsCrc()
"Cyclic Redundancy Check" value of the settings data used by the module.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - 16 bit CRC value of the settings data that is in use.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetSettingsCrc()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This CRC value can for example be used to compare with the CRC
    value from the settings application or your server application
    with CGPSsettings::GetSettingsCRC()
    When different, then you know that the module is not using that
    same settings data.
function CanGetIO()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetIO()
Digital input/output lines active/inactive status.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Byte value that contains the I/O status as bits.
        *** "Module Digital Input/Output" bitmask definitions ***

  • MDIO_Output1// Bitmask for the module's digital output 1
  • MDIO_Output2// Bitmask for the module's digital output 2
  • MDIO_Output3// Bitmask for the module's digital output 3
  • MDIO_Output4// Bitmask for the module's digital output 4
  • MDIO_Input1// Bitmask for the module's digital input 1
  • MDIO_Input2// Bitmask for the module's digital input 2
  • MDIO_Input3// Bitmask for the module's digital input 3
  • MDIO_Input4// Bitmask for the module's digital input 4

Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetIO()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The return value of this function can be stored in a MySQL SMALLINT
    UNSIGNED field (=1 byte unsigned).
    For background information on digital (and analog) inputs see
    CGPS::CanGetAnalogInputs().
    For additional inputs see CGPS::GetAdditionalIO().
Usage example:


    <?php
    if($pcGPS->CanGetIO()) //Is the I/O status availabe in the current record?
    {
        $i1=$i2=$i3=$i4=$o1=$o2=$o3=$o4='Inactive'; //Initialize all variables with "Inactive' text.
        $IO=$pcGPS->GetIO(); //Retrieve the I/O status from this record
        if($IO & MDIO_Input1) $i1='Active'; //If the status for this input is active, then change the "Inactive" text to "Active".
        if($IO & MDIO_Input2) $i2='Active';
        if($IO & MDIO_Input3) $i3='Active';
        if($IO & MDIO_Input4) $i4='Active';
        if($IO & MDIO_Output1) $o1='Active'; //If the status for this output is active, then change the "Inactive" text to "Active".
        if($IO & MDIO_Output1) $o2='Active';
        if($IO & MDIO_Output1) $o3='Active';
        if($IO & MDIO_Output1) $o4='Active';
    } else $i1=$i2=$i3=$i4=$o1=$o2=$o3=$o4='Unknown'; // The I/O status is not available in the current record, so set all text to "Unknown".
    print("Digital status of the inputs: 1=$i1 / 2=$i2 / 3=$i3 / 4=$i4<BR>");
    print("Digital status of the outputs: 1=$o1 / 2=$o2 / 3=$o3 / 4=$o4<BR>");
    ?>


function CanGetAdditionalIO()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetAdditionalIO()
Digital inputs via serial port lines active/inactive status.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Byte value containing status bits of the additional digital inputs.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAdditionalIO()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    Description of the status bits:
    - Bit 1: Rev5:468 / Rev8/9:all
        - Full I/O connector pin 10 (RXD4_3V).
            3 Volt input for serial port 4 which has an internal pull-up
            (also used for camera and 1-Wire).
            When not connected, this status bit is set.
            When pulled down to ground, this status bit is cleared.
        - Micro I/O connector pin 2 (Serial IN).
            Input for serial port which has an internal pull-down.
            When not connected, this status bit is cleared.
            When 2..31 Volt is applied this status bit is set.
    - Bit 2: Rev5:468 / Rev8:161 / Rev9:all
        - Full I/O connector pin 20 (RXD2_RS232).
            RS232 input of serial port 2 which has an internal pull-down.
            Status of this bit is internally inverted.
            When not connected, this status bit is set.
            When pulled up to at least 3.3Volt, this status bit is cleared.
    - Bit 3: Rev5:468 / Rev8:none / Rev9:none
        - Full I/O connector pin 19 (RXD3_RS232).
            RS232 input of serial port 3 which has an internal pull-down.
            Status of this bit is internally inverted.
            When not connected, this status bit is set.
            When pulled up to at least 3.3Volt, this status bit is cleared.
            NOTE: Since Rev8:162, when this bit is set, it signals that
                the automatic accel/Gforce-sensor calibration is finished
                and in use. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() background info.
    - Bit 4: Rev5:none / Rev8:161 / Rev9:all
        - Full I/O connector pin 6 (RXD1_3V).
            3 Volt input of serial port 1 (and hardware pulse counter),
            which has an internal pull-up.
            When not connected, this status bit is set.
            When pulled down to ground, this status bit is cleared.
    - Bit 6: [Rev5:none / Rev8:172 / Rev9:all].
        - Full+Basic I/O connector pin 4 (In5).
            Input 5 for which the status of this bit depends on the
            measured input voltage compared with your settings
            SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput5 and
            SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput5 conditions (or
            in settings application section 51).
            If the input is not connected or an input voltage below the conditions in
            the settings is supplied, then this status bit is cleared.
            When the input measures a voltage above the conditions in the settings,
            then this status bit is set.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $p10=$p20=$p19=$p6=$i5='Not available';
    if($pcGPS->CanGetAdditionalIO()) //Is additional I/O status available in the current record?
    {
        $IO=$pcGPS->GetAdditionalIO(); //Get the additional I/O status from the current record
        $Rev=$pcGPS->GetRev(); //Get the hardware revision series of the module from the record
        $Ver=$pcGPS->GetVersion(); //Get the firmware version of the module from the record
        // Change the variables from "Not available" to "Active" or "Inactive" where appropriate
        if(    ( ($Rev==5) && ($Ver>=468) ) //Rev5 with at least firmware 468 ?
            || ($Rev==8) //OR Rev8 with any firmware version ?
            || ($Rev==9) //OR Rev9 with any firmware version ?
          ) $p10=($IO & 2) ? 'Inactive' : 'Active';
        if(    ( ($Rev==5) && ($Ver>=468) ) //Rev5 with at least firmware 468 ?
            || ( ($Rev==8) && ($Ver>=161) )  //OR Rev8 with at least firmware 161 ?
            || ($Rev==9)  //OR Rev9 with any firmware version ?
          ) $p20=($IO & 4) ? 'Inactive' : 'Active';
        if(    ($Rev==5) && ($Ver>=468) //Rev5 with at least firmware 468 ?
          ) $p19=($IO & 8) ? 'Inactive' : 'Active';
        if(    ($Rev==8) && ($Ver>=161) //Rev8 with at least firmware 161 ?
            || ($Rev==9) //OR Rev9 with any firmware version ?
          ) $p6=($IO & 16) ? 'Inactive' : 'Active';
        if(    ( ($Rev==8) && ($Ver>=172) ) //Rev8 with at least firmware 172 ?
            || ($Rev==9) //OR Rev9 with any firmware version ?
          ) $i5=($IO & 64) ? 'Active' : 'Inactive';
    }
    print("Digital status of the additional inputs: Pin10=$p10 Pin20=$p20 Pin19=$p19 Pin6=$p6 Input5=$i5");
    ?>


function CanGetMiscStatus()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetMiscStatus()
Miscellaneous status of the module.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - 8 bit value containing various status bits.
Notes:
    Description of the status bits:
    - Bit 7: Module power mode
        0=power-saving (since Rev8:158 real status).
        1=Full power (for Rev5 and before Rev8:158 this bit is always set to 1 even in power-saving mode).
    - Bit 6: MiscStatus bits valid
        0: No, status of the other bits are al invalid (unusual situation, like forwarding transmitted records).
        1: Yes, status of the other bits are valid.
    - Bit 5: Camera successfully used to take a picture since module (re)start.
        0=No (might still be one connected, but not (successfully) used since (re)start-up).
        1=Yes (a successful picture has been taken before, so camera and cable are functioning correctly).
    - Bit 3: Virtual Output 1 status.
        0: Inactive
        1: Active
    - Bit 2: Virtual output 2 status.
        0: Inactive
        1: Active
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Miscellaneous status: ');
    if($pcGPS->CanGetMiscStatus())
    {
        $MiscStatus=$pcGPS->GetMiscStatus();
        print("$MiscStatus meaning:");
        if($MiscStatus&64)
        {
            print('<BR>- Virtual output 1=');
                if($MiscStatus&8) print('Active'); else print('Inactive');
            print('<BR>- Virtual output 2=');
                if($MiscStatus&4) print('Active'); else print('Inactive');
            if($MiscStatus&32) print('<BR>- Camera present and successfully used');
            if(!($MiscStatus&128)) print('<BR>- Module in power saving mode');
        } else print(' Invalid');
    } else print('Unknown');
    ?>


function CanGetHardwareStatus()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetHardwareStatus()
Hardware status of the module.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - 16 bit value containing various hardware status bits.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetHardwareStatus()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    if(GetHardwareStatus() & 0x3000) Using valid user settings
    if(GetHardwareStatus() & 0xc000) AD-converter calibration and PCB-type in EEPROM
    if(GetHardwareStatus() & 0x0002) Restart caused by power supply low/power-up
    if(GetHardwareStatus() & 0x0004) Watchdog reset (usually deliberate)
function CanGetRestartCause()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetRestartCause()
Cause for the automatic module restart.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value that contains the cause.
    Current firmware versions do not generate this anymore.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetRestartCause()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    But current firmware versions do not generate this info anymore,
    they add detailed info in the next SV_PowerUp record instead.
function CanGetCounters()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
Notes:
    When this function returns a boolean TRUE, the following counter
    readings are available in the currently selected record:
    - CGPS::GetCounterSecondsActive()
    - CGPS::GetCounterSecondsMoving()
    - CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters() (see also CGPS::CanGetCounterTravelledMeters())
    - CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters() (see also CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters())
    - CGPS::GetCounterPulsesInput1()
    - CGPS::GetCounterInput3Active()
    You can log a copy of the current readings of these counters as a
    SV_Counters record for any EVENT_... you which by enabling the action
    ACTION_CountersLog for it (or "log counters" in the settings application).
    Additionally records logged at the same time can be:
    - SV_CountersHighestSpeed; unless disabled with
        SETTING_DoNotLogHighestSpeedWithCounters.
    - SV_CountersAnalogInputs; when enabled with
        SETTING_AnalogInputLoggingWithCounters.
    But some counters can even be logged together with every position
    depending on the SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType or by executing an
    ActionID (e.g. 55..58).


******
****** Background information on counters and their non volatile memory backup
******
    The module keeps track of various automatic counters like:
    - Total ODO distance: CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters()
    - Total trip distance: CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters()
    - Total voltage pulses: CGPS::GetCounterPulsesInput1()
    - Total input voltage time: CGPS::GetCounterInput3Active()
    - Total time in moving mode: CGPS::GetCounterSecondsMoving()
    - Total time module powered up: CGPS::GetCounterSecondsActive()
    You can log a copy of the current readings of these counters as a
    SV_Counters record for any EVENT_... you which by enabling the action
    ACTION_CountersLog for it (or "log counters" in the settings application).
    Additionally records logged at the same time can be:
    - SV_CountersHighestSpeed; unless disabled with
        SETTING_DoNotLogHighestSpeedWithCounters.
    - SV_CountersAnalogInputs; when enabled with
        SETTING_AnalogInputLoggingWithCounters.
    Some of these counters can even be logged together with every position
    depending on the SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType or by executing an
    ActionID (e.g. 55..58).

    There are also user counters which you record in the log with
    ActionID 76 and read at your server with CGPS::GetUserCounter().
    From your own LCD/Source-code running in the module you modify the
    contents of the user counters with module commands like INCR and USET.

    Since the above mentioned counters run in volatile RAM, their
    contents be lost when the power supply to the module is discontinued.
    Therefore a copy of the counter readings is made automatically into
    non volatile EEPROM memory:
    - Every hour.
    - When changing state from "Moving mode" to "Not moving mode"
        (requires proper motion detection settings see CGPS::GetShake()).
    - When the module restarts on command or self determined reason.
    - When the module automatically powers down because the (optional)
        internal backup battery gets empty because no external power
        supply is connected.
    - When the module is commanded to go into power-down mode with
        ActionID 72.
    When the module is powered-up, it reads the copy of the last
    recorded counter readings back into volatile RAM as initial counter
    readings.
function GetCounterSecondsActive()
Total number of seconds that the module has been active.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Total number of seconds that the module has been active.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetCounters()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This counter restarts at 0 after it has reached the maximum reading
    of 4294967295 seconds.
    See CGPS::CanGetCounters() for additional information on the
    non volatile storage of the counters in general.

    You make let the module write the current reading of this counter
    (including the other counters) to the log in a SV_Counters
    record from any EVENT_... that you which by enabling the
    "Log counters" action for it (ACTION_CountersLog).
    From these records, you can read the counter readings and subtract
    them from each other to determine the difference between the
    two events.
function GetCounterSecondsMoving()
Total number of seconds that the module has been in the 'Moving Mode'.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Total number of seconds that the module has been in the 'Moving Mode'.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetCounters()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This counter restarts at 0 after it has reached the maximum reading
    of 4294967295 seconds.
    See CGPS::CanGetCounters() for additional information on the
    non volatile storage of the counters in general.
    See CGPS::GetShake() for additional information on "moving" and
    "not moving modes".

    You make let the module write the current reading of this counter
    (including the other counters) to the log in a SV_Counters
    record from any EVENT_... that you which by enabling the
    "Log counters" action for it (ACTION_CountersLog).
    From these records, you can read the counter readings and subtract
    them from each other to determine the difference between the
    two events.
function CanGetCounterTravelledMeters()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetCounterTravelledMeters()
Total number of GPS determined meters that the module has travelled.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Travelled meters as a floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetCounterTravelledMeters()
    (or CGPS::CanGetCounters()) function returns a Boolean TRUE.

    This counter is automatically increased while the "moving mode" is
    and the GPS determined speed is above 5Kmh.
    This counter restarts at 0.0 after it has reached the maximum
    reading of 429496729 meters.
    See CGPS::CanGetCounters() for additional information on the
    non volatile storage of the counters in general.
    See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information
    on motion detection.

    You make let the module write the current reading of this counter
    (including the other counters) to the log in a SV_Counters
    record from any EVENT_... that you which by enabling the
    "Log counters" action for it (ACTION_CountersLog).
    From these records, you can read the counter readings and subtract
    them from each other to determine the difference between the
    two events.
    Just like you can write down the travelled distance before and
    after a trip and subtract the two to know the total distance of
    that trip, you can do the following:
    Set the module to do a "Log counters" action (ACTION_CountersLog)
    at the beginning and end of every trip (EVENT_StartMoving and
    EVENT_StopMoving).
    From the two SV_Counters records generated by those two events,
    you read the travelled meters counter and subtract them from each
    other which gives you  the distance travelled during the trip.
    If it is only the distance for trips that you are after, then
    you can of course also simply use CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters()
    which automatically restarts at 0 at the beginning of every trip.
    But with the travelled meters counter you can of course do
    additional things like determining if it is time again to take the
    vehicle to the garage for a service checkup, when the travelled
    distance counter increased enough since the last service check.

    If you want to, you can have the current travelled meters counter
    reading included with every GPS position that you record in the log
    by selecting SV_PositionTravelledMeters as your preferred record
    Switch Value in the module with SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType
    (or in section 54 of the settings application).
    And independent from that setting, you can also use ActionID 56
    to record a single SV_PositionTravelledMeters record.
function CanGetCounterTripMeters()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetCounterTripMeters()
GPS determined meters travelled since the last "Start Moving" event.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Travelled meters as a floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetCounterTripMeters()
    (or CGPS::CanGetCounters()) function returns a Boolean TRUE.

    This counter is automatically increased while the "moving mode" is
    and the GPS determined speed is above 5Kmh.
    This counter automatically restarts at 0.0 when the module switches
    into "moving mode".
    The counter also restarts at 0.0 after the maximum reading of
    429496729 meters for a trip.
    You can also restart the counter at 0.0 yourself during a trip can
    with ActionID 60.
    See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information
    on motion detection.
   
    You can for example set the module to perform a "Log counters"
    action (ACTION_CountersLog) at the end of every trip when you
    stop moving (EVENT_StopMoving).
    From the logged SV_Counters record you can read the trip meters to
    get the distance travelled during that trip.
    If you want to, you can have the current trip meters counter
    reading included with every GPS position that you record in the log
    by selecting SV_PositionTripMeters as your preferred record
    Switch Value in the module with SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType (or
    in section 54 of the settings application).
    And independent from that setting, you can also use ActionID 55
    to record a single SV_PositionTripMeters record.

    If you need more than just the travelled distance of every trip,
    then you could use the travelled distance counter
    CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters() which does not restart at
    each trip and can therefore also be used for distance spans over
    multiple trips or keeping track of a total travelled distance
    until the next vehicle servicing is required.
function GetCounterPulsesInput1()
Total number of pulses counted by the internal hardware pulse counter
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Pulses value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetCounters()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This counter restarts at 0 after it has reached the maximum reading
    of 429496729 pulses.
    See CGPS::CanGetCounters() for additional information on the
    non volatile storage of the counters in general.


******
****** Background information on the internal hardware pulse counter
******
    The internal pulse counter hardware increments the counter when
    it receives a pulse via:

    * Since the Rev8 hardware series of the module with "full I/O",
      running firmware version 117 and on newer hardware series of the
      module where the hardware pulse counter is combined with serial
      input 1.
        Connector pin 6 (also used for serial port 1 RXD) at every
        change from a voltage between 0.0Volt(=absolute minimum)
        and +1.0Volt to a voltage range between 1.7Volt and
        3.0Volt(=absolute maximum) will trigger the hardware pulse
        counter and increment the total count.
        Reactions to voltages between the two ranges are undefined.
        Pulse frequencies up to about 100Khz can be counted, depending
        on the waveform of the pulses.
        The pulse counter hardware in the module can be disabled with
        SETTING_DisablePulseCounterHardware (also section 56 of the
        settings application) if you do not use it and want to save
        a little power consumption like when running on small batteries.
        In case the voltage range of the pulse you want to count is not
        within the above mentioned range, you could adapt it for example
        with a simple and cheap SB140A schottky diode like this:
        Module pin 6 -------a--|>][--c------- Pulse voltage (range high: +2.5V..+40.0V / Low: 0.0V..+0.4V)
        Module pin 3/9/14 ------------------- Pulse ground (connect it to any I/O_ground pin of the module)
        (make very sure you do not exchange the anode/cathode of the
        diode, the side marked with the painted band connects to the
        pulse voltage and NOT to the connector pin of the module).

    * Modules with "Basic I/O" where the hardware pulse counter is combined
      with input 1.
        Connector pin B (also analog/digital input and digital output 1)
        at every change from a voltage range between 0.0Volt
        (=absolute minimum) and 1.0Volt to a voltage range between 1.7Volt
        and 31.0Volt (=absolute maximum) will trigger the hardware pulse
        counter and increment the total count.
        NOTE:
        The hardware pulse counter adds a pull-up to the input resulting
        in an input voltage over 2Volt when not connected.
        So make sure the pulse you connect does pull down that voltage
        low enough for the pulses to be measured.
        The pulse counter hardware in the module can be disabled with
        SETTING_DisablePulseCounterHardware (also section 56 of the
        settings application) if you do not use it and want to save
        a little power consumption like when running on small batteries.
        When disabled, also the above mentioned pull-up is disabled which
        is also useful when using the input only as input because
        otherwise the pull-up may keep input digitally active always
        unless you set the a switch level (requires hysteresis) of like
        at least 4 Volt with SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1
        (or in section 51 of the settings application).

    * With module hardware revisions older than the Rev8 series running
      at least firmware version 468 where the hardware pulse counter is
      combined with digital input 1.
        Connector pin 24 (also used for digital input 1) at every change
        from a voltage between 0.0Volt(=absolute minimum) and +0.5Volt to
        a voltage range between +3.5Volt and +31.0Volt(=absolute maximum)
        will trigger the the hardware pulse counter and increment the
        total count.
        Reactions to voltages between the two ranges are undefined.
        Pulse frequencies of about 5Khz can be counted, depending on the
        waveform of the pulses.

    You can make the module write the current reading of the pulse
    counter (including the other counters) to the log in a
    SV_Counters record from any EVENT_... that you which by
    enabling the "Log counters" action for it (ACTION_CountersLog).
    From these records, you can read the counter readings and subtract
    them from each other to determine the difference between the
    two events.
    You could for example determine how often a button/switch has
    been activated between the two events, or count the pulses that
    some vehicles/vessels/pumps/machinery/devices generate.

    There are also two "System Variables" which you can use from your
    own LCD/source-code to log/SMS/display a value derived from the
    hardware pulse counter:
    - %S63: Total number of pulses counted.
    - %S96: Current pulse frequency in Hertz (pulses in the last second).

    Since Rev8:190 it is also possible to use RXD1_3V pin 10 which will
    result in "User Counter" number 19 incremented at every high flank
    of the applied pulse signal up to about 50Hz.
    The min/max voltage range of pin 10 is identical to that described
    for pin 6 above, so you could use the same SB140A schottky diode
    method if needed.
    See CGPS::GetUserCounter() for reading the "User Counters" on
    the server side.       
    In your LCD/Source-code you can use %SJ2 for the live contents of
    user counter 19.
function GetCounterInput3Active()
Total number of 100 milliseconds units that the module detected an active signal on digital input 3
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of the total number of 100 milliseconds units.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetCounters()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This counter restarts at 0 after it has reached the maximum reading
    of 4294967295 units of 100ms.
    See CGPS::CanGetCounters() for additional information on the
    non volatile storage of the counters in general.

    You can make the module write the current reading of this counter
    (including the other counters) to the log in a SV_Counters
    record from any EVENT_... that you which by enabling the
    "Log counters" action for it (ACTION_CountersLog).
    From these records, you can read the counter readings and subtract
    them from each other to determine the difference between the
    two events.
function CanGetAnalogInputs()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
Notes:
    When this function returns a Boolean TRUE, the
    CGPS::GetAnalogInput...() functions for inputs
    1, 2, 3 and 4 return a floating point value representing the
    voltage measured on the analog input port at the time that the
    record was logged.

******
****** Background information for analog / digital inputs
******
    The Rev5 module series by default have digital inputs (0 up to 31
    Volt where digital state <2.5V=inactive and >3.5V=active), but can
    be changed into analog inputs (supporting 0 up to 2.5Volt) by a
    manual hardware modification for inputs 1&2 and/or 3&4 and then
    also the firmware notified of the change in the settings with
    SETTING_AnalogInput1and2NOTdigital and
    SETTING_AnalogInput3and4NOTdigital (or in section 51
    of the settings application).
    Analog inputs of Rev5 modules must be connected to a live voltage
    within proper input voltage range, because when not connected at
    all, they will deliver undefined readings.
    For Rev5 modules, the GND of the external inputs must be connected
    to connector pin 14 and their voltages can be connected to pins
    24/25/27/28 for inputs 1 to 4.

    The Rev8 module series have inputs that allow a voltage range of 0
    up to 31Volt.
    Each input can be used as both digital inputs and analog inputs at
    the same time.
    Inputs 1 to 4 can be used to measure a voltage range of 0Volt up to
    around 26Volt.
    Input 5 can be used to measure a voltage range of 0Volt up to
    around 30Volt (so a small percentage higher than inputs 1 to 4,
    with the same percentage less accurate).
    The digital active/inactive state of an input is determined by the
    firmware from the voltage that is measured on the input port.
    A low voltage (or not connected) is evaluated in digitally inactive
    state and a high voltage level is evaluated in a digitally active
    state.
    You can set the level yourself with
    SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1/2/3/4/5 above/below an
    input voltage is to be evaluated into a digitally active/inactive
    state and you can even set you preferred hysteresis level with
    SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput1/2/3/4/5 (also
    possible in section 51 of the settings application).
    Having both settings disabled (set to 0.0Volt) for an input makes
    the firmware use defaults (<3Volt=inactive / >3Volt=active and no
    hysteresis) that give about the same digital input (in)active state
    results as Rev5 modules do fixed in hardware.
    The hysteresis level is useful to overcome a possible problem of
    constant digitally active/inactive toggling when an input voltage
    is around the digital voltage level of a port and natural
    disturbance/noise on the voltage makes the voltage fluctuate just
    below/above the level all the time.
    Setting a hysteresis for example of 1.0Volt, requires an input
    voltage that changed below the digital switch level voltage
    (resulting in a switch from digitally active to inactive state) to
    raise *at least* that 1.0Volt above the digital switch level to
    switch the digital state back from inactive to active again.
    And with Rev8 modules, you can even simulate an input port to be
    connected to something, like to the internal Li-ion battery (for a
    module that has such hardware circuits built in) using
    SETTING_Input1BehaviorSimulationType or equivalent for
    another input port (see CGPS::GetAccu() documentation for an
    example of level+hysteresis+simulation combination for measuring
    the internal Li-ion battery voltage and send an SMS text message
    below a certain voltage).
    For Rev8 modules, the GND of the inputs is to be connected to
    connector Pin 9 (Input 1/2/3/4) and Pin 3 (Input 5).
    But since those connector pins 9, 3 and 14 (serial ports) grounds
    are internally connected to each other, it does not matter which
    one you use.
    Those three pins are also internally connected to pin 1 (GND of VCC
    power supply), but via a noise filtering coil, so you will want to
    connect the I/O grounds anyway, especially when relaying analog
    voltage level readings.

    For both Rev5 and Rev8, you can create events in the module to
    trigger on the digitally active/inactive/change/... states of the
    inputs (and outputs) with CGPSsettings::SetEventIO() (or in
    section 11 of the settings application).
    Of course you make the module to perform an action when such events
    occur, like logging the current position because records containing
    a GPS position also contain the digital states of the inputs (and
    outputs) from which you can retrieve their states with
    CGPS::GetIO().

    Both Rev5 and Rev8 can filter fast voltage changes from the voltage
    measured on the inputs enabling you to filter out peaks/spikes/noise
    that could otherwise for example cause false digital level triggers
    or give a snapshot voltage that does not represent the average.
    For Rev5, this filter can be disabled for all inputs with
    SETTING_AnalogInput_LowPassFilter_Disabled.
    For Rev8, the filter level for each individual input can be set
    separately at a level you which.

    Having SETTING_AnalogInputLoggingWithCounters enabled (or
    in section 51 of the settings application), you can make the module
    measure and log the voltages on the inputs into a
    SV_CountersAnalogInputs record every time you do a "Log
    counters" action (ACTION_CountersLog and even
    CGPS::mCountersLog initiated from the server or "module
    command" SACT initiated via SMS or LCD/source-code).
    In SV_CountersAnalogInputs records, the voltage measurements
    are recorded in 16bit and can be retrieved with the
    CGPS::GetAnalogInput...() functions.
    You can also set SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType to type
    GLST_PositionAnalogInputs to have analog readings (instead
    of Temperature/Altitude/Reset) included with each position logged
    as SV_PositionAnalogInputs records (or in section 54 of the
    settings application).
    With Rev8, you can independently log SV_PositionAnalogInputs
    records too with ActionID 58.
    In SV_PositionAnalogInputs records (and sub variants depending
    on GPS status), the voltage readings are recorded in 8bit and can
    be retrieved with the CGPS::GetAnalogInput...() functions.
function GetAnalogInput1()
Analog input #1 voltage level.
Function input:
    - None.
Function result:
    - Floating point value of the analog input voltage level.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAnalogInputs()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    Background info on inputs in general also described at
    CGPS::CanGetAnalogInputs().

    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    CGPS::CanGetAnalogInputs().

    CGPS::CanGetAnalogInputs().

Notes:

    CGPS::GetAnalogInput5() function returns a floating
    point value representing the voltage measured on the analog input
    port.

    - Floating point value of the analog input voltage level.

    function returns a boolean TRUE.
