    CGPS::CanGetAnalogInputs().
function CanGetExtraDataSize()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetExtraDataSize()
Size of extra transmitted data in bytes.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of size in bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetExtraDataSize()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    With transmissions like SV_Photo and SV_PhotoGps there is extra
    data included in the asynchronous transmission (not via the
    module's internal log) to the server.
    The result of this function is the size in bytes of the extra data
    which can be used to check if the real amount of extra bytes that
    is received is complete.
    When you are using a HTTP compatible transmission string in the
    module server transmission settings, the data bytes of the jpeg
    picture are included the same way as if the picture was uploaded
    to your server via a piece of HTTP FORM code like:
    <form method="post" name="submit" enctype="application/octet-stream">
        <input type="file"><input type="submit" name="submit" value="submit">
    </form>
    In PHP for example, you can retrieve such uploaded data in a
    variable like $ExtraData=file_get_contents('php://input');
    In VBscript like ExtraData=System.Web.HttpContext.Current.Request.BinaryRead(Request.TotalBytes)
function CanGetPhotoPort()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetPhotoPort()
The port number used to take the picture (for identification which camera was used in a multiple camera setup).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Port number value.
        (Values 1/2/3/4 mean camera connected to serial port 1/2/3/4).
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetPhotoPort()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    See description of CGPS::GetPhotoLogDataBytes() for general
    background information of taking pictures.
function CanGetPhotoLogDataSize()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetPhotoLogDataSize()
Size in bytes of a logged picture that spread over several other records.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of size in bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetPhotoLogDataSize()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
   
    This function extracts the total size in bytes value of the picture
    data from a SV_PhotoLog or SV_PhotoGpsLog record (which
    one is created for your picture depends on
    SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto).
    To reconstruct the full JPEG picture, append all data bytes from the
    individual SV_PhotoLogData records that follows until you reach that
    total data size.
    The last SV_PhotoLogData record can contain some additional bytes
    which are to be ignored.
    They are all logged and transmitted in correct order, but
    additionally they specifically contain an incrementing timestamp
    (retrievable with CGPS::GetUtcTime() and CGPS::GetGpsTime()).
    Therefore the record time of the first record will have the same
    date/time as the SV_PhotoLog or SV_PhotoGpsLog record that
    starts the data and the last one has not.
    But that is more meant as a warning that the timestamp of them is
    different, because if you need to sort the records in proper order.
    You can simply sort them in low to high order on their binary data
    (CGPS::GetBinaryData()), even as data strings (CGPS::GetHttpData())
    alphabetically and case sensitive.
    The example server contains functional code to do al this already
    which you of which you can of course use its feature and/or re-use
    its source code.

    See description of CGPS::GetPhotoLogDataBytes() for general
    background information of taking pictures.
function CanGetPhotoLogDataBytes()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetPhotoLogDataBytes()
The data bytes in a picture log record.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Binary bytes that are part of a full JPEG picture taken with the camera.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetPhotoLogDataBytes()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    With this function you can extract the JPEG data bytes from the
    SV_PhotoLogData records that follows a SV_PhotoLog or SV_PhotoGpsLog
    record (depends on SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto) from which
    the total data size can be retrieved with CGPS::GetPhotoLogDataSize().
    See CGPS::GetPhotoLogDataSize() function description for more info
    about reconstruction the JPEG picture data from such records.

******
****** Background information for taking pictures with an attached camera
******
    When a photo is taken with an attached camera, the picture data is compressed
    in JPEG format and transmitted asynchronously as a big binary block of data
    via a live connection to the server together with a SV_Photo or SV_PhotoGps
    record (depending on SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto).
    So pictures can only be taken while there actually is (or can be set up when
    taking the picture) a live connection to the server.
    The next picture can only be taken when the full data is transmitted of which
    the speed depends on the GSM/GPRS signal quality and of course the speed of
    your provider's network system, which can take up to several minutes in which
    no other picture can be taken.
    If the connection gets lost during the transmission, then you will receive
    only a part of the data on your server and the data size stated in the
    SV_Photo/SV_PhotoGps record (CGPS::GetExtraDataSize()) will be bigger than
    the number of bytes that you actually receive on the server.
    NOTE: Some providers manipulate/limit data with proxy systems in their network
    and then deliver the result instead via the internet to your server and then
    the data size and received bytes do not match either.

    When the option to store pictures in the log (SETTING_LogPhotos) is enabled in
    the module settings, then a SV_PhotoLog or SV_PhotoGpsLog  (depending on
    SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto) is stored in the log and including the
    picture data spread over as many individual SV_PhotoLogData records as
    required for the full picture.
    At the server, from the SV_PhotoLog/SV_PhotoGpsLog record you can get the size
    of the picture (CGPS::GetPhotoLogDataSize()) and from every SV_PhotoLogData
    record the bytes (GetPhotoLogDataBytes()).
    A SV_PhotoLogData record can hold up to 25 bytes, so a picture of 25600 bytes
    (25KB) will create 25600/25=1024 records in the log.
    The records are created in the log much faster than they can be transmitted,
    so you can take a new picture already usually within a few seconds, even while
    the current one is being transmitted to the server.
    The advantage via the log is also, that taking pictures is always possible
    (unless of course the log is too full already, because records that still have
    to be transmitted are not overwritten) even if there is no live or signal
    stable quality connection.
    From the log, these records are transmitted just like any other record types
    (like the ones containing a GPS position) and are transmitted to the server
    with verification hand-shake.
    So even if during transmission data the GPRS connection goes bad or drops,
    records are resent or resumed when a new connection is established again.
    The picture data will not be recognized by proxy systems in your provider's
    network either.
    The down side of pictures via the log is, that because of this two way
    handshake transmission process, the total GPRS data usage per picture is
    higher.
    Having SETTING_MaxBatchTransmission ("Maximum batch size" in section 60
    of the settings application) to the highest level that still works with
    your server and GPRS provider's network, minimizes the extra GPRS data
    usage and at the same time increases
    transmission speed.
    The effective transmission speed depends of course on the network speed and
    the processing and responds speed of the server that every transmission is
    done to.

    Only for the very first picture with the camera after the module has been
    powered-up or restarted, there is a set-up time which takes about 1 to 2
    seconds.
    For every picture that is taken as ACTION_Photo for EVENT_TIMERS_1/2/3/4
    or any other EVENT_..., then the module will actually take 5 pictures with
    the camera and from those use the one with the highest JPEG compressed size,
    which allows the camera to adjust to the current light conditions and usually
    get the best picture result but on average requires about 5 seconds for a
    resulting picture.
    When taking a picture as ACTION_Photo for EVENT_TIMERS_5/6/7/8 or a
    direct command like ActionID 26, then only one picture is taken and used
    which then takes about 1 to 2 seconds instead.
function CanGetPhotoGpsTimeDifference()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetPhotoGpsTimeDifference()
Time difference in seconds between picture taken and the included GPS information.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Time in seconds as floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetPhotoGpsTimeDifference()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    A result of 0x800000 is returned if no GPS information was
    available to be included.
    When SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto is enabled,
    the module will transmit pictures to the server via
    SV_PhotoGps instead of SV_Photo.
    With this record, the module includes GPS information from
    the last position as a possibly inaccurate position.
    (see function CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate()).
    In ideal circumstances, every second a GPS position is available,
    so the included position could be up to a second old.
    When not moving, the position will be accurate, but when driving on
    a highway, the position could be 30 meters back.
    (see function CGPS::GetShake()).
    With bad GPS reception, the included position can be much older.
    Additional information included could be used to determine a more
    accurate position (see function CGPS::GetSpeed...()
    and CGPS::GetHeading()).
function CanGetLogDataType()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetLogDataType()
Type value of the logged data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    Value indicating the type of the data that was recorded in the log
    by the module:
    1: Binary data from a smart card reader initiated by ActionID 63.
        If the size of the data is only 2 bytes, then the data contains
        an error code indicating what went wrong during the attempt to
        read data from the card with the card reader.
        (smart card reader must be connected to serial port 3 and port
        mode set to "output", not "input/output").
    2: Settings data from EEPROM backup uploaded by the module,
        initiated by ActionID 97.
    3: LCD/Source-code data from FLASH backup uploaded by the module,
        initiated by ActionID 98.
        The data is uploaded as binary data which you can convert into
        source code with the CGPSCODE class, by using
        CGPSCODE::SetBinaryData() to input the binary data, then
        CGPSCODE::GetSourceCode() to retrieve the source code.
    4: Settings data from runtime RAM uploaded by the module,
        initiated by ActionID 99.
    5: LCD/Source-code data from runtime RAM uploaded by the module,
        initiated by ActionID 100.
        The data is uploaded as binary data which you can convert into
        source code with the CGPSCODE class, by using
        CGPSCODE::SetBinaryData() to input the binary data, then
        CGPSCODE::GetSourceCode() to retrieve the source code.
    6: 4000+ FLASH regions data from FLASH backup, initiated by
        ActionID 101.
    7: 4000+ FLASH regions data from runtime RAM, initiated by
        ActionID 102.
    8: SiRF GPS receiver ephemeris data, initiated by ActionID 143.
        You can upload a recent copy of this data from your server
        as assisted GPS data into other modules with SiRF GPS
        receiver to speed-up its time to first fix.
        Upload it from your server via the CGPS::mReserved member,
        for example when you receive a SV_PowerUp record from the
        module.
Notes:
    - Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLogDataType()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    - The ActionID numbers mentioned above will only add the data to
    the log if there is enough free record space left to fit the data.
    - See CGPS::GetLogDataBytes() for background information on how the
    logged data can be retrieved from the individual records.
function CanGetLogDataSize()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetLogDataSize()
Size in bytes of a logged data that spread over several other records.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of size in bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLogDataSize()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
   
    This function extracts the total size in bytes value of the logged
    data from a SV_LogDataHeader record.
    To reconstruct the full logged binary data block, append all data
    bytes from the individual SV_LogData records that follow, until you
    reach that total data size.
    The last SV_LogData record can contain some additional bytes which
    are to be ignored.
    They are all logged and transmitted in correct order, but
    additionally they specifically contain an incrementing timestamp
    (retrievable with CGPS::GetUtcTime() or CGPS::GetGpsTime()).
    The first SV_LogData record has the same timestamp as that of the
    SV_LogDataHeader record that starts the data and the rest increases.
    But that is more meant as a warning that the timestamp of them is
    different, for if you need to sort the records in proper order.
    You can simply sort them in low to high order on their binary data
    (CGPS::GetBinaryData()), even as data strings (CGPS::GetHttpData())
    alphabetically and case sensitive.
    The example server contains functional code to do al this already
    which you of which you can of course use its feature and/or re-use
    its source code.

    See description of CGPS::GetLogDataBytes() for general background
    information of logged data.
function CanGetLogDataBytes()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetLogDataBytes()
Retrieve the data bytes from the VSM_LogDataBytes record.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Binary bytes that are part of the full binary data block that was logged.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLogDataBytes()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    With this function you can extract the binary data bytes from the
    SV_LogDataHeader records that follow a SV_LogData
    record of which the total data size can be retrieved with
    CGPS::GetLogDataSize().
    See CGPS::GetLogDataSize() function description for more info
    about reconstruction the binary data from such records.

******
****** Background information on binary data bytes via the log
******
    The ActionID numbers mentioned for CGPS::GetLogDataType() will
    record a block of binary data bytes in the log when executed.
    If at that time there is not enough free space in the log, then no
    data is logged and no records already on the log are overwritten.
    When the data is recorded in the log, then a SV_LogDataHeader
    is stored in the log, followed by the actual binary data spread
    over as many individual SV_LogData records as required for the
    full data block that is logged.
    At the server, from the SV_LogDataHeader record you can retrieve
    type of the binary data with CGPS::GetLogDataType() and
    the size of the binary data with CGPS::GetLogDataSize().
    Each SV_LogData record has space for 25 bytes of data, so a log
    data size of for example 12345 bytes would mean 12345/25=493.8=494
    records of which the last one record has 5 unused bytes at the end.
    From the individual SV_LogData records (in order that they were
    logged) you gather the data blocks with CGPS::GetLogDataBytes()
    and combine them together until you have all the bytes together
    of the above mentioned log data size.

    The advantage via the log is, that logging binary data blocks
    is always possible (unless of course the log is too full already,
    because records that still have to be transmitted are not
    overwritten) even if there is no live signal stable quality
    connection.
    From the log, these records are transmitted just like any other
    record types (like the ones containing a GPS position) and are
    transmitted to the server with verification hand-shake.
    So even if during transmission data the GPRS connection goes bad
    or drops, records are resent or resumed when a new connection is
    established again.
    Having SETTING_MaxBatchTransmission ("Maximum batch size" in
    section 60 of the settings application) to the highest level that
    still works with your server and GPRS provider's network, minimizes
    the extra GPRS data usage and at the same time increases
    transmission speed.
    The effective transmission speed depends of course on the network
    speed and the processing and responds speed of the server that
    has to acknowledge every individual batch transmission.
function CanGetLogDataGpsTimeDifference()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetLogDataGpsTimeDifference()
Time difference in seconds between the logged data and the included GPS information.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Time in seconds as floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLogDataGpsTimeDifference()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    A result of 0x800000 is returned if no GPS information was
    available to be included.
    With this record, the module includes GPS information from
    the last position as a possibly inaccurate position.
    (see function CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate()).
    In ideal circumstances, every second a GPS position is available,
    so the included position could be up to a second old.
    When not moving, the position will be accurate, but when driving on
    a highway, the position could be 30 meters back.
    With bad GPS reception, the included position can even be much older.
    Additional included GPS information could be used to determine
    a more accurate position (see functions CGPS::GetSpeed...()
    and CGPS::GetHeading()).
function CanGetPortData()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetPortDataSize()
Size in bytes of the data that the module received via a serial port.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of size in bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetPortData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::GetPortDataBytes()
function GetPortDataBytes()
The data bytes that the module received via a serial port.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Binary bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetPortData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::GetPortDataSize()

******
****** Background information about the serial ports
******
A serial port is controlled by a so called UART.
(Universal Asynchronous Receiver / Transmitter).
Rev8 hardware series modules with full I/O connector have for example
have two internal UARTs to control their 4 external serial ports.
One for ports 1 and 2, and one for ports 3 and 4.
So when receiving incoming serial data (RxD) via serial port 1 or 2,
it ends up at the same UART.
For that reason it is unknown to the module via which physical
external connector pin the data is actually received and internally
processed as one and when recorded in the log the data is stored in
SV_Port2Data records.
Same thing with port 3 and 4 which are stored in the log as
SV_Port4Data records.
Newer module hardware series than Rev8 (like the Rev9 series) actually
do have 4 UARTs but by default for backward compatibility emulate the
same behavior as the Rev8 series as described above.
Older module hardware series than Rev8 (like the Rev5 series) only
have one UART and store all data in the log in SV_Port4Data records.

Logically when more than one serial port is connected to the same
UART, they share the same protocol and baud rate.
But there will also be a problem if two devices connected to the same
UART send data because not only there is no telling which device sent
the data, it will also create an electrical problem because the
high/low voltages generating the signals contradict.
So you can only have one serial device per UART.
But there is are exceptions though.
Consider for example this:
Port 1 driver: NMEA output (standard GPS receiver output).
Port 2 driver: LCD + keyboard + iButton (an available add-on).
The NMEA driver only outputs serial data (TxD).
The LCD driver outputs data but also expects input.
Logically both drivers send out serial data and with the same UART
both ports output that same data and would be a problem.
But the module takes care of both drivers, by having the output of the
UART connected (or not) to the physical output pins of the serial
ports that the data should actually come out of externally.
So in the above example, every time the module outputs NMEA data it
temporarily has only port 1 connected to the output of the UART and
when sending data to the LCD module, it only temporarily connects
port 2 to the output of the UART.
Would you for example set the NMEA output for both ports, then it
would simply connect both ports to the output for the same NMEA
output on both ports.
In the above NMEA & LCD example, the NMEA drive only outputs
data, so you only connect port 1 TxD (and I/O-ground) to the external
device and not RxD because it is not needed.
And connect of port 2 TxD and RxD (and I/O-ground) to the LCD module.
So as you can see, this would work fine because because from serial
there is never incoming serial data, only from port 2 so no problem.
There are even combinations possible with external devices that both
send serial data, but only if for combinations that the module
firmware specifically supports for devices that only send data when
asked for and thus the module assuming incoming data was sent by
the device connected on port one or the other.

Like mentioned above, serial ports driven by the same UART need to be
in the same protocol and baud rate otherwise incoming data will not be
received (technically not required for sending out serial data because
of the "bank switch" method mentioned also above).
So you will have to take care of selection the same protocol and
baud rate.
You can use the following definitions in the settings:
- MPM_... (Module Port Mode).
- MPP_... (Module Port Protocol).
- MPB_... (Module Port Baudrate).
(the above can also be selected in section 59 of the settings
application).
function CanGetIButton()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.

******
****** Background information about 1-Wire bus/devices and iButtons
******
    1-Wire is a device communications bus system designed by Dallas
    Semiconductor Corp. that provides low-speed data, signaling, and
    power over a single signal.
    The bus send out requests to which attached 1-Wire devices respond
    with their own unique serial number and everything is done in a way
    that you can attach multiple 1-Wire devices in parallel to the same
    bus. So the bus can tell when 1-Wire devices are attached to the bus
    and tell when they are removed again later.
    If you for a module with “Full I/O” (those have a 24 pin connector)
    set SETTING_ModulePortMode4 to the MPM_1WireBus driver (or
    via settings application section 59), then it will generate an
    1-Wire bus for you. So without the need of any additional hardware,
    you can simply wire the pins of the full I/O module like this:

    10)--+
    11)--+--------------------------------- 1-Wire bus data

      9)------------------------------------ 1-Wire bus ground

    21)------------------------------------ additional power (if needed)

    !!! Consult the data sheet of the module for the pin layout spread
    !!! over the 4 and 24 pin connectors.
    Simply connect the two 1-Wire pins of the module together at the
    module side and from there you can go up to several meters to a
    1-Wire device. Its I/O-ground pin goes there directly. Only for
    1-Wire devices that require additional you need an extra wire.
    DS18B20/DS18S20/DS1822 temperature sensors for example
    have a third connection for connecting an additional 3,3Volt power
    supply that they require and for those you simply use the 3,3Volt
    output power pin of the module.

    With the above mentioned driver setting and wiring, you have created
    yourself a 1-Wire bus that automatically polls several times per
    second by sending data and charges to detect and read 1-Wire devices
    (enabled by default, but can be turned off/on by executing ActionID
    49..51). So when you simply connect an 1-Wire device to the bus, the
    module will automatically detected it and:
        - read the unique serial number of the 1-Wire device.
        - record a SV_iButton with the serial number in the log, but can
            be disabled with SETTING_DoNotLog1WireAttach (or in
            settings application section 54).
        - remember the serial number being attached in a list up to 30
            devices which you can record in the log with ActionID 16.
        - trigger EVENT_AttachIButton to execute the actions you
            have set for it.
      And additionally for LCD/Source-code use:
        - copy the serial number into User Variable 99
        - copy previous serial number in User Variable 98
        - Scan the instruction slots for Type settings like 13, 14, 15
            and 40 to do the compares and possible triggers you have
            set.
        - update contents of System Variables like %S99, %SA0..%SA9,
            %SB0..%SB9, %SC0..%SC9.
    From then, the device is "attached" to the bus. When you disconnect
    it again, during the next automatic poll logically does nor respond
    anymore with the following "detached" actions performed by the
    module:
        - trigger EVENT_DetachIButton to execute the actions you
            have set for it.
        - record a SV_1WireDetached with the serial number (or
            SV_iButton without serial number when using reader
            on display module), but can be disabled with
            SETTING_DoNotLog1WireDetach (or via settings
            application section 54).
    And additionally for LCD/Source-code use:
        - copy "----------------" into User Variable 99
        - update contents of System Variables like %S99, %SA0..%SA9,
            %SB0..%SB9, %SC0..%SC9.
    The module supports up to thirty 1-Wire devices connected at the
    same time to its 1-Wire bus. Therefore you can decide with
    SETTING_1WireBusChangeEvent if you want the
    EVENT_AttachIButton / EVENT_DetachIButton events
    to trigger with every 1-Wire device attach/detach or only with the
    first/last device. And having people manually touching/connecting
    devices to the 1-Wire bus, they could possibly connect and
    disconnect the device multiple times (even with steady hands and no
    shaking), thus resulting in multiple attach/detach events.
    Therefore by default the module will only determine a device
    detached if a device with the same serial number does not respond
    anymore for 1 second (you can change this time with
    SETTING_iButtonRemovalDelay or in settings application
    section 55).

    An iButton is an 1-Wire device without additional features in a
    metal casing.
    ( http://www.maximintegrated.com/products/ibutton/ibuttons/ )
    The metal casing is small, robust, waterproof and looks a bit like
    round a flat battery that can easily be integrated in a key-chain
    holder or glued to devices or shipping crates. Have some touch pad
    consisting of two metal contacts connected to your 1-Wire bus and
    you can easily touch the two together. For that and also something
    that holds the iButton many options are readily available. For
    example not only to touch the 1-Wire bus to the iButton, but also
    to easily touch the iButton to the 1-Wire bus or even have it stick
    until you remove it again. So you can imagine that applications from
    user identification to open a door or drive a vehicle, to
    parcels/containers checkpoints up-to punch-clock like things for
    people being present or not.

    The parasite power 1-Wire devices draw from the bus is sufficient
    for the serial number, but as said earlier, 1-Wire devices like the
    DS18B20/DS18S20/DS1822 are temperature sensors that require
    additional power fore their additional internal circuitry. Without
    additional power, they will only properly supply their serial number,
    to have them measure the temperature additional power must be
    connected. And you also need to initiate sending/receiving commands
    and data to start and receive the reading to them over the 1-Wire
    bus. You simply do that by executing ActionID 17 to have that done
    automatically for all attached temperature sensors and have their
    temperature readings recorded in the log as SV_1WireData1 records.
    Recommended to not do that again within half a minute or so,
    because from that work the sensor may heat up and thus give you
    higher readings.

    Logically records mentioned above you put in the log get from there
    transferred to your server just like your position records and such
    you put in the log. So on your server you can retrieve all
    information from them and know exactly when what happened.

Usage example:


    <?php
    $pcGPS=new CGPS();
    if(!$pcGPS->SetHttpData('<enter a module data string here>'))
    {
        for($DataPart=0;$DataPart<$pcGPS->GetDataPartCount();$DataPart++) //Loop through all module data parts if there are more than one
        {
            printf('******** module data part #%d ********<BR>', $DataPart);
            if( $pcGPS->SelectDataPart($DataPart) && $pcGPS->IsValid() )
            {
                if($pcGPS->CanGetIButton())
                {
                    print('1-Wire device (e.g. iButton) connection change: ');
                    if($pcGPS->GetIButtonAttached()) print('Attach<BR>');
                    else print('Detach<BR>');
                }
                if($pcGPS->CanGetIButtonSerialNumber())
                {
                    printf('Device serial number read: %s<BR>', $pcGPS->GetIButtonSerialNumberText());
                    printf('Device serial number swapped: %s<BR>', $pcGPS->GetIButtonSerialNumberTextSwapped());
                }
                if($pcGPS->CanGet1WireData())
                {
                    printf('1-Wire data part: %d<BR>', $pcGPS->Get1WireDataPart());
                    printf('1-Wire data last part: %s<BR>', $pcGPS->Get1WireDataClosure() ? 'Yes' : 'No');
                    printf('1-Wire data part length: %d<BR>', $pcGPS->Get1WireDataLength());
                    printf('1-Wire data bytes (hexadecimal): %s<BR>', bin2hex($pcGPS->Get1WireDataBytes()));
                }
                if($pcGPS->CanGet1WireDS18B20temperature())
                    printf('1-Wire DS18B20/DS18S20/DS1822 device temperature degrees: %.1fC/%.1fF<BR>'
                        , $pcGPS->Get1WireDS18B20celcius(), $pcGPS->Get1WireDS18B20fahrenheit());
            } else printf('ERROR bad part: %s<BR>', htmlspecialchars($pcGPS->GetLastError()));
        }
    } else printf('ERROR bad data string: %s<BR>', htmlspecialchars($pcGPS->GetLastError()));
    ?>


function GetIButtonAttached()
Determine if a 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton) was being attached or detached.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE=attach or FALSE=detach.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetIButton()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGetIButton() function documentation for usage example.
function CanGetIButtonSerialNumber()
Returns boolean TRUE or FALSE depending on the availability of the
serial number of a 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton).
Notes:
    See CGPS::CanGetIButton() function documentation for usage example.
function GetIButtonSerialNumberBinary()
The serial number of a 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton) as binary bytes.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Binary bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetIButtonSerialNumber()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::CanGetIButtonSerialNumber() and
    CGPS::GetIButtonSerialNumberText().
    The serial number can be printed on the iButton device in reversed
    byte order.
function GetIButtonSerialNumberText()
The serial number of a 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton) as text.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with hexadecimal representation of the serial number.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetIButtonSerialNumber()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    For 1-Wire devices that are big enough to have the serial number
    stamped/imprinted on its body, the serial number is usually in
    opposite byte order compared to how it electrically supplies
    its serial number, so a device that delivers serial number
    0831C39500000027 has 2700000095C33108 stamped/imprinted
    on its body.
    This function returns the serial number in the same order as the
    device supplies it.
    See CGPS::CanGetIButton() function documentation for usage example.
    See also CGPS::GetIButtonSerialNumberTextSwapped()
    See also ByteSwap1WireSerialNumber()
function GetIButtonSerialNumberTextSwapped()
The serial number of a 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton) as text in
reversed byte order.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with hexadecimal representation of the serial number
        in reversed byte order.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the function
    CGPS::CanGetIButtonSerialNumber() returns a boolean TRUE.
    For 1-Wire devices that are big enough to have the serial number
    stamped/imprinted on its body,
    the serial number is usually in opposite byte order compared to how
    it electrically supplies its serial number, so a device that
    delivers serial number 0831C39500000027 has 2700000095C33108
    stamped/imprinted on its body.
    This function returns the serial number in the opposite byte order
    as the device supplies it, which is usually the order that the
    serial number is stamped/imprinted on larger devices (e.g. iButton).
    See CGPS::CanGetIButton() function documentation for usage example.
    See also CGPS::GetIButtonSerialNumberText()
    See also ByteSwap1WireSerialNumber()
function CanGet1WireData()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
Notes:
    *** Information about 1-Wire data format ***
    The data that is read from a device via the 1-Wire bus formatted as: <Device serial number><Device data>.
    This full data structure is stored in the module log with Switch value SV_1WireData1 (see CGPS::GetSwitch()).
    Depending on the total size of the data, SV_1WireData1 only contains the first part of the total data.
    In that case the second part is stored as SV_1WireData2, the 3rd as SV_1WireData3 ...
    (see CGPS::Get1WireDataPart()) up to the final part of the data (see CGPS::Get1WireDataClosure()).
    By retrieving and combining the data from all individual parts (see CGPS::Get1WireDataBytes()),
    you reconstruct the full data structure of which the format is described above.
    <Device serial number>=<device type byte><6 bytes unique number><CRC byte>
    <Device data>=data bytes of which meaning and length depend on the device type and reading.

    See CGPS::CanGetIButton() function documentation for usage example.
function Get1WireDataPart()
The part number of the current part of the 1-Wire (iButton) device data structure.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of data part.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGet1WireData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGet1WireData() function documentation for more
    info on 1-Wire data.
function Get1WireDataClosure()
Determine if this is the last part of the 1-Wire (iButton) data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE or FALSE.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGet1WireData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGet1WireData() function documentation for more
    info on 1-Wire data.
function Get1WireDataLength()
Length in bytes of this part of the 1-Wire device (iButton) data structure.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of length in bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGet1WireData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGet1WireData() function documentation for more
    info on 1-Wire data.
function Get1WireDataBytes()
The binary data bytes of this part of the 1-Wire (iButton) device data structure.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Binary bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGet1WireData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGet1WireData() function documentation for more
    info on 1-Wire data.
function CanGet1WireDS18B20temperature()
Returns boolean TRUE or FALSE depending on availability.
function Get1WireDS18B20celcius()
Temperature of a DS18B20/DS18S20/DS1822 1-Wire device in degrees Celsius.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Temperature in degrees Celsius as floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGet1WireDS18B20temperature()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    A 1-Wire temperature sensor devices themselves produce heat during
    a measurement cycle which may lead to higher readings when
    processed more than once per minute.
    Unlike 1-Wire devices like iButtons, 1-Wire temperature devices can
    not operate from parasite power only and require a 3.3Volt power
    supply which can be taken from connector pin 21.
    Without this power supply, temperature measurements usually result
    in constant readings of 85 degrees Celcius.
    See CGPS::CanGetTemperature() for background information on
    measuring temperatures().
    See CGPS::CanGet1WireData() function documentation for more
    info on 1-Wire data.
    See also CGPS::Get1WireDS18B20fahrenheit().
function Get1WireDS18B20fahrenheit()
Temperature of a DS18B20/DS18S20/DS1822 1-Wire device in degrees Fahrenheit.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Temperature in degrees Fahrenheit as floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGet1WireDS18B20temperature()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    A 1-Wire temperature sensor devices themselves produce heat during
    a measurement cycle which may lead to higher readings when
    processed more than once per minute.
    Unlike 1-Wire devices like iButtons, 1-Wire temperature devices can
    not operate from parasite power only and require a 3.3Volt power
    supply which can be taken from connector pin 21.
    Without this power supply, temperature measurements usually result
    in constant readings of 185 degrees Fahrenheit.
    See CGPS::CanGetTemperature() for background information on
    measuring temperatures().
    See CGPS::CanGet1WireData() function documentation for more
    info on 1-Wire data.
    See also CGPS::Get1WireDS18B20celcius().
function CanGetLcdData()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
Notes:
    *** Information about the data from the LCD-display add-on ***
    The Data field contents of an instruction slot programmed by
    your LCD/Source-code is recorded into the log as a record with
    Switch value SV_LcdData1 (see CGPS::GetSwitch()).
    If the data does not fit into a single record, then it is
    automatically divided into parts (see CGPS::GetLcdDataPart())
    and recorded in additional record SV_LcdData2 up-to record
    SV_LcdData16 if necessary.
    The last record containing the end of the data always has a
    closing marker set for the record, so by checking that you
    know if there are more parts in other record or not (see
    CGPS::GetLcdDataClosure()).
    By retrieving the data parts from the individual records
    (see CGPS::GetLcdDataBytes()) and and combining the
    output together you reconstruct the full data.
function GetLcdDataPart()
The part number of the current part of the LCD-display data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of data part.
        1 for first data part (from SV_LcdData1 data record).
        2 for second data part (from SV_LcdData2 data record).
        ...
        16 for sixteenth data part (from SV_LcdData16 data record).
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLcdData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGetLcdData() function documentation for more
    info on LCD-display data.
function GetLcdDataClosure()
Determine if this is the last part of the LCD-display data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE or FALSE.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLcdData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGetLcdData() function documentation for more
    info on LCD-display data.
function GetLcdDataLength()
Length in bytes of this part of the LCD-display data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of length in bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLcdData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGetLcdData() function documentation for more
    info on LCD-display data.
function GetLcdDataBytes()
The data bytes of this part of the LCD-display data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Binary bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLcdData()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGetLcdData() function documentation for more
    info on LCD-display data.
function CanGetCustomPositionData()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetCustomPositionData()
Custom data produced by custom firmware.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - 32 bit value with custom firmware data.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetCustomPositionData()
    function returns a Boolean TRUE.
    The meaning of the resulting 32 value of this function completely
    depends on the custom function that you are using it for.
    If a custom firmware feature is created for you that generates your
    custom data, you will know what it is for.
    The custom data itself can be retrieved from records with Switch
    value: SV_PositionCustom, SV_KeepAliveCustom,
    SV_TimeAliveCustom and SV_InaccuratePositionCustom which
    will be logged by the module if the GLST_PositionCustom type
    is selected in the module settings.
    When the log was triggered by a Custom event, the event value that
    you can retrieve with the CGPS::GetEventID() function
    will have Event value 70 (= Custom).
function CanGetAccelerationX()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetAccelerationX()
Get G-Force reading of the X direction acceleration sensor.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point G-Force value from -6g up to +6g.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAccelerationX()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The result value is positive or negative depending on the direction.
    See also CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and
    CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration().

******
****** Background information about the internal 3D acceleration sensor
******          (for modules that have one built-in)
    The g force from -6g up to +6g is measured in 16 bits for the X, Y
    and Z directions.
    When you mount the module at horizontal level with the antenna
    connectors towards the front of the vehicle with the connector text
    readable, then:
    - Sensor X measures forward/backward g-force.
        Positive (+X) values are for accelerating (more gas).
        Negative (-X) values are for decelerating (breaking).
    - Sensor Y measures left/right g-force.
        Positive (+Y) values while making a left turn.
        Negative (-Y) values while making a right turn.
    - Sensor Z measures up/down g-force.
        Measures about -1g from the earth's gravitation pull.
        While accelerating upwards, the value gets further negative.
        While accelerating downwards, the value gets further positive.
    If mounted in a different/random but static orientation, you could
    enable SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration
    (or in section 10 of the settings application), then the readings of
    the sensors are automatically converted by the results of a one time
    automatic calibration process and then the mounting orientation of
    the module does not matter at all.
    Note that the automatic calibration feature disables events based on
    accel-sensor readings and will never trigger before the automatic
    calibration process is fully finished which if you use the unit on
    your desktop, in your pocket or even in/on a vehicle/vessel that
    never reaches minimum GPS speeds and acceleration/deceleration
    required by various steps of the automatic calibration process that
    it will logically never reaches calibrated state either.
    First step of this automatic calibration process is when a GPS
    determined speed of at least 40kmph (25mph) is reached (thus
    assuming that it is mounted in a vehicle already).
    Then when speed later becomes completely zero (assuming parked
    leveled and not on a slope), the Z-axis is calibrated to the earths
    gravitation pull.
    After that calibration, first time decrease in GPS speed detected
    from at least 40kmph (25kmph) down to a speed in range between
    10 to 30kmph (6.25 to 18.75mph) while GPS heading direction
    during that time is constant, the X and Y calibration are
    determined.
    From then on (as long as the setting is still enabled) all accel
    sensor readings are converted for performing accel events and
    recordings in the log.
    If you later want to re-initiate the calibration process again with
    ActionID 62, like after you changed the mounting orientation of the
    module.
    If needed, you can check the calibration progress via "System
    Variable" %S93 of LCD/Source-code and also the status of Bit 3
    of the CGPS::GetAdditionalIO() function result can be used
    to check if the calibration process is finished and in use.

    An X sensor value of -0.5g is for example when you use your vehicle
    breaks relatively strong.
    Accelerating a vehicle depends of course on the vehicle, but when
    you are a bit in a hurry in a car with reasonable strong engine,
    you get about +0.3g.
    If you like a total maniac take a roundabout, you get a Y-sensor
    value of +0.9g (or of course -0.9g if you drive on the left hand
    side of the road like in the U.K. or Japan).
    So values from 1.0g can be considered a "problem" already.
    1g means a speed change of 9.81 m/s^2, so if you measure 1g, the
    speed changes at 35 km/h in that direction.
    Thus theoretically speaking, if you drive 140 km/h (87.5mph) and
    would use the breaks at 1g, then you will make a full stop in just
    4 seconds.

    Next to what you find a suitable limit for your vehicles, for
    trucks and special loads, the law enforcement and/or manufacturer
    may already specify certain limits.
    In the module's settings, you can specify the maximum g-force
    readings of the x/y/z sensors via EVENT_ACCELERATION_...
    events (section 10 of the settings application) to have the g-force
    readings constantly monitored and have the actions you want
    performed when those limits are exceeded.
    You could for example have the max event activate a digital output
    and the min event deactivate a digital output and have some noisy
    buzzer device connected to that to warn a driver for dangerous
    driving.

    You can (also) make these events log a SV_PositionAcceleration
    record by making them execute ActionID 57 (even by setting
    SETTING_LogSwitchType to type GLST_PositionAcceleration
    (or in section 54 of the settings application) to have every GPS
    position that you make the module record in the log include the
    current accel sensor readings instead of Temperature, Altitude and
    Reset information, but in most cases that is not what you want).
    Unlike most other events, that would not set a to-do flag (which are
    gathered once per second) to start the process of turning+keeping
    GPS receiver on and wait until it outputs a usable fix to derive
    the information from.
    Instead, the accel events immediately log records and uses info from
    the last fix that previously came out of the GPS receiver in them
    (or if not available or more than two seconds old generates a
    TimeAlive or KeepAlive substitute record instead according to your
    choice via SETTING_UseSystemTimeForKeepAlive).
    With CGPS::GetEventID() you can see from the record which event
    triggered and recorded it.
    And from SV_PositionAcceleration records (and substitutes) you can
    retrieve the accel values that triggered the event with
    CGPS::GetAccelerationX(), CGPS::GetAccelerationY() and
    CGPS::GetAccelerationZ().

    With SETTING_AccelEventsTriggering you can make the accel-max
    events use the accel-sensor reading that triggered the event as new
    condition value for the event.
    If you for example set a condition value of 0.5g for a max event and
    choose 0.05g incremental triggering, then at first, the event will
    trigger to any accel-sensor reading above 0.5g.
    Suppose a reading of 0.6g occurs then the event triggers, but next
    next time it will only trigger again on values above 0.6g+0.5g.
    Depending on the live situation, that can of course be reached
    really soon and generate up to 4 triggers per second.
    But in most cases you will eventually reach a condition value that
    is not exceeded anymore in practice.
    That is were the accel-min events come in.
    Every time an accel-min event triggers, the accel-max event
    condition will be automatically reset back to the condition value
    you have set in the settings as the bottom level of the hysteresis
    relation between the two.
    So unless you for example are only are interested in the highest
    measured g-force during a trip, you will always want to set a
    relatively low condition value for the accel-min event too, to reset
    the triggering again after everything returned to what you think
    are safe levels again.

    More information about g-force in general at:
    http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G-force

    But you can do more with the accel sensor than measuring the
    G-force for the X/Y/Z axis.
    The module also calculates a vibrancy/motion level value from all
    measurements it does with the accel sensor.
    This value is continuously calculated and can vary between 0 and
    65536 and has nothing to do with G-force.
    When for example the module is mounted in a car of which the engine
    is running stationary, the value is above 100 (around 500 for an
    average car) while during the start of the engine the value
    normally exceeds 4000.
    You can make use of this continuously live updated vibrancy/motion
    value:
    - for motion detection with SETTING_MinSensorDetectionStartMoving
        and SETTING_MovingOnSensorDetect (or "start >" and "stop <" in
        section 57 of the settings application) to have to have the
        module switch between "moving mode" and "not moving mode" based
        on the current vibrancy/motion value.
        See CGPS::GetShake() for background information on
        motion detection.
    - to prohibit region detection events from triggering while the
        vibrancy/motion value is below your preferred minimum level
        that you have used in the settings with
        SETTING_MinimumAccelSensorMotionForRegionDetection
        (or in section 53 of the settings application).
        See CGPSsettings::SetEventRegion() for background information
        on region detection).
    - via System Variable %S94 which you can in your own LCD/source-
        code for example use to log the log the current value, send it
        via SMS, display it on an attached LCD module or even monitor
        the value to be above/below/between some level and take actions
        if it is or not.

    Tip for displaying the live vibrancy/motion level value live on an
    attached LCD module so you can simply see the currently measured
    value in an actual environment:
    Start the LCD simulator and click "Show editor".
    Click "Create new program" and change the contents of the "Data"
    field into: X%S47 Y%S48%010Z%S49 V%S94
    Click "Save", then click "Download source code".
    Upload the source code into the module and also settings in which
    you have set serial port 2 mode to: "LCD + keyboard + iButton".
    (Re)start-up the module and on the connected LCD you will see the
    live values of the X/Y/Z-sensors and the Vibrancy/motion level value.
function CanGetAccelerationY()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetAccelerationY()
Get G-Force reading of the Y direction acceleration sensor.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point G-Force value from -6g up to +6g.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAccelerationY()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The result value is positive or negative depending on the direction.
    See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for some background information.
function CanGetAccelerationZ()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetAccelerationZ()
Get G-Force reading of the Z direction acceleration sensor.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point G-Force value from -6g up to +6g.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAccelerationZ()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The result value is positive or negative depending on the direction.
    See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for some background information.
function GetGpsTime()
GPS date/time of the data as a timestamp.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Timestamp as double precision floating point value.
        Use PHP functions like date() and gmdate().
Notes:
    The returned time stamp contains the module's system time in GPS
    time when it logged the data, which is not adjusted with leap
    seconds like UTC time, for which you will want to use
    CGPS::GetUtcTime() instead.
    See CGPS::GetUtcTime() for more details on the subject.
function GetGpsTimeMySQL()
GPS date/time of the data in SQL query format (yyyymmddhhmmss text).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - ASCII text string in yyyymmddhhmmss format (year/month/day/hour/minute/second).
Notes:
    The text string is generated from the GPS time of the
    CGPS::GetGpsTime() function, which is not adjusted with
    leap seconds as with the CGPS::GetUtcTimeMySQL() function.
    See CGPS::GetUtcTime() function notes for additional information.
function CanGetLatLong()
Test for availability of probably accurate GPS information.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE or FALSE.
Notes:
    When this function returns a boolean TRUE result, then GPS
    information is available with reasonable probability that the
    accuracy is high.
    On boolean FALSE result, CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate()
    may return TRUE instead if there is GPS info at all.
    For GPS status use CGPS::GetGpsStatus().
    For the accuracy level use CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInMeters()
    or CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInFeet().
    Also usable to determine an accuracy estimate are:
    CGPS::GetView(), CGPS::GetFix() and CGPS::GetMaxDB().
function CanGetLatLongInaccurate()
Test for availability of probably inaccurate GPS information.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE or FALSE.
Note:
    When this function returns a boolean TRUE result, then GPS
    information is available with reasonable probability that the
    accuracy is low to none at all.
    On boolean FALSE result, CGPS::CanGetLatLong() may return
    TRUE instead if there is a high chance for accurate info.
    For GPS status use CGPS::GetGpsStatus().
    For the accuracy level use CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInMeters()
    or CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInFeet().
    Also usable to determine an accuracy estimate are:
    CGPS::GetView(), CGPS::GetFix() and CGPS::GetMaxDB().
function GetLatitudeSmall()
Latitude in small storage form.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Integer value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when
    CGPS::CanGetLatLong() (or CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate())
    returns a boolean TRUE.
    The return value of this function can be stored in a MySQL INT
    field (=4 bytes).
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to
    find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See conversion functions:
    - LatitudeSmallToFloat()
    - LatitudeFloatToSmall()
    - LatitudeSmallToDegrees()
function GetLatitudeFloat()
Latitude as floating point value.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The return value of this function can be stored in a MySQL DOUBLE
    field (=8 bytes).
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to
    find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLatitudeSmall() and LatitudeSmallToFloat()
function GetLatitudeDegrees(&rDegrees, &rMinutes, &rSeconds, &rNS, &rfDecimals)
Latitude in Degrees, Minutes, Seconds, N(orth)/S(outh) and minute decimals.
Function input:
    - rDegrees: Reference to a variable that will receive the degrees as integer value.
    - rMinutes: Reference to a variable that will receive the minutes as integer value.
    - rSeconds: Reference to a variable that will receive the seconds as integer value.
    - rNS:    Reference to a variable that will receive the letter 'N' or 'S' as a string.
    - rfDecimals: Reference to a variable that will receive the minute decimals as floating point value.
Function result:
    - None. All results are directly stored into the referenced variables.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to
    find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See also CGPS::GetLatitudeSmall()
function GetLongitudeSmall()
Longitude in small storage form.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Integer value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The return value of this function can be stored in a MySQL INT
    field (=4 bytes).
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to
    find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See conversion functions:
    - LongitudeSmallToFloat()
    - LongitudeFloatToSmall()
    - LongitudeSmallToDegrees()
function GetLongitudeFloat()
Longitude as floating point value.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The return value of this function can be stored in a MySQL DOUBLE
    field (=8 bytes).
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to
    find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLongitudeSmall()
function GetLongitudeDegrees(&rDegrees, &rMinutes, &rSeconds, &rEW, &rfDecimals)
Longitude in Degrees, Minutes, Seconds, E(ast)/W(est) and minute decimals.
Function input:
    - rDegrees: Reference to a variable that will receive the degrees as integer value.
    - rMinutes: Reference to a variable that will receive the minutes as integer value.
    - rSeconds: Reference to a variable that will receive the seconds as integer value.
    - rEW:    Reference to a variable that will receive the letter 'E' or 'W' as a string.
    - rfDecimals: Reference to a variable that will receive the minute decimals as floating point value.
Function result:
    - None. All results are directly stored into the referenced variables.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to
    find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLongitudeSmall()
function CanGetLatLongMargin()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetLatLongMargin()
Maximum Latitude/Longitude position dislocation with a probability of 67%.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Integer value.
        0 = Unknown margin
        Formula for 1 and up: meters=((1.1 to power of value)-1)*10
        Examples results: 1=1, 2=2.1, 3=3.31, 4=4.641, 5=6.1051
        6=7.7, 7=9.5, 8=11.4, 9=13.6, 10=15.9, 11=18.5, 12=21.3
        13=24.5, 14=28.0, 15=31.8, 16=35.9, 17=40.5, 18=45.6
        19=51.2, 20=57.3, 21=64.0, 22=71.4, 23=79.5, 24=88.5
        25=98.4, 26=109.2, 27=121.0, 28=134.2, 29=148.6
        30=164.5, 31=181.9, 32=201.1, 33=222.3, 34=245.5
        35=271.0, 36=299.1, 37=330.0, 38=364.0, 39=401.5
        40=442.6, 41=487.9, 42=537.6, 43=592.4, 44=652.6
        45=718.9, 46=791.8, 47=872.0, 48=960.2, 49=1057.2
        50=1163.9, 51=1281.3, 52=1410.4, 53=1552.5, 54=1708.7
        55=1880.6, 56=2069.7, 57=2277.6, 58=2506.4, 59=2758.0
        60=3034.8, 61=3339.3, 62=3674.2, 63=4042.7, 64=4447.9
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLongMargin()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This margin value is calculated by the GPS received itself from
    internal calculations on available data and is more sophisticated
    and reliable than you could determine yourself from basic info
    like HDOP, satellites in view, satellites used for fix, etc.
    When a margin 0 is returned, the actual margin was unknown
    at the time it was logged.
    See also CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInMeters()
    See also CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInFeet()
function GetLatLongMarginInMeters()
Maximum Latitude/Longitude position dislocation in meters with a probability of 67%.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLongMargin()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This margin value is calculated by the GPS received itself from
    internal calculations on available data and is more sophisticated
    and reliable than you could determine yourself from basic info
    like HDOP, satellites in view, satellites used for fix, etc.
    When a margin 0.0 meters is returned, the actual margin was unknown
    at the time it was logged.
    See also CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInFeet()
function GetLatLongMarginInFeet()
Maximum Latitude/Longitude position dislocation in feet with a probability of 67%.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLongMargin()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This margin value is calculated by the GPS received itself from
    internal calculations on available data and is more sophisticated
    and reliable than you could determine yourself from basic info
    like HDOP, satellites in view, satellites used for fix, etc.
    When a margin 0.0 feet is returned, the actual margin was unknown
    at the time it was logged.
    See also CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInMeters().

Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetAltitudeInMeters()
Altitude in meters (above WGS84 ellipsoid).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAltitude()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::GetAltitudeInFeet()
function GetAltitudeInFeet()
Altitude in feet (above WGS84 ellipsoid).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAltitude()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::GetAltitudeInMeters()

depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetAltitudeMargin()
function GetAltitudeMarginInMeters()
Maximum altitude position dislocation in meters with a probability of 67%.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAltitudeMargin()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This margin value is calculated by the GPS received itself from
    internal calculations on available data and is more sophisticated
    and reliable than you could determine yourself from basic info
    like VDOP, satellites in view, satellites used for fix, etc.
    When a margin 0.0 meters is returned, the actual margin was unknown
    at the time it was logged.
    See also CGPS::GetAltitudeInFeet()
function GetAltitudeMarginInFeet()
Maximum altitude position dislocation in feet with a probability of 67%
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetAltitudeMargin()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This margin value is calculated by the GPS received itself from
    internal calculations on available data and is more sophisticated
    and reliable than you could determine yourself from basic info
    like HDOP, satellites in view, satellites used for fix, etc.
    When a margin 0.0 feet is returned, the actual margin was unknown
    at the time it was logged.
    See also CGPS::GetAltitudeMarginInMeters()
function CanGetSpeed()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetSpeedKPH()
Speed in kilometers per hour.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetSpeed()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The maximum value that this function returns is limited to
    approximately 600KPH.
    (See also the functions: CGPS::GetSpeedMPH() and
    CGPS::GetSpeedKnots()).
    While the module is in "Not moving mode", you can have the GPS
    determined speed patched to 0.0 by enabling
    SETTING_ForceSpeedToZeroWhenNotMoving (or in section 54
    of the settings application).
    See background information in the CGPS::GetShake() function
    description for info about "(Not) Moving mode".
function GetSpeedMPH()
Speed in miles per hour.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetSpeed()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The maximum value that this function returns is limited to
    approximately 375MPH.
    (See also the functions: CGPS::GetSpeedKPH() and
    CGPS::GetSpeedKnots()).
    While the module is in "Not moving mode", you can have the GPS
    determined speed patched to 0.0 by enabling
    SETTING_ForceSpeedToZeroWhenNotMoving (or in section 54
    of the settings application).
    See background information in the CGPS::GetShake() function
    description for info about "(Not) Moving mode".
function GetSpeedKnots()
Speed in knots.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetSpeed()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The maximum value that this function returns is limited to
    approximately 325Knots.
    (See also the functions: CGPS::GetSpeedKPH() and
    CGPS::GetSpeedMPH()).
    While the module is in "Not moving mode", you can have the GPS
    determined speed patched to 0.0 by enabling
    SETTING_ForceSpeedToZeroWhenNotMoving (or in section 54
    of the settings application).
    See background information in the CGPS::GetShake() function
    description for info about "(Not) Moving mode".
function CanGetHeading()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetHeading()
Heading direction from 0.0 up to 359.99 degrees.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetHeading()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The floating point value that this function returns is the heading
    direction of which 0.0 means North and 180.0 means South.
Usage example:


    <?php
    if($pcGPS->CanGetHeading())
    {
        $fDegrees=$pcGPS->GetHeading();
        if($fDegrees<22.5) $Text='North';
        else if($fDegrees<67.5) $Text='North/East';
        else if($fDegrees<112.5) $Text='East';
        else if($fDegrees<157.5) $Text='South/East';
        else if($fDegrees<202.5) $Text='South';
        else if($fDegrees<247.5) $Text='South/West';
        else if($fDegrees<292.5) $Text='West';
        else if($fDegrees<337.5) $Text='North/West';
        else $Text='North';
    } else $Text="Not available";
    ?>


function CanGetHDOP()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetHDOP()
Horizontal Dilution Of Precision.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetHDOP()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also functions CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInMeters()
    and CGPS::GetLatLongMarginInFeet().
function CanGetView()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetView()
Number of "visible" satellites.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetView()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The GPS receiver keeps track of the data it extracts from the
    signals of as many GPS satellites you supply it via the GPS
    antenna.
    This function returns the number of individual GPS satellites
    it has gathered at least a minimal amount of data from.
    But only a useful amount of data of which a minimum level of
    reliability can be used in the calculation of a fix, so usually
    not all satellites in view are used to determine the fix.
    See also CGPS::GetFix()
    See also CGPS::GetMaxDB()
function CanGetFix()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetFix()
Number of satellites used to determine the GPS information.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetFix()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The GPS receiver keeps track of the data it extracts from the
    signals of as many GPS satellites you supply it via the GPS
    antenna.
    This function returns the number of satellites that were used to
    establish the GPS fix from.
    This usually is less than the number of satellites "in view" of
    which it has gathered at least some data from so far, because
    satellites from which a minimum amount of data with a level of
    reliability can is gathered can be used in the complicated
    calculations of position/speed/direction/...
    See also CGPS::GetView()
    See also CGPS::GetMaxDB()
function CanGetMaxDB()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetMaxDB()
Signal reception strength in dBm of the strongest GPS satellite.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - DB value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetMaxDB()
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetMaxDB()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This function returns the signal reception strength in dBm (decibel
    referenced to 1 milliwatt) of the strongest GPS satellite of the
    ones that were received from the GPS antenna.
    So the signal strength of all other GPS satellites in view are all
    are all lower than the returned value and therefore may not even.
    A MaxDB value below 35 happens when the GPS antenna is not placed
    properly to get a clear view in all directions (e.g. behind an
    obstruction or inside a building) to feed strong signals from as
    many GPS satellites at once to the GPS receiver.
    A MaxDB value around 50 is a normal value which you will want to
    get by providing a clear outdoors view in all directions around
    and is even possible with a good passive GPS antenna.
    See also CGPS::GetFix()
    See also CGPS::GetView()
    See also CGPS::GetGpsHighestMaxDB()
function CanGetGpsHighestMaxDB()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetGpsHighestMaxDB()
Highest signal reception strength in dBm of the strongest GPS satellite since the module (re)started.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - DB value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetGpsHighestMaxDB()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    This function returns the signal reception strength in dBm (decibel
    referenced to 1 milliwatt) of the strongest GPS satellite of the
    ones that were received from the GPS antenna since the module was
    (re)started.
    A MaxDB value below 35 happens when the GPS antenna is not placed
    properly to get a clear view in all directions (e.g. behind an
    obstruction or inside a building) to feed strong signals from as
    many GPS satellites at once to the GPS receiver.
    A MaxDB value around 50 is a normal value which you will want to
    get by providing a clear outdoors view in all directions around
    and is even possible with a good passive GPS antenna.
    See also CGPS::GetMaxDB()
function CanGetGpsStatus()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetGpsStatus()
Status of the GPS receiver
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value containing status bits of the GPS receiver.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetGpsStatus()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    Description of the status bits:
    - 5: Accuracy not met.
    - 0: Speed+Heading invalid.
Usage example:


    <?php
    if($pcGPS->CanGetGpsStatus())
    {
        $Bits=$pcGPS->GetGpsStatus();
        if($Bits)
        {
            $TextResult='Not OK:';
            if($Result&32) $TextResult.=' Insufficient accuracy.';
            if($Result&1) $TextResult.=' Speed and heading direction invalid.';
        } else $TextResult='OK: Everything within margin';
    } else $TextResult='Not available in this data';
    print("Current GPS status: $TextResult");
    ?>


function CanGetGpsFirmwareCrc()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetGpsFirmwareCrc()
"Cyclic Redundancy Check" value of GPS firmware.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - CRC value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetGpsFirmwareCrc()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
function CanGetGsmFirmwareCrc()
Returns boolean TRUE or FALSE depending on availability.
function GetGsmFirmwareCrc()
"Cyclic Redundancy Check" value of GMS firmware.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - CRC value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetGsmFirmwareCrc()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
function CanGetGsmCGACT()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
