depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetGsmCGACT()
PDP context (AT+CGACT?).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value representing one of the following:
        *** "GPRS context ACTivated" definitions ***

  • CGACT_Deactivated// PDP context deactivated
  • CGACT_Activated// PDP context activated

Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetGsmCGACT()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    The returned value gives you an indication if the PDP context
    was activated or not at the time the record containing the info
    was logged.
function CanGetGsmCGATT()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetGsmCGATT()
GPRS attach or detach (AT+CGATT?).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value representing one of the following:
        *** "Gprs Attached or Detached" definitions ***

  • CGATT_Detached// GPRS detached
  • CGATT_Attached// GPRS attached

Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetGsmCGATT()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    The returned value gives you an indication if a GPRS session
    was open or not at the time the record containing the info was
    logged.
function CanGetGsmCREG()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetGsmCREG()
Network Registration Report (AT+CREG?).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value representing one of the following:
        *** "network REGistration report" definitions ***

  • CREG_NotRegistered// Not registered to a network. Probably no network in range that allows the SIM card to register.
  • CREG_HomeNetwork// Registered to home network of the used SIM-card (so not roaming).
  • CREG_Searching// Searching for a usable network that allows registering onto, because none was found yet.
  • CREG_AccessDenied// Network allowed GSM registration (so phone calls and SMS messages should work), but denied GPRS usage making transmissions to the server impossible. Reasons for the network provider to deny GPRS usage can vary from no GPRS support for your SIM-card up to (temporary) works/problems at your provider. The module will automatically keep retrying and buffer records in the log until transmitting them is possible again and in the meanwhile continue its other duties normally.
  • CREG_Unknown// Unknown registering status.
  • CREG_Roaming// Registered onto a network that is of another provider than that of the SIM card. Usually this means that the SIM card providers network is not available like when you are in another country and therefore another provider's network is used instead. Note that roaming other networks is usually more expensive because you get charged by the network you are roaming plus your own network provider that data is forwarded throug, but all depends on whatever arrangements both providers agreed upon together for charging you. You can if you want disable roaming use of other networks with SETTING_SendGpsLogWhenRoaming or in section 58 of the settings application.

Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetGsmCREG()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    The returned value gives you an indication if the internal GSM
    modem was registered to a network at the time the record containing
    the info was logged.
Usage example:


    <?php
    if($pcGPS->CanGetGsmCGATT()==TRUE)
    {
        switch($pcGPS->GetGsmCGATT()) //Network Registration Report
        {
            case CREG_NotRegistered:
                $Report='Not registered to a network';
                break;
            case CREG_HomeNetwork:
                $Report='Registered to home network';
                break;
            case CREG_Searching:
                $Report='Searching network';
                break;
            case CREG_AccessDenied:
                $Report='Network did not allow registration';
                break;
            case CREG_Unknown:
                $Report='Current status unknown';
                break;
            case CREG_Roaming:
                $Report='Roaming';
                break;
            default:
                $Report='Unsupported report value: '.$pcGPS->GetGsmCGATT();
                break;
        };
    } else $Report="No report information available";
    ?>


function CanGetFstr()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetFstr()
GSM network signal quality from 0 up to 31 or 99 for unknown (AT+CSQ?).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value.
    0: -113dBm (or worse)
    1: -111dBm
    2..30: -109dBm .. -53dBm
    31: -51dBm (or better)
    99: unknown
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetFstr()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    Decent GPRS data transmissions require a signal strength of at
    least 11.
    But for larger blocks of data like settings, photos and firmware a
    higher strength may be required.
    NOTE: The field strength value is only measured and updated when a
    new GPRS session is opened.
function CanGetIMSI()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetIMSI()
International Mobile Subscriber Identity (AT+CIMI=?).
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with IMSI number.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetIMSI()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
function CanGetGsmNetworkID()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetGsmNetworkID()
The ID number of the GSM network provider that is in use.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of ID.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetGsmNetworkID()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The ID value is the MCC+MNC values of the network that the SIM card
    is registered onto.
    For SV_Network records this the first record transferred over that
    network to your server and the ones from the log transferred to your
    server afterward.
    You can for example use it to determine the provider and
    country of the network that the SIM card was registered to via lists
    on the internet like:
    http://www.google.com/search?q=20404+26202+vodafone+20408+kpn+31017+bell
    http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Network_Code
function CanGetSimPin()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetSimPin()
The PIN-code used to attempt to unlock the SIM-card
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string containing the used PIN-code where:
        FFFF means that no PIN-code or 0000 was tried.
        0000 up/to 9999 means the actual number that was tried.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetSimPin()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
function CanGetPhoneNumber()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetPhoneNumber()
Phone number that called or sent an SMS to the module.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with phone number.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetPhoneNumber()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    When you make a phone call to the phone number of the SIM-card
    used in the module, it will receive a "RING" message from the
    internal GSM modem.
    If that "RING" message includes an additional "clip", then a
    SV_CalledByKnownPhoneNumber is recorded in the log including
    the "clip" information with this function.
    Usually that contains the phone number of the caller, but
    even an empty clip or nonsense is possible depending on what
    the provider of the caller has put in it.
    If the provider of the caller does not support a feature often
    referred to as "Caller ID", or if it has been disabled for the
    the phone number of the caller, then there usually is no "clip"
    included either and then the SV_CalledByKnownPhoneNumber
    is recorded in the log.

    With an SMS message there is usually always a phone number
    of the sender included in the received data that contains the
    actual message, even if sender has "Caller ID" is disabled.
function GetMapquestUrl()
A www.mapquest.com compatible URL.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with URL.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    At time of writing, http://www.mapquest.com (no relations)
    provides a free service on the internet that graphically displays
    a position on a map.
    The service of http://www.mapquest.com can be unavailable or discontinued at any time.
function GetMultimapUrl()
A www.multimap.com compatible URL.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with URL.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    At time of writing, http://www.multimap.com (no relations) provides
    a free service on the internet that graphically displays a position
    on a map.
    The service of http://www.multimap.com can be unavailable or
    discontinued at any time.
function GetGoogleMapsUrl()
A maps.google.com compatible URL.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with URL.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    At time of writing, http://maps.google.com (no relations) provides
    a free service on the internet that graphically displays a position
    on a map.
    The service of http://maps.google.com can be unavailable or
    discontinued at any time.
function GetLiveMapsUrl()
A maps.live.com compatible URL.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with URL.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetLatLong() or
    CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    At time of writing, http://maps.live.com (no relations) provides
    a free service on the internet that graphically displays a position
    on a map.
    The service of http://maps.live.com can be unavailable or
    discontinued at any time.
function GetNMEA_RMC()
NMEA 0183 RMC protocol compatible string of the current position.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - NMEA text string.
Notes:
    The ASCII text string that this function returns is in NMEA RMC format.
    This "Recommended Minimum Specific GNSS Data" format contains
    time, date, position, speed and direction data of a GPS receiver.
    It is the most basic and standard form which most GPS receivers send
    as output via the serial port.
    Most navigation programs support these strings and you can use these
    strings to emulate a live working GPS receiver.
    NOTE:
    Information that is not available will be omitted from the output string.
    When CGPS::CanGetLatLong() (or even CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate())
    returns a Boolean TRUE result, most information in the output is available.
function GetNMEA_GGA()
NMEA 0183 GGA protocol compatible string of the current position.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - NMEA text string.
Notes:
    The ASCII text string that this function returns is in NMEA GGA format.
    This "Global Positioning System Fix Data" format contains time, position,
    used satellites, HDOP (Horizontal dilution of position) and altitude.
    Most GPS receivers can send this as extra output data via the serial port.
    See also CGPS::GetNMEA_RMC()
    NOTE:
    Information that is not available will be omitted from the output string.
    When CGPS::CanGetLatLong() (or even CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate())
    returns a Boolean TRUE result, most information in the output is available.
function GetNMEA_VTG()
NMEA 0183 VTG protocol compatible string of the current position.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - NMEA text string.
Notes:
    The ASCII text string that this function returns is in NMEA VTG format.
    This "Track Made Good and Ground Speed" format contains heading direction
    and ground speed information.
    Most GPS receivers can send this as extra output data via the serial port.
    See also CGPS::GetNMEA_RMC()
    NOTE:
    Information that is not available will be omitted from the output string.
    When CGPS::CanGetLatLong() (or even CGPS::CanGetLatLongInaccurate())
    returns a Boolean TRUE result, most information in the output is available.
function ClearResponseActionMembers()
Clear all response action member variables of the class by giving them a neutral setting.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - None.
Notes:
- This member function sets/clears all CGPS::m... action members of
        the class to a state in which they do not evoke an action.
        The constructor of the class automatically calls this function
        at the time that a new instance object op the CGPS class is
        created.
        See CGPS::BuildResponseHTTP()and CGPS::BuildResponseTCP()
        for more information.
- This function does not reset/clear internal memory allocated by
        settings data in the class like with CGPS::SetHttpData()
        and CGPS::SetTcpData.
        Use CGPS::Clear() to do that.
function RequireResponseActionMembersStall()
Check if one or more existing action request uploads require
the use of additional actions to be stalled for upload in
a next transmission.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Boolean: TRUE=yes or FALSE=no
Notes:
    The result of this function can help you to decide to make use
    of an additional CGPS::m... class member to upload a pending
    action or to wait and do it in a next transmission.
    If this function returns a Boolean TRUE result, you will probably
    want to stall your other pending actions to be uploaded in a next
    transmission.

    If you for example set CGPS::mActionID to 64, then ActionID 64
    will be executed by the module resulting in a restart of the unit
    and the other actions or uploads in the same transmission are
    likely to be without effect.
    Of course this is just about a worst case scenario and you will
    probably not use ActionID 64 ever anyway, but there are more
    actions that while being executed live when they are received
    byte-by-byte by the module from your server could result in some
    internal processing that could lead to the rest of the incoming
    bytes from the same server transmission not to be processed
    anymore.
    Some examples that could lead to other action requests uploaded
    in an upload at the same time not (fully) being processed:
    - CGPS::mActionID some actions (e.g. ActionID 64)
    - CGPS::mFirmware or CGPS::mFirmwareManufacturer
        which will make the module restart into a special mode in which
        it will attempt to download a firmware file from the server.
    - CGPS::mSettings which will make the module erase and update
        internal non volatile memory and after a full CRC check
        decide make the new settings permanent and restart to make the
        new settings the current ones in use.
    - CGPS::mSourceCode in case it contains live commands that make the
        module write the current contents in volatile memory into non
        volatile memory for which heavy processing of CRC calculations
        and clearing/programming FLASH memory is required.
function BuildResponseHTTP(NumberOfDataPartsToAcknowledge)
Builds response data to be sent back via the HTTP server as
acknowledge to a module that transmitted data.
Function input:
    - NumberOfDataPartsToAcknowledge: The number of the received
    data parts that you want to acknowledge.
Function result:
    - Binary data to send (back) to the module as response (and
    possibly also request(s) for action(s) if any of the
    CGPS::m... response action members of the class were
    activated.
Notes:
    After inserting the data that a module has sent to the server into
    the class object instance with the CGPS::SetHttpData() function,
    you can use this function to build binary data to send to the
    module to acknowledge the received data.
    If the supplied NumberOfDataPartsToAcknowledge matches the
    number of data parts that were inserted before in the class
    (from the last CGPS::SetHttpData() usage), then the returned
    binary data of this function contains a proper acknowledge to
    let the module know that the all data parts from its
    transmission were properly received and stores and that it must
    delete those records from its internal log.
    Otherwise, the module will not be requested to remove those records
    from its internal log and will re-transmit the same records again
    later.

    Additional to the binary output mentioned above, this function will
    generate binary data that tells the module to perform the specific
    tasks that you may have set with the CGPS::m... response action
    class members.
    Therefore if you re-use the same object instance it is important
    that you call the CGPS::ClearResponseActionMembers() function
    ( this is automatically done when the object is created like
      $pcGPS=new CGPS(); ).
    And you will want have these class members cleared before inserting
    data in the class with the CGPS::SetHttpData(), because in some
    (very rare) cases the class automatically sets one already
    depending on the inserted data.
function BuildResponseTCP(NumberOfDataPartsToAcknowledge)
Builds response and/or action request data to be sent via an
open TCP socket connection with a module.
Function input:
    - NumberOfDataPartsToAcknowledge: the number of received data
    parts you want to acknowledge, or value 0 if you are not
    acknowledging received data, but only want to upload actions to be
    performed from the CGPS::m... action members that you have set.
Function result:
    - Binary data to send (back) to the module as response and/or
    request for actions.
Notes:
    Since you are likely to use this function for a TCP socket server
    with which you keep socket connections open, you are also
    likely to re-use the same CGPS class object too.
    Remember to use CGPS::ClearResponseActionMembers()
    before you put received module data in the class with
    CGPS::SetTcpData() and/or set the CGPS::m... members.

    If you only want to generate data to upload via an open socket
    connection, then simple set CGPS::m... members you like and
    for NumberOfDataPartsToAcknowledge use value 0.

    If you want to after inserting the data that a module has sent to the
    server into the class with the CGPS::SetTcpData() function,
    you will for NumberOfDataPartsToAcknowledge use the number of
    data parts that you have processed from the received data.
    So normally you always use the value that
    CGPS::GetDataPartCount() returns.
function CanGetDigTach1Info()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.

******
****** Background information on Digital Tachograph
******
    A tachograph is a device that monitors a vehicles usage by it's
    driver(s) from speed limits to working/rest hour limits and is
    enforced by the government of many countries.
    Older analog tachographs did that by drawing a graph with ink on
    a spinning paper disk which the driver had to replace and provide
    to the authorities on request.
    A modern digital tachograph records events on the personal digital
    card of the driver (and even the card of the co-driver).
    But a digital tachograph also outputs a continuous stream of data
    which you can feed the module.
    You can actually have the module record all data into it's log and
    from there transfer that to your server.
    But that is an enormous amount of data, so usually you will want to
    have the module only record only a snapshot of the current data
    at events that matter to you.
    You can even have the module monitor the data stream and trigger
    events to changes in the information that it decodes from the data.
   
    Connecting the output of a digital tachograph like:
        Actia SmarTach [10400Baud/8N1 Rev8:147]
        Siemens VDO DTCO 1381 [10400Baud/8N1 Rev8:147]
        Stoneridge Electronics Digital Tachograph 5000 [1200Baud/8N1 Rev9:281]

    They provide a TxD output data signal and a ground for that signal.
    Connect those with the help of a cheap and simple SB140A schottky
    diode to a module type with full size I/O connector like this:
      Module pin 6 -------a--|>][--c------- Tachograph TxD data output
      Module pin 3/9/14 ------------------- Tachograph data ground
    Make very sure you do not exchange the anode/cathode of the
    diode, the side marked with the painted band connects to the
    tachograph and NOT to the connector pin of the module.
    The data ground of the tachograph directly connects to any of the
    I/O ground pins of the module.
   
    In the module settings, set SETTING_ModulePortMode1 to
    MPM_DigitalTachograph (or via settings application section
    59, set port 1 mode to driver "Digital tachograph").
    Set the baudrate and protocol identical to the output of the
    tachograph that you are using.
    See list above for examples and make sure you are running at least
    a module series and firmware version that supports your tachograph.

    Now you can as action for every EVENT_... event you which have
    ActionID 52/53/54 executed to have the module record SV_DigTach1,
    SV_DigTachVIN, SV_DigTachVRN, SV_DigTachCARD1 or
    SV_DigTachCARD2 records in the log containing information derived
    from the data stream received from the tachograph.

    From information in the data stream itself you can trigger
    actions via events EVENT_DigTachReceivedValidData,
    EVENT_DigTachStatusChanges, EVENT_DigTachWhileIgnitionActive,
    EVENT_SPEED_DigTachAbove, and EVENT_SPEED_DigTachBelow
    (or in settings application section 16).
    Using them for example to log a GPS position, will enable you to
    determine from the CGPS::GetEventID() result of such a position
    record which event occurred (and of course when and where that
    event occurred).
    Even the motion detection of the module can be derived from the
    data stream via SETTING_MovingInputDetection (or in
    section 57 of the settings application).
function GetDigTach1UtcTime()
UTC date/time of the digital tachograph as a timestamp.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Timestamp as floating point value.
        Use PHP functions like date() and gmdate().
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The returned time stamp contains the digital tachograph's time in UTC
    (use CGPS::GetUtcTime() for a timestamp when the data was logged by the module).
function GetDigTach1PositionTime()
UTC date/time with current position adjustment of the digital tachograph as a timestamp.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Timestamp as floating point value.
        Use PHP function like gmdate().
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    The returned time stamp contains the digital tachograph's UTC time
    already adjusted with its internal time difference from UTC for at
    the position where the data was logged.
    (use CGPS::GetUtcTime() for a timestamp when the data was logged).
function GetDigTach1StatusChanges()
Bitmask with status changes since the previous data output of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    Value that consists of the following status bits that are set when
    their corresponding status has changed:
    *** "Digital Tachograph Data Change Event Bit Mask" definitions ***

  • DTDCEBM_Motion// Change between: motion / no motion
  • DTDCEBM_Driver1workstate// Change of Driver1 working state
  • DTDCEBM_Driver2workstate// Change of Driver2 working state
  • DTDCEBM_Overspeed// Over speed change (in)active
  • DTDCEBM_Driver1card// Change of Driver1 card state
  • DTDCEBM_Driver2card// Change of Driver2 card state
  • DTDCEBM_Driver1warning// Change in Driver1 warning messages
  • DTDCEBM_Driver2warning// Change in Driver2 warning messages
  • DTDCEBM_Ignition// Change in Ignition status

Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.

    Usually a digital tachograph outputs lots of status information every second.
    The returned value of this function has bits set for information of which the status
    changed and cleared for those of which the status has not changed.
    If the status bit is set, then that status changed from the previous output of the
    tachograph (not previous log record) compared to the status you logged in the current
    log record that you are examining with this function.

    Therefore the bitmask is particularly useful when you in the settings tell the
    module that you want it to log the current states including this bitmask so you
    can tell from the bitmask which of the included statuses changed.
    Use the CGPSsettings::SetEventDigTachStatusChange() function to have the
    EVENT_DigTachStatusChanges monitor for the changes that you want to be noticed.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print("Tachograph status changes: ");
    if($pcGPS->CanGetDigTach1Info()) //Does current selected record contain this info?
    {
        $StatusBitMask=$pcGPS->GetDigTach1StatusChanges(); //Get bitmask with status changes
        if($StatusBitMask) //Has it a value different than 0?
        {
            //The value is not 0, so one or more bits are set to mark a change
            //of the status of their representative info.
            //This is of course always the case for a record that you specifically
            //logged when a status change is detected.
            //When logged for example via a timer interval, the value will of course usually be 0.
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Motion) print("<BR>Change between: motion / no motion");
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Driver1workstate) print("<BR>Change of Driver1 working state");
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Driver2workstate) print("<BR>Change of Driver2 working state");
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Overspeed) print("<BR>Over speed change (in)active");
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Driver1card) print("<BR>Change of Driver1 card state");
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Driver2card) print("<BR>Change of Driver2 card state");
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Driver1warning) print("<BR>Change in Driver1 warning messages");
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Driver2warning) print("<BR>Change in Driver2 warning messages");
            if($StatusBitMask & DTDCEBM_Ignition) print("<BR>Change in Ignition status");
        } else print("No status change since the previous data output"); //Value was 0, so no status changed
    } else print("Info not available in the currently selected record");
    ?>


function GetDigTach1Workstates()
Work states information of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value with bitmask for work states.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.

Description of the bits:
Bit 7-6: 00=no motion, 01=motion, 10=error, 11=reserved
Bit 5-3: Driver2 -> 000=rest, 001=available, 010=work, 011=drive, 1xx=reserved
Bit 2-0: Driver1 -> 000=rest, 001=available, 010=work, 011=drive, 1xx=reserved
(The example server contains a bits to readable text conversion for this function).
function GetDigTach1Driver1()
Driver 1 information of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value with bitmask for driver 1.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.

Description of the bits:
Bit 7-6: Driver1 overspeed; 00=no overspeed, 01=overspeed, 10=error, 11=reserved
Bit 5-4: Driver1 Card; 00=no card, 01=card present, 10=card malfunction, 11=reserved
Bit 3-0: Driver1 time related states;
    0000=no warning = 0 up to 4.25hours
    0001=warning1 = 4.25 up to 4.5hours
    0010=warning2 = 4.5 up to 8.75hours
    0011=warning3 = 8.75 up to 9hours
    0100=warning4 = 9 up to 15,75hours
    0101=warning5 = 15.75 up to 16hours
    others=reserved
(The example server contains a bits to readable text conversion for this function).
function GetDigTach1Driver2()
Driver 2 information of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value with bitmask for driver 2.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.

Description of the bits:
Bit 7-6: Reserved
Bit 5-4: Driver2 Card; 00=no card, 01=card present, 10=card malfunction, 11=reserved
Bit 3-0: Driver2 time related states;
    0000=no warning = 0 up to 4.25hours
    0001=warning1 = 4.25 up to 4.5hours
    0010=warning2 = 4.5 up to 8.75hours
    0011=warning3 = 8.75 up to 9hours
    0100=warning4 = 9 up to 15,75hours
    0101=warning5 = 15.75 up to 16hours
    others=reserved
(The example server contains a bits to readable text conversion for this function).
function GetDigTach1SpeedKPH()
Speed in kilometers per hour of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Speed value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.
function GetDigTach1TravelledMeters()
Travelled meters of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Travelled meters as a floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::GetCounterTravelledMeters().
function GetDigTach1TripMeters()
Trip meters of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Trip meters as a floating point value.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters().
function GetDigTach1Info1()
Information 1 of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value with bitmask for info 1.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTach1Info() function returns a boolean TRUE.

Description of the bits:
Bit 7-6: 00=printer door open or no paper, 01=printer door closed and paper present, 10=error, 11=reserved.
Bit 5-4: 00=no ignition, 01=ignition, 10=error, 11=reserved.
Bit 3-2: 00=D2off, 01=D2on, 10=error, 11=reserved.
Bit 1-0: 00=D1off, 01=D1on, 10=error, 11=reserved.
(The example server contains a bits to readable text conversion for this function).
function CanGetDigTachData()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetDigTachDataSize()
Size in bytes of the data of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value of size in bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTachData() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::GetDigTachDataBytes()
function GetDigTachDataBytes()
The data bytes of the digital tachograph.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Binary bytes.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetDigTachData() function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See also CGPS::GetDigTachDataSize()
function CanGetFuel()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetFuel()
Fuel level.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Value ranging from 0 up to 100 for 0% up to 100%,
        or value 255 for unknown fuel level.
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetFuel()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.

    If GLST_PositionTravelledMetersFuel is selected in the
    settings for SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType to have the module
    include a fuel level when logging position records while no hardware
    or source is available to derive a fuel level from, then the module
    will record unknown fuel level value 255.

    The fuel level comes from an external sensor of which which in
    the reading is available via CAN-bus which directly or via ODB-II
    can be read with an on-board can bus controller or since Rev9:482
    even from the output of an external Squarell device via the
    MPM_Squarell driver.
   
******
****** Background information on CAN-bus
******
    CAN (controller area network) is data communication network.
    Like your computer connected to others via network cables, over the
    CAN-bus many micro controllers and devices communicate with each
    other in vehicles.
    Even though the electrical method of data communication over the
    network is standardized, the data being communicated is not.
    So just like applications on your computer can communicate over the
    network with another application but only those that speak the same
    (data) language.
    For CAN-bus, those applications can be just about everything, from
    the computer controlling the engine to the meters on the dashboard
    and from electrically adjustable mirrors to seats in the vehicle.
    Unfortunately, just about every vehicle manufacturer has invented
    their data addresses and meaning and can even be different per
    vehicle model.
    Therefore you require the specific documentation from the
    manufacturer of the vehicle brand/model describing the addresses of
    the available data, the number of bytes for each address and the
    format and meaning of the data bytes.
    The ODB-II standard was defined to have at least an additional
    basic set of commands and responses available over the CAN-bus
    which should be available in any modern vehicle.
    For more info see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAN_bus

    To use CAN-bus data with or via the modules to your server, you need
    a connector that matches the CAN-bus connector in your specific
    vehicle brand/model via which the signals go to a CAN-bus controller
    interface that is connected to the module.
    For the CAN-bus controller interface you have two options:
    - Built-in CAN-bus controller interface in the module itself
        depending on the type you ordered (you can check this
        with the "hardware" button in the settings application,
        the description of the connector pins of the built-in CAN-bus
        controller is in the product summary/data-sheet of the module).
        To make use of it, set SETTING_CanBusInterface to Built-in
        controller interface and SETTING_CanBusSpeed to the
        actual speed at which the CAN-bus in your specific vehicle
        brand/model outputs the data (or via settings application
        section 61).
        If you want to select the driver that only reads from the
        CAN-bus or the one that can also write over it is up to you.
        The latter one is potentially dangerous because with that you
        can actually insert data on the bus in between all data that
        all other devices already transmit over it.
        Since everything on the CAN-bus has to wait for each other to
        transmit something over the bus, as a precaution the built-in
        CAN-bus controller will intentionally limit all outgoing
        commands you generate to a maximum of 20 commands per second.
        You will need the driver that also transmits data when you
        want to send ODB-II commands to request info you are after.
        Executing ActionID 141 for example you will generate 255
        transmissions for requesting ODB-II PIDs 0 up to 254.
        So logically that back-ground process will take at least
        255/20=12.77 seconds to finish plus some unknown waiting time
        per command waiting for an empty space on the CAN-bus to push
        the data for the command into.
        Even if you would ActionID 141 every second, you will still be
        protected from transmitting more than 20 commands per second
        over the CAN-bus.
    - An external 3th party CAN-bus interface with serial output.
        You connect the serial output port of the external interface
        to serial input port 3 of the module, logically wiring both
        together at the same RS232 or 3V voltage communication levels
        of which the connector pins can be found in the product
        summary/data-sheets).
        You also have to set the serial port 3 driver mode, protocol
        and baud rate with SETTING_ModulePortMode3,
        SETTING_ModulePortProtocol3 and SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate3
        (or via settings application section 59).
        Logically the protocol and baud rate identical to the port
        of the interface that you are using.
        The port mode driver can be set to:
        - CAN-bus interface (MPM_CanBus)
            For this driver you also set the SETTING_CanBusInterface
            (or via section 61 of the settings application) to one of
            the supported external interfaces, to have the module
            itself already extract information from the output of
            that specific interface.
        - Serial input/output (MPM_SerialInOut)
            This driver automatically records all data it receives
            via the serial port as SV_Port4Data records for your
            server and if you want even send data from there via
            CGPS::mSerialPort3.
        - Serial output (MPM_SerialOut)
            This driver does not record data to the server, but
            keeps the last received data in a buffer of which you can
            read the contents via system variable %S71 in your own
            LCD/source-code to parse as you please (TIP: you could
            use instruction slots set to Type 33/36/37/38/39).

    Using the built-in CAN-bus controller interface as described above,
    the last received CAN-bus data is automatically cached.
    The cache has room for 63 unique entries of which newer receptions
    the same type will automatically overwrite each other.
    For each new unique data received not already in the cache a new
    entry is added, unless none is free anymore in which case a single
    fixed 64th storage in the cache is always overwritten.
    Executing ActionID 75 will make the module record all used entries
    in the cache into the log as SV_Port4Data records and then clears
    all entries in the cache.
    And on your server you retrieve the ODB-II data from the records
    with CGPS::GetPortDataBytes().
    Description of the ODB-II response data is on the internet like
    http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OBD-II_PIDs
    But you can also extract information from the cache in the module
    itself from your LCD/Source-code using template markers like
    %I<xxxxxxxx> and %I<xxxxxxxx>.
    http://qontrol-vision.com/cgpsModuleCommands.html#template
    So you can for example make decisions for actions on the module
    side and even transmit self defined commands over the CAN-bus
    using a module command like "CANT".
    http://qontrol-vision.com/cgpsModuleCommands.html#CANT

    With ODB-II usage, User Counter 37 (see CGPS::GetUserCounter())
    gets updated with the distance in meters based on the CAN-bus
    vehicle speed.
function CanGetUserCounter()
Test for Valid_Switch_Marker and returns boolean TRUE or FALSE
depending on availability of this information in the currently
selected module record in the CGPS class.
function GetUserCounter(CounterNumber)
User counters that can count whatever you make them count
Function input:
    - CounterNumber: The number value of the counter from which you
        want to retrieve the value from the current record of which
        the following counters can be retrieved:
        -1: "Block offset" of the record (see notes for detailed info).
        0: Reading of the first 32bit counter in the record.
        1: Reading of the second 32bit counter in the record.
        2: Reading of the third 32bit counter in the record.
        3: Reading of the fourth 32bit counter in the record.
        4: Reading of the fifth 32bit counter in the record.
Function result:
    - The value of the requested counter (see notes for detailed info).
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetUserCounter()
    function returns a boolean TRUE.
    See CGPS::CanGetCounters() for background information on how the
    values of the user counters are backed up into non volatile memory.

    With this function you can retrieve the user counter readings that
    you have recorded in the log as SV_CountersUser records by
    executing ActionID 76.
    You can control the contents of the user counters via module
    commands INCR and USET (e.g. from your own LCD/source-code).
    There are more user counters than can be fitted into a single
    record in the log.
    Therefore the "Block offset" of such records contains the offset
    to the set of the total available amount of user counters that was
    logged in the record.
    If for example the "Block offset" value of the record is 0, then
    readings of counters 0,1,2,3,4 in the record contain the readings
    of user counters 0,1,2,3,4 of the total set of user counters.
    If for example the "Block offset" value of the record is 5, then
    readings of counters 0,1,2,3,4 in the record contain the readings
    of user counters 5,6,7,8,9 of the total set of user counters.

    The following user counters are already used by the firmware:
    - 19: Since Rev8:190 this counter is incremented at each high flank
        measured by connector pin 10 (RXD1_3V).
        (more detailed info on counting pulses is described in the
        documentation for CGPS::GetCounterPulsesInput1()).
    - 37: Since Rev9:393 this counter is filled with the distance in
        meters, based on the CAN-bus vehicle speed info.

Usage example:


    <?php
    if($pcGPS->CanGetUserCounter()) //Does current selected record contain user counter readings?
    {
        //Yes, so lets print the counter readings
        $BlockOffset=$pcGPS->GetUserCounter(-1);
        for($RecordCounter=0;$RecordCounter<5;$RecordCounter++)
            print('User counter #'.($BlockOffset+$RecordCounter).' contains value: '.($pcGPS->GetUserCounter($RecordCounter))."<br>\r\n");
    }
    ?>


function CanGetPowerUpReason()
Function returns boolean true for SV_PowerUp records generated
by a Rev8 hardware module running firmare 185 or generated by
newer hardware/firmware.
function GetPowerUpReason()
Power-up reason for the module after a power-down or reset
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - One of the following values indicating the reason why the module
    was previously powered down or rebooted:

    -4    =>    'Software generated reboot by watchdog; Caused by given command (e.g. issued by your settings/sourcecode/server/SMS or firmware self decided timeout)',
    -3    =>    'Power-up start; Power to the unit previously discontinued without shutdown on request',
    -2    =>    'Reset controller generated restart; Caused by reset controller because internal power supply voltage got below 2.7Volt',
    -1    =>    'Power-on reset; Power to the unit was previously discontinued',
    0    =>    '(Re)start of the module was caused by unknown reason',
    2    =>    'Wake-up restart by vibration sensor (from ActionID 72 initiated power-down mode)',
    3    =>    'Wake-up restart by time-out (from ActionID 72 initiated power-down mode)',
    4    =>    'Wake-up restart by digital input status change (from ActionID 72 initiated power-down mode)',
    5    =>    'Middle/OnOff-button (=Input 5) [Rev8/9 keyfob only]',
    6    =>    'Wake-up restart by change of charger status [Rev8/9]',
    7    =>    'Wake-up restart by change of charger status [Rev8]',
    8    =>    'Right/Star-button change (=Input 2) [Rev9 keyfob only]',
    9    =>    'Left/SOS-button change (=Input1) [Rev9 keyfob only]',
    10    =>    'Change on Rev9 serial input, command mode detect or external digital input [Rev9 keyfob only]',
    11    =>    'By advanced settings "Timeout to reboot if data delayed in seconds"',
    12    =>    'Input 4 status change [Rev9 only]',
    13    =>    'Firmware update progress timeout',
    14    =>    'Wrong header for firmware upgrade',
    15    =>    'Restart via safety timeout from power-down',
    16    =>    'External power supply voltage raised above power-down level again',
    17    =>    'Internal (battery) power supply raised above power-down level again',
    18    =>    'Safety power-down/reset "Li-ion too low" / "temperature too high"',
    19    =>    '2 minutes timeout for modem "OK" response after "AT" command at startup',
    20    =>    'PCB type changed',
    21    =>    'SKMC changed',
    22    =>    'Reboot from module command SRV<x>',
    23    =>    'Wake-up restart by accel-sensor (from ActionID 72 initiated power-down mode)',
    24    =>    'Wake-up restart by RF Ack (from ActionID 72 initiated power-down mode)',
    25    =>    'Wake-up restart by RF no Ack (from ActionID 72 initiated power-down mode)',
    47    =>    '2 minutes timeout for modem "OK" response after "AT" command at baudrate change',
    247    =>    'Module command REST=3',
    248    =>    'Command mode request detection port 3/4',
    249    =>    'Command mode request detection port 1/2',
    250    =>    'Settings power-down',
    251    =>    'Module command REST=241 or REST=242',
    252    =>    'Module command REST=1',
    253    =>    'ActionID 64',
    254    =>    'Unknown/unexpected reset'
Notes:
    Function result is only valid when the CGPS::CanGetPowerUpReason()
    function returns a boolean TRUE (which it does for SV_PowerUp records).
    This power-up reason value is also available via "System Variable"
    %S98 in your own LCD/Source-code.



|| *** Static conversion functions ***
|| A set of functions that can be useful to convert data into another format.
|| Usage example:

||
||     <?php
    //Select all records in a database that contain a valid GPS position that is inside a given geographical region.
    $MinSwitch=SV_LowestPositionSwitch; $MaxSwitch=SV_HighestPositionSwitch;
    $LatMin=LatitudeFloatToSmall(40.12345); $LatMax=LatitudeFloatToSmall(40.54321);
    $LonMin=LongitudeFloatToSmall(80.12345); $LonMax=LongitudeFloatToSmall(80.54321);
    $SQLquery="SELECT * FROM DataBaseTable WHERE Switch>=$MinSwitch && Switch<=$MaxSwitch && Latitude>=$LatMin && Latitude<=$LatMax && Longitude>=$LonMin && Longitude<=$LonMin";
Public static class CGPShelper functions
    ?>
||
||

====
function LatitudeSmallToFloat(LatitudeSmall)
Convert a compact format latitude to floating point format.
Function input:
    - LatitudeSmall: Compact format latitude coordinate.
        (the compact format is a 32 bit unsigned value passed as a float to
        not become and integer with a negative value)
Function result:
    - Floating point coordinate.
Notes:
    Using small format in your database costs less data storage and less
    processor time to find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLatitudeSmall()
function LatitudeFloatToSmall(LatitudeFloat)
Convert a floating point format latitude into a compact format.
Function input:
    - LatitudeFloat: Floating point latitude coordinate.
Function result:
    - Compact format coordinate.
        (the compact format is a 32 bit unsigned value passed as a float to
        not become and integer with a negative value)
Notes:
    Using small format in your database costs less data storage and less
    processor time to find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLatitudeSmall()
function LatitudeSmallToDegrees(LatitudeSmall, &rDegrees, &rMinutes, &rSeconds, &rNS, &rfDecimals)
Convert a compact format latitude to Degrees, Minutes, Seconds and N(orth)/S(outh).
Function input:
    - LatitudeSmall: The compact form latitude to convert (see CGPS::GetLatitudeSmall()).
        (the compact format is a 32 bit unsigned value passed as a float to
        not become and integer with a negative value)
    - rDegrees: Reference to a variable that will receive the degrees as integer value.
    - rMinutes: Reference to a variable that will receive the minutes as integer value.
    - rSeconds: Reference to a variable that will receive the seconds as integer value.
    - rNS:    Reference to a variable that will receive the letter 'N' or 'S' as a string.
    - rfDecimals: Reference to a variable that will receive the minute decimals as floating point value.
Function result:
    - None. All results are directly stored into the variables.
Notes:
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLatitudeSmall().
function LongitudeSmallToFloat(LongitudeSmall)
Convert a compact format longitude to floating point format.
Function input:
    - LongitudeSmall: Compact longitude coordinate.
        (the compact format is a 32 bit unsigned value passed as a float to
        not become and integer with a negative value)
Function result:
    - Floating point coordinate.
Notes:
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLongitudeSmall()
function LongitudeFloatToSmall(LongitudeFloat)
Convert a floating point format longitude into a compact format.
Function input:
    - LongitudeFloat: Floating point latitude coordinate.
        (the compact format is a 32 bit unsigned value passed as a float to
        not become and integer with a negative value)
Function result:
    - Compact format coordinate.
Notes:
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLongitudeSmall()
function LongitudeSmallToDegrees(LongitudeSmall, &rDegrees, &rMinutes, &rSeconds, &rEW, &rfDecimals)
Convert a compact format longitude to Degrees, Minutes, Seconds and N(orth)/S(outh).
Function input:
    - LongitudeSmall: The compact form longitude to convert (see CGPS::GetLongitudeSmall()).
        (the compact format is a 32 bit unsigned value passed as a float to
        not become and integer with a negative value)
    - rDegrees: Reference to a variable that will receive the degrees as integer value.
    - rMinutes: Reference to a variable that will receive the minutes as integer value.
    - rSeconds: Reference to a variable that will receive the seconds as integer value.
    - rEW:    Reference to a variable that will receive the letter 'E' or 'W' as a string.
    - rfDecimals: Reference to a variable that will receive the minute decimals as floating point value.
Function result:
    - None. All results are directly stored into the variables.
Notes:
    Small format costs less data storage and less processor time to find back in your storage without loosing accuracy.
    See CGPS::GetLongitudeSmall()
function DecompressImei(CompressedIMEI)
Decompress IMEI (International Mobile Equipment Identification).
Function input:
    - CompressedIMEI: A text string with the compressed IMEI number.
Function result:
    - A text string with the decompressed IMEI number.
Notes:
    If the supplied compressed IMEI can not be decompressed, it will be
    returned as it is supplied.
    See also function CompressImei()
    See function CGPS::GetImei() for additional info.
function CompressImei(IMEI)
Compress IMEI (International Mobile Equipment Identification).
Function input:
    - IMEI : A text string with the IMEI number.
Function result:
    - A text string with the compressed IMEI number.
Notes:
    If the supplied IMEI is invalid, it will be returned as it is supplied.
    See also function DecompressImei()
    See also CGPS::GetImei() for additional info.
function CheckImeiCrc(IMEI)
Check IMEI (International Mobile Equipment Identification).
Function input:
    - IMEI : A text string with the IMEI number.
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE or FALSE
Notes:
    The last (15th) digit of an IMEI number is a simple CRC of the other
    digits.
    With this function you can check if a supplied IMEI string consists
    out of exactly 15 numerical digits and that a CRC check on those turns
    out to be correct.
    This function is for example useful to verify an IMEI number entry that
    you have a user enter manually.
    But remember that because of the simple CRC used in an IMEI only
    consists of one digit with 10 possible combinations, the verification
    strength is also one out of 10.
    See also function DecompressImei()
    See also CGPS::GetImei() for additional info.



|| ////////////Definitions for the CGPSsettings class
====



|| ########################################################################
|| ########################################################################
|| ########################################################################
|| ########################### CGPSsettings class functions and definitions
|| ########################################################################
|| ########################################################################
|| ########################################################################
|| Class for creating/modifying module settings data.
|| This class is compatible with settings data that is created with the settings application v1.0.0.38 or later.
|| Usage example:

||
||     <?php
    require('cgps.php'); //Include CGPS classes to your program.
    $pcGPSsettings=new CGPSsettings(); //Create instance object of the class
    //New settings can be created in the class or you can set it with existing settings data like received
    //from a module via SV_SettingsData, something you previously stored from the SetSettingsData() function of the class.
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSettingsData(file_get_contents('SettingsFile.tms'))) //Feed existing settings data to the class (in this example from a disk file)
    {
        //The class accepted the given settings data, let's display the current CRC of the settings data.
        print("The CRC value of settings data that was read is: ".$pcGPSsettings->GetSettingsCRC()."<br>");

        //Now you can for example use the Get...() functions to checkout all individual settings
        $Setting=0; //Create a variable to receive the current event setting into
        print('The "When speed becomes above" event speed condition is currently set to: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventSpeed(EVENT_SPEED_Above, $Setting)) //Read the event condition into the variable
        {
            if($Setting==0) print('Event condition is disabled<BR>');
            else print("$Setting kilometer per hour<BR>");
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
        print("The 'Log GPS data' action for this event in the settings is: ");
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_SPEED_Above, ACTION_GpsLog, $Setting)) //Read the event action setting into the variable
        {
            if($Setting) print("ACTIVATED<BR>\r\n"); //Setting is boolean TRUE
            else print("DEACTIVATED<BR>\r\n"); //Setting is boolean FALSE
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');

        //Changing settings can be done with the Set...() functions
        print('Setting the "When speed becomes above" event speed condition to 130 kilometer per hour: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventSpeed(EVENT_SPEED_Above, 130)) //Change the event condition to 130 kilometers per hour
            print('OK<BR>');
        else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
        print("Activating the 'Log GPS info' action of this event: ");
        if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_SPEED_Above, ACTION_GpsLog, TRUE)) //Enable "Log GPS info" action for this event
            print("OK<BR>\r\n");
        else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');

        //Let's display the current CRC of the settings data, which after making changes will of course be different.
        print("The CRC value of the settings data is now: ".$pcGPSsettings->GetSettingsCRC()."<br>");

        //Current settings in the class can be build into settings data
        $SettingsData=$pcGPSsettings->GetSettingsData(); //Let class build settings data and put it into the $SettingsData variable
        //You can for example write this data into a settings file on disk
        //or upload it to the module from your server via the mSettings
        //action response member of the CGPS class.
    } else print("ERROR: ".htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError())."<BR>"); //Settings data was rejected. In that case, the reason can be retrieved with the GetLastError() function.
    ?>
||
||

====
function CGPSsettings()
Class constructor.
Notes:
    Function is automatically executed when a new instance of the class is created.
    This function automatically calls the CGPSsettings::ClearSettings() function.
function ClearSettings()
Clear all settings in the class.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - None
Note:
    After using this function, the class will contain settings data
    in which everything is disabled and all settings are cleared.
    This is also the default contents when you create a new instance
    object of the class.
    But you will likely want to use your own default settings data
    file instead that you have created with the settings application
    and put that in the class via the CGPSsettings::SetSettingsData()
    function.
function GetLastError()
Get the last error that occurred in the class as a text string.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with error message.
Notes:
    - This function is only useful directly after another function
        of the same class returned a failure result and the
        documentation of that says that last error information can be
        retrieved with this function.
    - When using the resulting text string in HTML/XML output, it is
        recommended to use a HTML/XML safe conversion function of the
        programming language that you are using like htmlspecialchars().
function GetSettingsCRC()
"Cyclic Redundancy Check" value of current settings data in the class.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - 16 bit CRC value.
Note:
    The CRC value of the settings data that is used by the module is encoded
    in some of the Switch Values that are logged.
    For these logs, the CGPS::CanGetSettingsCrc() returns a boolean TRUE
    (e.g. SV_PowerUp / SV_SettingsAccepted / SV_Network) and the CRC can be
    extracted with CGPS::GetSettingsCrc().
    If the returned CRC value is not identical to the value returned by the
    CGPSsettings::GetSettingsCRC() function, then you are sure that the module
    is NOT using that same settings data.
function GetSettingsData()
Retrieve all settings in the class combined as settings data.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Settings data that can be sent to a module via the CGPS::mSettings action response member, or saved to a file.
function SetSettingsData(SettingsData)
Overwrite all settings in the class with a settings data file.
Function input:
    Existing settings data e.g.:
    - Created with the CGPSsettings::GetSettingsData() function.
    - Written to a file with the settings application.
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE if the settings data is accepted.
    - Boolean FALSE if the settings data is not accepted (use CGPSsettings::GetLastError() for an error description).
function GetEventAction(Event, Action, &rSetting, Get=true)
Use this function to retrieve the current action setting for an event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: The 'EVENT_...' definition of the event for which the
        action setting is to be retrieved.
    - Action: The 'ACTION_...' definition of the action setting that
        is to be retrieved.
    - rSetting: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        current action setting. See 'ACTION_...' definition for
        details.
    - Get: If not omitted and is boolean FALSE, then the action setting
        in the rSetting variable will be used to overwrite the current
        action setting instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
WARNING:
    Specifically for "while..." condition type events (like for example
    EVENT_WhileMoving, EVENT_WhileRoaming,
    EVENT_VOLTAGE_Below, etc... up to even
    EVENT_ReceivedGpsFix) you will want to be cautious
    setting certain actions.
    That is because such events trigger continuously while the condition
    that you have set for it is met and thus at such times also execute
    the actions you have set for that event continuously.
    So for those events you likely would not want to set actions that
    do things like generate data or send things like SMS text messages
    because of course then that is what will happen continuously while
    the event triggers to the condition you have set.
    For such events, especially an action like ACTION_ResetTimer1
    and/or other timers, are particulary useful to effectively prohibit
    the event for the timer to not reach the trigger condition while the
    condition for your "While..." type event is met.
    Think for example of constructions like not generating data or doing
    things by a frequent timer event while you are roaming on another
    (usually expensive) GSM network or while the battery is low, etc...
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Setting=0; //Variable we will use to receive individual action settings below.
    print('*** Info about some of the actions of the "Start moving" event in the current settings<br>');
    print('- "Log GPS" action is set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_GpsLog, $Setting))
        print($Setting ? 'Yes<BR>' : 'No<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('"Photo" action is set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_Photo, $Setting)) //Read setting into the variable
    {
        if($Setting==RACD_Photo_No) print('Do not take a picture<br>');
        else if($Setting==RACD_Photo_LoRes) print('Take a low resolution picture<br>');
        else if($Setting==RACD_Photo_HiRes) print('Take a high resolution picture<br>');
        else print('An undefined action<br>');
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- "Log counters" action is set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_CountersLog, $Setting))
        print($Setting ? 'Yes<BR>' : 'No<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('"Transmit log" action is set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_TransmitLog, $Setting))
        print($Setting ? 'Yes<BR>' : 'No<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- "Reset timer 1" action is set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_ResetTimer1, $Setting))
        print($Setting ? 'Yes<BR>' : 'No<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- The event is set to perform: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts, $Setting))
    {
        if($Setting)
        {
            print('ActionID (instead of "SMS-alerts") and is set to: ');
            if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_ActionID, $Setting))
                print("$Setting<br>");
            else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
        }
        else
        {
            print('"SMS-alerts" (instead of ActionID) and is set to:<BR>');
            print('- Send Alert-SMS to "Alert-SMS phone number 1" is set to: ');
            if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_SmsAlert1, $Setting))
                print($Setting ? 'Yes<BR>' : 'No<BR>');
            else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
            //Possibly do the same for ACTION_SmsAlert2 and ACTION_SmsAlert3 as above too.
            print('- Send Alert-SMS to "Called by phone number 1" is set to: ');
            if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1, $Setting))
                print($Setting ? 'Yes<BR>' : 'No<BR>');
            else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
            //Possibly do the same for ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown2 and ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown3 as above too.
        }
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- Digital output 1 action is set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_Output1, $Setting))
    {
        if($Setting==RACD_DigitalOutput_NoChange) print('Do not change digital output state<br>');
        else if($Setting==RACD_DigitalOutput_Enable) print('Activate digital output<br>');
        else if($Setting==RACD_DigitalOutput_Disable) print('Deactivate digital output<br>');
        else if($Setting==RACD_DigitalOutput_Toggle) print('Toggle digital output from disabled to enabled or vice versa<br>');
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventAction(Event, Action, Setting)
Use this function to change the current action setting for an event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: The 'EVENT_...' definition of the event for which the
        action setting is to be changed.
    - Action: The 'ACTION_...' definition of the action setting of
        the event that is to be changed.
    - Setting: The new setting that is to be used. See documentation
        of the used 'ACTION_...' for details.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
WARNING:
    Specifically for "while..." condition type events (like for example
    EVENT_WhileMoving, EVENT_WhileRoaming,
    EVENT_VOLTAGE_Below, etc... up to even
    EVENT_ReceivedGpsFix) you will want to be cautious
    setting certain actions.
    That is because such events trigger continuously while the condition
    that you have set for it is met and thus at such times also execute
    the actions you have set for that event continuously.
    So for those events you likely would not want to set actions that
    do things like generate data or send things like SMS text messages
    because of course then that is what will happen continuously while
    the event triggers to the condition you have set.
    For such events, especially an action like ACTION_ResetTimer1
    and/or other timers, are particulary useful to effectively prohibit
    the event for the timer to not reach the trigger condition while the
    condition for your "While..." type event is met.
    Think for example of constructions like not generating data or doing
    things by a frequent timer event while you are roaming on another
    (usually expensive) GSM network or while the battery is low, etc...
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('*** Setting/changing some actions to be performed when the "Start moving" triggers<br>');
    print('- Activating "Log GPS" action: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_GpsLog, true))
        print('Success<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- Activating "High resolution picture" action: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_Photo, RACD_Photo_HiRes))
        print('Success<br>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- Activating "Log counters" action: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_CountersLog, true))
        print('Success<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- Activating "Transmit log" action: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_TransmitLog, true))
        print('Success<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- Activating "Reset timer 1" action: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_ResetTimer1, true))
        print('Success<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    //Warning: You can use Alert-SMS actions *OR* set an ActionID (you have to switch between the two).
    //*AND* have to set all 6 individual Alert-SMS actions when switching ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts from true to false.
    print('- Activating "Send Alert-SMS to phone number 1..3" and "Send Alert-SMS to Called by known phone number 1..3" actions: ');
    if(    $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts, false)
        && $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_SmsAlert1, true)
        && $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_SmsAlert2, true)
        && $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_SmsAlert3, true)
        && $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1, true)
        && $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown2, true)
        && $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown3, true)
        ) print('Success<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    //Warning: Setting an ActionID for an event, will automatically disable all it's existing Alert-SMS actions.
    //So the next change to the settings will actually disable all the Alert-SMS settings that were set above again.
    print('- Activating "ActionID 13" action: ');
    if(    $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts, true)
        && $pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_ActionID, 13) //Using value 0 would disable both the ActionID and all Alert-SMS actions.
        ) print("Success<br>"); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('- Setting "Digital output 1 state to: toggle" action: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_StartMoving, ACTION_Output1, RACD_DigitalOutput_Toggle))
        print("Success<br>"); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventActionRegion(Region, Event, Action, &rSetting, Get=true)
Read the current action settings of region events.
Function arguments:
    - Region: The number of the region of 1 up-to 50.
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        action setting is to be retrieved:

  • REGION_EVENT_Entering// Event that triggers once when the region is entered
  • REGION_EVENT_Inside// Event that triggers every second while being inside the region
  • REGION_EVENT_Leaving// Event that triggers once when the region is left
  • REGION_EVENT_Outside// Event that triggers every second while being outside the region

    - Action: The 'ACTION_...' definition of the action setting
        that is to be retrieved.
    - rSetting: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        current action setting. See 'ACTION_...' definition
        for details.
    - Get: If not omitted and is boolean FALSE, then the action
        setting in the rSetting variable will be used to overwrite
        the current action setting instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    See CGPSsettings::SetEventRegion() function documentation for
    background information about regions in general.
    Since only the first two argument parameters of this function
    differ from CGPSsettings::GetEventAction(), you will want to have
    a look at the more extensive example code there too.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Setting=0; //Create a variable that will receive the setting
    print('The "Log GPS info" action for the "Entering region #1" event is set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventActionRegion(1, REGION_EVENT_Entering, ACTION_GpsLog, $Setting)) //Read the setting into the variable
        print($Setting ? 'Yes<BR>' : 'No<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventActionRegion(Region, Event, Action, Setting)
Change action settings of region events.
Function arguments:
    - Region: The number of the region (1 up-to 50).
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the action
        setting is to be written:

  • REGION_EVENT_Entering// Event that triggers once when the region is entered
  • REGION_EVENT_Inside// Event that triggers every second while being inside the region
  • REGION_EVENT_Leaving// Event that triggers once when the region is left
  • REGION_EVENT_Outside// Event that triggers every second while being outside the region

    - Action: The 'ACTION_...' definition of the action setting of the
        event that is to be set.
    - Setting: The new setting that is to be used. See the documentation
        of the used 'ACTION_...' definition for details.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    See CGPSsettings::SetEventRegion() function documentation for
    background information about regions in general.
    Since only the first two argument parameters of this function
    differ from CGPSsettings::SetEventAction(), you will want to have
    a look at the more extensive example code there too.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Activating the "Log GPS info" action for the "When leaving Region #1": ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventActionRegion(1, REGION_EVENT_Leaving, ACTION_GpsLog, true)) //Write boolean TRUE as the new setting to enable
        print('Success'):
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()));
    ?>


function GetEventIO(Event, &rCondition, Get=true)
Retrieve the event condition of a digital input/output port.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        condition setting is to be retrieved:
        *** "Input Output Event" definitions ***

  • EVENT_IO_1A// First event for the digital input/output 1 state (equivalent of 1st event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 1 or a voltage connected to Input 1 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput1 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput1. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_1B// Second event for the digital input/output 1 state (equivalent of 2nd event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 1 or a voltage connected to Input 1 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput1 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput1. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_2A// First event for the digital input/output 2 state (equivalent of 3rd event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 2 or a voltage connected to Input 2 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput2 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput2. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_2B// Second event for the digital input/output 2 state (equivalent of 4th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 2 or a voltage connected to Input 2 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput2 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput2. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_3A// First event for the digital input/output 3 state (equivalent of 5th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 3 or a voltage connected to Input 3 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput3 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput3. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
