  • EVENT_IO_3B// Second event for the digital input/output 3 state (equivalent of 6th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 3 or a voltage connected to Input 3 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput3 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput3. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_4A// First event for the digital input/output 4 state (equivalent of 7th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 4 or a voltage connected to Input 4 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput4 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput4. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal I4BST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_4B// Second event for the digital input/output 4 state (equivalent of 8th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 4 or a voltage connected to Input 4 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput4 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput4. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal I4BST_... simulated voltage instead.

    - rCondition: A reference to a variable that will receive one of
        the following condition definitions:
        *** "Input Output Event Status" definitions ***

  • IOES_InputActive// Makes the event trigger every second while its input is connected to a voltage level that is inside digitally active range
  • IOES_InputInactive// Makes the event trigger every second while its input is connected to a voltage level that is outside digitally active range
  • IOES_InputActivated// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches becomes inside digital active range
  • IOES_InputDeactivated// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches becomes outside digital active range
  • IOES_InputChanged// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches inside/outside digital active/inactive range
  • IOES_InputUnchanged// Makes the event trigger every second while its input is connected to a voltage level that does not change between digitally active/inactive range
  • IOES_OutputActive// Makes the event trigger every second while its output is activated
  • IOES_OutputInactive// Makes the event trigger every second while its output is deactivated
  • IOES_OutputActivated// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches becomes activated
  • IOES_OutputDeactivated// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches becomes deactivated
  • IOES_OutputChanged// Makes the event trigger once every time its output switches between activated/deactivated
  • IOES_OutputUnchanged// Makes the event trigger every second while its output is not switched between activated/deactivated

    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition in the
        rCondition variable will be used to overwrite the current
        condition instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Condition=0; //Create a variable that will be used to receive the current event condition.
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventIO(EVENT_IO_1A, $Condition)) //Use function to read the current condition into the variable
    {
        print('The first event condition for digital input/output port 1 is currently set to: ');
        if($Condition==IOES_InputActive) print('While input is active');
        else if($Condition==IOES_InputInactive) print('While input is not active');
        else if($Condition==IOES_InputActivated) print('When input becomes active');
        else if($Condition==IOES_InputDeactivated) print('When input becomes inactive');
        else if($Condition==IOES_InputChanged) print('When input changes');
        else if($Condition==IOES_InputUnchanged) print('When input has not changed');
        else if($Condition==IOES_OutputActive) print('While output is active');
        else if($Condition==IOES_OutputInactive) print('While output is not active');
        else if($Condition==IOES_OutputActivated) print('When output becomes active');
        else if($Condition==IOES_OutputDeactivated) print('When output becomes inactive');
        else if($Condition==IOES_OutputChanged) print('When output changes');
        else if($Condition==IOES_OutputUnchanged) print('When output has not changed');
        else print("Unknown condition ($Condition)");
    } else print('The following error occurred: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()));
    ?>


function SetEventIO(Event, Condition)
Overwrite the current event condition of a digital input/output port.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions to which the
        condition setting is to be written:
        *** "Input Output Event" definitions ***

  • EVENT_IO_1A// First event for the digital input/output 1 state (equivalent of 1st event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 1 or a voltage connected to Input 1 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput1 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput1. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_1B// Second event for the digital input/output 1 state (equivalent of 2nd event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 1 or a voltage connected to Input 1 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput1 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput1. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_2A// First event for the digital input/output 2 state (equivalent of 3rd event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 2 or a voltage connected to Input 2 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput2 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput2. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_2B// Second event for the digital input/output 2 state (equivalent of 4th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 2 or a voltage connected to Input 2 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput2 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput2. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_3A// First event for the digital input/output 3 state (equivalent of 5th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 3 or a voltage connected to Input 3 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput3 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput3. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_3B// Second event for the digital input/output 3 state (equivalent of 6th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 3 or a voltage connected to Input 3 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput3 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput3. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_4A// First event for the digital input/output 4 state (equivalent of 7th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 4 or a voltage connected to Input 4 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput4 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput4. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal I4BST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_4B// Second event for the digital input/output 4 state (equivalent of 8th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 4 or a voltage connected to Input 4 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput4 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput4. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal I4BST_... simulated voltage instead.

    - Condition: One of the following condition definitions:
        *** "Input Output Event Status" definitions ***

  • IOES_InputActive// Makes the event trigger every second while its input is connected to a voltage level that is inside digitally active range
  • IOES_InputInactive// Makes the event trigger every second while its input is connected to a voltage level that is outside digitally active range
  • IOES_InputActivated// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches becomes inside digital active range
  • IOES_InputDeactivated// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches becomes outside digital active range
  • IOES_InputChanged// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches inside/outside digital active/inactive range
  • IOES_InputUnchanged// Makes the event trigger every second while its input is connected to a voltage level that does not change between digitally active/inactive range
  • IOES_OutputActive// Makes the event trigger every second while its output is activated
  • IOES_OutputInactive// Makes the event trigger every second while its output is deactivated
  • IOES_OutputActivated// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches becomes activated
  • IOES_OutputDeactivated// Makes the event trigger once every time the voltage connected to its input switches becomes deactivated
  • IOES_OutputChanged// Makes the event trigger once every time its output switches between activated/deactivated
  • IOES_OutputUnchanged// Makes the event trigger every second while its output is not switched between activated/deactivated

Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Usage example:


    <?php
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventIO(EVENT_IO_1A, IOES_InputActivated)) //Set first event condition
        print('The first event condition for digital input/output port 1 is now set to: When digital input becomes active');
    else print('The following error occurred: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()));
    ?>


function GetEventTimers(Event, &rMovingInterval, &rNotMovingInterval, Get=true)
Retrieve the conditions of a timer interval event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        interval condition settings are to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_TIMERS_1// Timer/Counter 1 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_2// Timer/Counter 2 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_3// Timer/Counter 3 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_4// Timer/Counter 4 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_5// Timer/Counter 5 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_6// Timer/Counter 6 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_7// Timer/Counter 7 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_8// Timer/Counter 8 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.

    - rMovingInterval: A reference to a variable that will receive
        timer interval condition for the module's "moving" state.
    - rNotMovingInterval: A reference to a variable that will receive
        timer interval condition for the module's "not moving" state.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the conditions in the
        rMovingTimer and rNotMovingTimer variables will be used to
        overwrite the current conditions instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - A timer is reset when the module starts/resets and when it reaches
        the given condition count the event triggers and then by default
        it also resets itself automatically start couning again unless
        disabled with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer.
    - A timer counts up to the given interval value in number of
        seconds or "becomes digitally active" state pulses depending
        on the bitmask setting of CGPSsettings::GetTimerPulseCount()
        and CGPSsettings::GetTimerPulseCount().
    - A timer interval value of 0 means that the timer won't trigger
        and thus the timer event is disabled.
    - Depending on the "moving mode" status, the timer automatically
        uses the "moving" or "not moving" interval condition you
        programmed. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background
        information on motion detection to control the moving mode
        state.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $SingleTriggerBitmask=$CountPulsesBitmask=$MovingCount=$NotMovingCount=0; //Variables to receive the current bitmask and timer event condition settings
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer, $SingleTriggerBitmask))
    {
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetTimerPulseCount($Bitmask))
        {
            if($SingleTriggerBitmask&1) print('Timer 1 is set to trigger only once<BR>');
            else print('Timer 1 is set to trigger continuously<BR>');
            if($CountPulsesBitmask&16) print('Timer 1 is set to count "becomes active pulses" of digital input port 1:');
            else print('Timer 1 is set to count seconds:');
            if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventTimers(EVENT_TIMERS_1, $Moving, $NotMoving)) //Read the event conditions into the variables
            {
                print('<BR> - Module "moving" state: ');
                if($Moving==0) print('Disabled'); else print($Moving);
                print('<BR> - Module "not moving" state: ');
                if(!$NotMoving==0) print('Disabled<BR>'); else print($NotMoving);
            } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
           
            if($SingleTriggerBitmask&2) print('Timer 2 is set to trigger only once<BR>');
            else print('Timer 2 is set to trigger continuously<BR>');
            if($CountPulsesBitmask&32) print('<BR>Timer 2 is set to count "becomes active pulses" of digital input port 2:');
            else print('<BR>Timer 2 is set to count seconds:');
            if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventTimers(EVENT_TIMERS_2, $Moving, $NotMoving)) //Read the event conditions into the variables
            {
                print('<BR> - Module "moving" state: ');
                if($Moving==0) print('Disabled'); else print($Moving);
                print('<BR> - Module "not moving" state: ');
                if(!$NotMoving==0) print('Disabled<BR>'); else print($NotMoving);
            } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
        } else print('ERROR reading bitmask: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    } else print('ERROR reading single trigger bitmask: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventTimers(Event, MovingInterval, NotMovingInterval)
Overwrite the conditions of a timer interval event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        interval condition settings are to be written:

  • EVENT_TIMERS_1// Timer/Counter 1 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_2// Timer/Counter 2 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_3// Timer/Counter 3 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_4// Timer/Counter 4 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_5// Timer/Counter 5 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_6// Timer/Counter 6 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_7// Timer/Counter 7 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_8// Timer/Counter 8 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.

    - MovingInterval: The interval value in seconds or pulses for
        the "moving" state event condition.
    - NotMovingTimer: The interval value in seconds or pulses for
        the "not moving" state event condition.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - A timer is reset when the module starts/resets and when it reaches
        the given condition count the event triggers and then by default
        it also resets itself automatically start couning again unless
        disabled with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer.
    - A timer counts up to the given interval value in number of
        seconds or "becomes digitally active" state pulses depending
        on the bitmask setting of CGPSsettings::GetTimerPulseCount()
        and CGPSsettings::GetTimerPulseCount().
    - A timer interval value of 0 means that the timer won't trigger
        and thus the timer event is disabled.
    - Depending on the "moving mode" status, the timer automatically
        uses the "moving" or "not moving" interval condition you
        programmed. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background
        information on motion detection to control the moving mode
        state.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $SingleTriggerBitmask=$CountPulsesBitmask=0; //Variables to receive the current bitmasks into
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer, $SingleTriggerBitmask))
    {
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetTimerPulseCount($Bitmask))
        {
            print('Example changing Timer 1 and Timer 4 conditions while leaving the other timers unchanged<BR>');
           
            print('Changing Timer 1 to trigger only once and Timer 4 to trigger continuously: ');
            $SingleTriggerBitmask|=1; //Set bit 0 for Timer 1
            $SingleTriggerBitmask&=~8; //Clear bit 3 for Timer 4
            if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer, $SingleTriggerBitmask)) print('OK<BR>');
            else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');

            print('Changing Timer 1 to count seconds and Timer 4 to count "becomes active pulses" of digital input port 4 (while not changing the others): ');
            $CountPulsesBitmask|=1; //Set bit 0 for Timer 1
            $CountPulsesBitmask&~=128; //Clear bit 7 for Timer 4
            if($pcGPSsettings->SetTimerPulseCount($CountPulsesBitmask)) print('OK<BR>');
            else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
           
            print('Changing Timer 1 to count up to 10 pulses while moving mode is active and no counting at all while moving mode is not active: ');
            if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventTimers(EVENT_TIMERS_1, 10, 0)) print('OK<BR>');
            else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
           
            print('Changing Timer 4 to count up to 30 seconds while moving mode is active and up to 5 minutes while moving mode is not active: ');
            if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventTimers(EVENT_TIMERS_1, 30, 5*60)) print('OK<BR>');
            else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
        }
    }
    ?>


function GetEventTime(Event, &rTime, Get=true)
Retrieve the time of day condition of an event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the time
        condition setting is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_TIME_1// Time of day event 1. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTime() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTime() functions.
  • EVENT_TIME_2// Time of day event 2. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTime() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTime() functions.

    - rTime: A reference to a variable that will receive time of day
        condition for the event in UTC.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the conditions in the
        rTime variable will be used to overwrite the current condition
        instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - The UTC time of day in seconds is used by the module without
      future time zone and/or daylight saving adjustments.
    - SETTING_RandomizeTimeOfDayEvents can be used to add some
      time spreading for protecting your server to not have all modules
      transmit to it all at the same time.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Time=0; //Create a variables to receive the current time of day event condition
    print('The "Time of day 1" event condition is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventTime(EVENT_TIME_1, $Time)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        $Hours=$Time/3600; $Time%=3600; $Minutes=$Time/60; $Seconds=$Time%60;
        printf('%d:%02d:%02d UTC<BR>', $Hours, $Minutes, $Seconds);
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventTime(Event, Time)
Overwrite the time of day condition of an event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the time
        condition setting is to be written:

  • EVENT_TIME_1// Time of day event 1. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTime() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTime() functions.
  • EVENT_TIME_2// Time of day event 2. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTime() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTime() functions.

    - Time: The time of day condition for the event in UTC seconds.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - The UTC time of day in seconds is used by the module without
      future time zone and/or daylight saving adjustments.
    - SETTING_RandomizeTimeOfDayEvents can be used to add some
      time spreading for protecting your server to not have all modules
      transmit to it all at the same time.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the "Time of day 1" event to 13:45:30 UTC: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventTime(EVENT_TIME_1, 13*3600+45*60+30)) //Change the event condition
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventTimes(Event, &rTimeStart, &rTimeEnd, Get=true)
Retrieve the start and end time of day condition in UTC of an event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        start/end-time condition settings are to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_TIMES_1// Event that triggers every 2 seconds while between two day times. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTimes() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimes() functions.
  • EVENT_TIMES_2// Event that triggers every 2 seconds while between two day times. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTimes() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimes() functions.

    - rTimeStart: A reference to a variable that will receive the start
      time condition of the event.
    - rTimeEnd: A reference to a variable that will receive the end
      time condition of the event.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the conditions in the
      rTimeStart and rTimeEnd variables will be used to overwrite the
      current conditions instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - The UTC time of day in seconds is used by the module without
      future time zone and/or daylight saving adjustments.
    - Events while between given times are trigger continuously while
      their condition is met, therefore only actions like
      ACTION_ResetTimer... and ACTION_Output...
      are suitable and not actions that result in data generation.
    - SETTING_RandomizeTimeOfDayEvents can be used to add some
      time spreading for protecting your server to not have all modules
      transmit to it all at the same time.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Time=0; //Create a variables to receive the current time of day event condition
    print('The "Between time of day 1" event condition are currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventTimes(EVENT_TIMES_1, $TimeStart, $TimeEnd)) //Read the event conditions into the variables
    {
        $Hours=$TimeStart/3600; $TimeStart%=3600; $Minutes=$TimeStart/60; $Seconds=$TimeStart%60;
        printf('<BR>- Start time: %d:%02d:%02d UTC', $Hours, $Minutes, $Seconds);
        $Hours=$TimeEnd/3600; $TimeEnd%=3600; $Minutes=$TimeEnd/60; $Seconds=$TimeEnd%60;
        printf('<BR>- End time: %d:%02d:%02d UTC<BR>', $Hours, $Minutes, $Seconds);
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventTimes(Event, TimeStart, TimeEnd)
Overwrite the start and end time of day condition in UTC of an event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the start/end-time condition settings are to be written:

  • EVENT_TIMES_1// Event that triggers every 2 seconds while between two day times. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTimes() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimes() functions.
  • EVENT_TIMES_2// Event that triggers every 2 seconds while between two day times. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTimes() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimes() functions.

    - TimeStart: The start time condition for the event.
    - TimeEnd: The end time condition for the event.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - The UTC time of day in seconds is used by the module without
      future time zone and/or daylight saving adjustments.
    - Events while between given times are trigger continuously while
      their condition is met, therefore only actions like
      ACTION_ResetTimer... and ACTION_Output...
      are suitable and not actions that result in data generation.
    - SETTING_RandomizeTimeOfDayEvents can be used to add some
      time spreading for protecting your server to not have all modules
      transmit to it all at the same time.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the "Between Time of day 1" event conditions to start 8:45:30 and end 18:15:00 UTC: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventTimes(EVENT_TIMES_1, 8*3600+45*60+30, 18*3600+15*60+00)) //Change the event conditions
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(Event, &rInterval, Get=true)
Retrieve the interval timer condition of an accident recording event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the interval
        timer condition setting is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_AccidentRecording1// [Rev8/9:296] Event that stores records it generates via actions ACTION_GpsLog and/or ActionID 55...58 into a accident log in RAM instead of into the normal log. For the loggin interval use CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval() and CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(). Then whenever you execute ActionID 107 (like when an accident occurrs), the amount of history records specified by you with SETTING_AccidentRecordingHistoryRecordAmount up to the number of future records you specified with SETTING_AccidentRecordingFutureRecordAmount are copied into the normal log which from there can be transferred to your server or later exported from there via a settings cable. NOTE: If this event is in use on Rev8 series modules, then all photo camera related features will not function anymore.
  • EVENT_AccidentRecording2// [Rev8/9:296] Event that stores records it generates via actions ACTION_GpsLog and/or ActionID 55...58 into a accident log in RAM instead of into the normal log. For the loggin interval use CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval() and CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(). Then whenever you execute ActionID 107 (like when an accident occurrs), the amount of history records specified by you with SETTING_AccidentRecordingHistoryRecordAmount up to the number of future records you specified with SETTING_AccidentRecordingFutureRecordAmount are copied into the normal log which from there can be transferred to your server or later exported from there via a settings cable. NOTE: If this event is in use on Rev8 series modules, then all photo camera related features will not function anymore.

    - rInterval: A reference to a variable that will receive an integer
        value that represents the timer interval in units of 1/256
        seconds.
        If the returned value is 0, the the event is disabled.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the conditions in the
        rTime variable will be used to overwrite the current condition
        instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - See also CGPSsettings::SetEventAccidentRecordingInterval()
Usage example:


    <?php
    $AccidentRecordingInterval=0;
    print('The "Accident recording 1" event interval timer condition is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval($aEvent[0], $AccidentRecordingInterval))
    {
        if($AccidentRecordingInterval==0) print('0 (Event condition is disabled)<BR>');
        else printf('%.3f seconds<BR>', $AccidentRecordingInterval*(1/256) );
    } else print('<B>ERROR:</B> '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(Event, Interval)
Overwrite the interval timer condition of an accident recording event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the interval
        timer condition setting is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_AccidentRecording1// [Rev8/9:296] Event that stores records it generates via actions ACTION_GpsLog and/or ActionID 55...58 into a accident log in RAM instead of into the normal log. For the loggin interval use CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval() and CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(). Then whenever you execute ActionID 107 (like when an accident occurrs), the amount of history records specified by you with SETTING_AccidentRecordingHistoryRecordAmount up to the number of future records you specified with SETTING_AccidentRecordingFutureRecordAmount are copied into the normal log which from there can be transferred to your server or later exported from there via a settings cable. NOTE: If this event is in use on Rev8 series modules, then all photo camera related features will not function anymore.
  • EVENT_AccidentRecording2// [Rev8/9:296] Event that stores records it generates via actions ACTION_GpsLog and/or ActionID 55...58 into a accident log in RAM instead of into the normal log. For the loggin interval use CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval() and CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(). Then whenever you execute ActionID 107 (like when an accident occurrs), the amount of history records specified by you with SETTING_AccidentRecordingHistoryRecordAmount up to the number of future records you specified with SETTING_AccidentRecordingFutureRecordAmount are copied into the normal log which from there can be transferred to your server or later exported from there via a settings cable. NOTE: If this event is in use on Rev8 series modules, then all photo camera related features will not function anymore.

    - Interval: An integer value that represents the timer interval
        in units of 1/256 seconds.
        Value 0 will disable the event.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - See also CGPSsettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval()
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Changing EVENT_AccidentRecording2 interval condition to 5 seconds: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(EVENT_AccidentRecording2, 1280)) //1280=(5sec/(1/256))
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventSpeed(Event, &rSpeed, Get=true)
Retrieve event speed condition in kilometers per hour.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the speed
        condition is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_SPEED_Above// Triggers only once (see EVENT_SPEED_Below) when the lowest GPS speed of last 5 seconds is above the above-speed. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventSpeed() and CGPSsettings::SetEventSpeed() functions. See also SETTING_SpeedAboveEventSamples.
  • EVENT_SPEED_Below// Triggers only once and re-enables the EVENT_SPEED_Above when the speed becomes lower again than the below-speed. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventSpeed() and CGPSsettings::SetEventSpeed() functions.
  • EVENT_SPEED_DigTachAbove// [Rev8:151] Event triggers when tachograph speed exceeds this speed or exceeds the speed of its last trigger (process restarts after EVENT_SPEED_DigTachBelow has triggered). Value 0=event disabled.
  • EVENT_SPEED_DigTachBelow// [Rev8:151] After this event triggers once after EVENT_SPEED_DigTachAbove has triggered and the speed dropped again to at least the given value. Value 0=event disabled.

    - rSpeed: A reference to a variable that will receive the event
        speed condition in kilometers per hour.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition in the
        rSpeed variable will be used to overwrite the current condition
        instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    The event is disabled if the condition value is set to 0.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Setting=0; //Create a variable to receive the current event setting into
    print('The "When speed becomes above" event speed condition is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventSpeed(EVENT_SPEED_Above, $Setting)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if($Setting==0) print('Event condition is disabled<BR>');
        else print("$Setting kilometer per hour<BR>");
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventSpeed(Event, Speed)
Overwrite event speed condition in kilometers per hour.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions to which the speed
        condition is to be written:

  • EVENT_SPEED_Above// Triggers only once (see EVENT_SPEED_Below) when the lowest GPS speed of last 5 seconds is above the above-speed. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventSpeed() and CGPSsettings::SetEventSpeed() functions. See also SETTING_SpeedAboveEventSamples.
  • EVENT_SPEED_Below// Triggers only once and re-enables the EVENT_SPEED_Above when the speed becomes lower again than the below-speed. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventSpeed() and CGPSsettings::SetEventSpeed() functions.
  • EVENT_SPEED_DigTachAbove// [Rev8:151] Event triggers when tachograph speed exceeds this speed or exceeds the speed of its last trigger (process restarts after EVENT_SPEED_DigTachBelow has triggered). Value 0=event disabled.
  • EVENT_SPEED_DigTachBelow// [Rev8:151] After this event triggers once after EVENT_SPEED_DigTachAbove has triggered and the speed dropped again to at least the given value. Value 0=event disabled.

    - Speed: The speed condition in kilometers per hour to be set for
        the given Event.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - Set the speed condition to the value 0 to disable the event.
    - Use a minimum speed condition of 5 kilometer per hour and set
        EVENT_SPEED_Above at least 5 kilometer per hour above
        EVENT_SPEED_Below.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the "When speed becomes above" event speed condition to 130 kilometer per hour: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventSpeed(EVENT_SPEED_Above, 130)) //Change the event condition to 130 kilometers per hour
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventDistance(Event, &rDistance, Get=true)
Retrieve event distance condition in meters/kilometers.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        distance condition is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_DISTANCE_1// Travelled distance event. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventDistance() and CGPSsettings::SetEventDistance() functions. See also SETTING_ResetDistanceEventPerGpsLog.

    - rDistance: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        distance condition for the event with the following meaning:
        0 the event is disabled.
        1 up-to 65520 for a distance in meters.
        65521 up-to 65535 are in (value-65520)*100000) meters
        (e.g. 65521=100km, 65522=200km, ...).
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition value
        already in the rDistance variable will be used to overwrite
        the current condition instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - The internal distance counter in the module used for this event
        works independent from the TripMeters counter (see also
        CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters()).
    - The internal distance counter resets to 0 when a "start moving"
        event occurs (see also CGPS::GetShake()), but is not
        the same as the TripMeters counter (see also
        CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters()).
    - When this internal counter reaches the distance condition for
        the current settings, the counter is reset to 0 and the actions
        that are set for this event are executed.
    - You can also have this internal distance counter reset to 0
        when a GPS position is logged with
        SETTING_ResetDistanceEventPerGpsLog.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Distance=0; //Create a variable to receive the current event setting into.
    print('The "travelled distance" event condition in meters is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventDistance(EVENT_DISTANCE_1, $Distance)) //Read the event condition into the variable.
    {
        if($Distance==0) print('Event is disabled<BR>');
        else if($Distance<65521) print("$Distance meters<BR>");
        else if($Distance<65535) printf('%d meters<BR>', ($Distance-65520)*100000);
        else print("Unsupported condition: $Distance<BR>");
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventDistance(Event, Distance)
Overwrite the event distance condition in meters/kilometers.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions to which the distance condition is to be written:

  • EVENT_DISTANCE_1// Travelled distance event. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventDistance() and CGPSsettings::SetEventDistance() functions. See also SETTING_ResetDistanceEventPerGpsLog.

    - Distance condition value with the following meaning:
        0 the event is disabled.
        1 up-to 65520 for a distance in meters.
        65521 up-to 65535 are in (value-65520)*100000) meters. (e.g. 65521=100Km, 65522=200Km, ...).
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - The internal distance counter in the module used for this event
        works independent from the TripMeters counter (see also
        CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters()).
    - The internal distance counter resets to 0 when a "start moving"
        event occurs (see also CGPS::GetShake()), but is not
        the same as the TripMeters counter (see also
        CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters()).
    - When this internal counter reaches the distance condition for the
        current settings, the counter is reset to 0 and the actions that
        are set for this event are executed.
    - You can also have this internal distance counter reset to 0 when
        a GPS position is logged with
        SETTING_ResetDistanceEventPerGpsLog.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the "travelled distance" event condition to 1000 meter: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventDistance(EVENT_DISTANCE_1, 1000)) //Change the event condition
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Setting the "travelled distance" event condition to 500 kilometer: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventDistance(EVENT_DISTANCE_1, 65525)) //Change the event condition
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventPhone(Event, &rPhone, Get=true)
Retrieve event phone number condition.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the phone
        number condition is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 4. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled, unless you also have SETTING_TriggerCalledByPhone1ForAnyNumber activated in which case the event will trigger to to a phone call with any CallerID event which you could use for example execute ActionID 27 up-to 36 to execute your own LCD/Source-code and decide how to act to incoming call of which the CallerID number is then in "System Variable" %S44. See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy1.
  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy2// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 5. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled. See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy2.
  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy3// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 6. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled, See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy3.

    - rPhone: A reference to a variable that will receive the event
        phone number condition.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition in the
        rPhone variable will be used to overwrite the current condition
        instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - Phone number in international format. (e.g. "31121234567" for
        Dutch phone number "012-1234567").
    - The event is disabled if the phone number is an empty string.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Phone=''; //Create a variable to receive the current event setting
    print('The phone number for the "Called by 1" event is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventPhone(EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1, $Phone)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if(!strlen($Phone)) print('Event condition is disabled<BR>');
        else print("$Phone<BR>");
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventPhone(Event, Phone)
Overwrite the phone number of event condition.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions to which the phone
        number condition is to be written:

  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 4. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled, unless you also have SETTING_TriggerCalledByPhone1ForAnyNumber activated in which case the event will trigger to to a phone call with any CallerID event which you could use for example execute ActionID 27 up-to 36 to execute your own LCD/Source-code and decide how to act to incoming call of which the CallerID number is then in "System Variable" %S44. See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy1.
  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy2// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 5. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled. See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy2.
  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy3// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 6. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled, See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy3.

    - Phone: A text string containing the phone number to write into the
        condition of the event.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - Set digits of a phone number in international format.
        (e.g. "31121234567" for Dutch phone number "012-1234567").
    - Set the phone number to an empty string to disable the event.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting phone number for the "Called by 1" event to Dutch phone number 012-1234567: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventPhone(EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1, '31121234567')) //Change the event condition
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventHeadingDegrees(Event, &rDegrees, Get=true)
Retrieve event "heading direction degrees change" condition.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        heading condition is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_HEADING_Degrees// Heading direction change event. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHeadingDegrees() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHeadingDegrees() functions and also SETTING_HeadingDegreesRelativity.

    - rDegrees: A reference to a variable that will receive the event
        heading condition in degrees as floating point.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition in the
        rDegrees variable will be used to overwrite the current
        condition instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Note:
    - A returned value of 0 degrees means that the event is disabled.
    - Limited to 1 up-to 180 degrees. Useful setting for street route
        tracing is around 10 degrees.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Setting=0; //Create a variable to receive the current event setting into
    print('The "Heading direction change" event condition is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventHeadingDegrees(EVENT_HEADING_Degrees, $Setting)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if($Setting==0) print('Event condition is disabled<BR>');
        else print("$Setting degrees<BR>");
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventHeadingDegrees(Event, Degrees)
Set event "heading direction degrees change" condition.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions to which the
        heading condition is to be written:

  • EVENT_HEADING_Degrees// Heading direction change event. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHeadingDegrees() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHeadingDegrees() functions and also SETTING_HeadingDegreesRelativity.

    - Degrees: The number of degrees to change the event's condition to.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - Limited to 1 up-to 180 degrees. Useful setting for street route
        tracing is around 10 degrees.
    - Use 0 degrees to disable the event.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the "Heading direction change" event condition to 10 degrees: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventHeadingDegrees(EVENT_HEADING_Degrees, 10)) //Change the event condition to 10 degrees
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventHertz(Event, &rHertz, Get=true)
Retrieve the current Hertz condition for the event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        heading condition is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterAbove// [Rev8:233] Event that triggers every second while the pulses per second measured by the hardware pulse counter is above the supplied condition value. Condition value can be in the range of 1..65000 (=1Hz...65kHz) and value 0 disables the event. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHertz() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHertz() functions.
  • EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterBelowOrEqual// [Rev8:233] Event that triggers every second while the pulses per second measured by the hardware pulse counter is below or equal to the supplied condition value. Condition value can be in the range of 1..65000 (=1Hz...65kHz) and value 0 disables the event. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHertz() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHertz() functions.

    - rHertz: A reference to a variable that will receive the event
        condition Hertz.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition in the
        rHertz variable will be used to overwrite the current
        condition instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - A returned value of 0 Hertz means that the event is disabled.
    - While the event condition is met, the event will trigger every
        second. Therefore only actions like "ACTION_ResetTimer..."
        and "ACTION_Output..." are suitable and not actions like
        sending out an SMS text message.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Setting=0; //Create a variable to receive the current event Hertz condition
    print('The "Hardware pulse counter above" event condition is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventHertz(EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterAbove, $Setting)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if($Setting==0) print('Event condition is disabled<BR>');
        else print("$Setting Hertz<BR>");
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventHertz(Event, Hertz)
Overwrite the Hertz condition for the event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions to which the
        heading condition is to be written:

  • EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterAbove// [Rev8:233] Event that triggers every second while the pulses per second measured by the hardware pulse counter is above the supplied condition value. Condition value can be in the range of 1..65000 (=1Hz...65kHz) and value 0 disables the event. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHertz() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHertz() functions.
  • EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterBelowOrEqual// [Rev8:233] Event that triggers every second while the pulses per second measured by the hardware pulse counter is below or equal to the supplied condition value. Condition value can be in the range of 1..65000 (=1Hz...65kHz) and value 0 disables the event. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHertz() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHertz() functions.

    - Degrees: The number of degrees to change the event condition to.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - Use a value of 0 Hertz to disable the event.
    - While the event condition is met, the event will trigger every
        second. Therefore only actions like "ACTION_ResetTimer..."
        and "ACTION_Output..." are suitable and not actions like
        sending out an SMS text message.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the "Hardware pulse counter above" event condition to 1 kilo Hertz: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventHertz(EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterAbove, 1000)) //Change the event condition
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventInputPattern(Event, &raPattern, Get=true)
Retrieve input pattern condition for the event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        input pattern condition is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_InputPattern1// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #1 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.
  • EVENT_InputPattern2// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #2 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.
  • EVENT_InputPattern3// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #3 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.

    - raPattern: A reference to an array that will receive the event's
        pattern conditions:
        array[0]: 0=Event disabled, 1..5=Input1..Input5.
        array[1]: 0=Inactive start, 1=Active start.
        array[2]: Step1-Min; value 0=disabled, 1..255=0.1sec..25.5sec.
        array[3]: Step1-Max; ...
        array[4]: Step2-Min; ...
        array[5]: Step2-Max; ...
        array[6]: Step3-Min; ...
        array[7]: Step3-Max; ...
        array[8]: Step4-Min; ...
        array[9]: Step4-Max; ...
        array[10]: Step5-Min; ...
        array[11]: Step5-Max; ...
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition in the
        rDegrees variable will be used to overwrite the current
        condition instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
function SetEventInputPattern(Event, aPattern)
Overwrite the event pattern condition for the event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        input pattern condition is to be overwritten:

  • EVENT_InputPattern1// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #1 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.
  • EVENT_InputPattern2// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #2 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.
  • EVENT_InputPattern3// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #3 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.

    - aPattern: An array that contains the input pattern.
        array[0]: 0=Event disabled, 1..5=Input1..Input5.
        array[1]: 0=Inactive start, 1=Active start.
        array[2]: Step1-Min; value 0=disabled, 1..255=0.1sec..25.5sec.
        array[3]: Step1-Max; ...
        array[4]: Step2-Min; ...
        array[5]: Step2-Max; ...
        array[6]: Step3-Min; ...
        array[7]: Step3-Max; ...
        array[8]: Step4-Min; ...
        array[9]: Step4-Max; ...
        array[10]: Step5-Min; ...
        array[11]: Step5-Max; ...
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
function GetEventVoltage(Event, &rVoltage, Get=true)
Retrieve the current event voltage condition for the event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        heading condition is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_VOLTAGE_Below// While power supply voltage below events. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventVoltage() and CGPSsettings::SetEventVoltage() functions.
  • EVENT_VOLTAGE_Above// While power supply voltage above events. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventVoltage() and CGPSsettings::SetEventVoltage() functions.

    - rVoltage: A reference to a variable that will receive the event
        condition voltage.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition in the
        rVoltage variable will be used to overwrite the current
        condition instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Note:
    - A returned value of 0.0 volt means that the event is disabled.
    - While the event condition is met, it triggers several events per
        second. Therefore only actions like "ACTION_ResetTimer..."
        and "ACTION_Output..." are suitable and not actions like
        sending out an SMS text message.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Setting=0.0; //Create a variable to receive the current event voltage condition
    print('The "Voltage below" event condition is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventVoltage(EVENT_VOLTAGE_Below, $Setting)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if($Setting==0) print('Event condition is disabled<BR>');
        else print("$Setting Volt<BR>");
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventVoltage(Event, Voltage)
Overwrite the event voltage condition for the event.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions to which the
        heading condition is to be written:

  • EVENT_VOLTAGE_Below// While power supply voltage below events. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventVoltage() and CGPSsettings::SetEventVoltage() functions.
  • EVENT_VOLTAGE_Above// While power supply voltage above events. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventVoltage() and CGPSsettings::SetEventVoltage() functions.

    - Degrees: The number of degrees to change the event condition to.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - Use a value of 0.0 volt to disable the event.
    - While the event condition is met, it triggers several events per
        second. Therefore only actions like "ACTION_ResetTimer..."
        and "ACTION_Output..." are suitable and not actions like
        sending out an SMS text message.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the "Voltage below" event condition to 11.5 Volt: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventVoltage(EVENT_VOLTAGE_Below, 11.5)) //Change the event condition
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventRegion(Region, &rLatTopLeft, &rLonTopLeft, &rLatBotRight, &rLonBotRight, Get=true)
Retrieve region event latitude/longitude coordinates condition in
small format.
Function arguments:
    - Region: The number of the region of 1 up-to 50.
    - rLatTopLeft: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        latitude of the top-left of the region.
    - rLonTopLeft: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        longitude of the top-left of the region.
    - rLatBotRight: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        latitude of the bottom-right of the region.
    - rLonBotRight: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        latitude of the bottom-right of the region.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the coordinates in the
        referenced variables will be used to overwrite the current
        conditions instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    The Latitude and Longitude coordinates are in small format that can
be converted with helper functions like LatitudeSmallToFloat(),
    LongitudeSmallToFloat(), LatitudeSmallToDegrees()
    and LongitudeSmallToDegrees().
Notes:
    - To disable the event condition, fill all coordinates with:

  • EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE// Empty region coordinate. Set all four coordinates of a region with this to disable the region event.

    - See CGPSsettings::SetEventRegion() function documentation for
    background information about regions in general.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $LatTopLeft=$LonTopLeft=$LatBotRight=$LonBotRight=0; //Create variables that will receive the region event condition coordinates.
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventRegion(1, $LatTopLeft, $LonTopLeft, $LatBotRight, $LonBotRight)) //Read the coordinates into the variables
    {
        print("---Current coordinates for region event 1 condition---<BR>\r\n");
        print('Top-left latitude: '); if($LatTopLeft==EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE) print("Not set<BR>\r\n"); else printf("%f<BR>\r\n", LatitudeSmallToFloat($LatTopLeft));
        print('Top-left longitude: '); if($LonTopLeft==EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE) print("Not set<BR>\r\n"); else printf("%f<BR>\r\n", LongitudeSmallToFloat($LonTopLeft));
        print('Bottom-right latitude: '); if($LatBotRight==EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE) print("Not set<BR>\r\n"); else printf("%f<BR>\r\n", LatitudeSmallToFloat($LatBotRight));
        print('Bottom-right longitude: '); if($LonBotRight==EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE) print("Not set<BR>\r\n"); else printf("%f<BR>\r\n", LongitudeSmallToFloat($LonBotRight));
    } else print('The following error occurred: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()));
    ?>


function SetEventRegion(Region, LatTopLeft, LonTopLeft, LatBotRight, LonBotRight)
Set region event latitude/longitude coordinates condition in small format.
Function arguments:
    - Region: The number of the region of 1 up-to 50.
    - LatTopLeft: The latitude of the top-left of the region that is
        to be set.
    - LonTopLeft: The longitude of the top-left of the region that is
        to be set.
    - LatBotRight: The latitude of the bottom-right of the region that
        is to be set.
    - LonBotRight: The longitude of the bottom-right of the region that
        is to be set.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - The latitude and longitude coordinates must be supplied in small
        format (see helper functions like LatitudeFloatToSmall()
        and LongitudeFloatToSmall()).
    - Latitude top left to bottom right limits are 90 and -90 degrees.
        Use a minimum delta between the two of 0.00028, 1 second or higher.
    - Longitude top left to bottom right limits are -180 and 180 degrees.
        Use a minimum delta between the two of 0.00028, 1 second or higher.
    - Coordinates you set are rounded to the nearest settings format unit,
        so when you read them back they may not be exactly the same.
    - To disable the event condition, fill all coordinates with:

  • EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE// Empty region coordinate. Set all four coordinates of a region with this to disable the region event.


******
****** Background information on regions and their detection
******
    Up to 50 regions can be defined in the settings and each region can
    trigger the following events:

  • REGION_EVENT_Entering// Event that triggers once when the region is entered
  • REGION_EVENT_Inside// Event that triggers every second while being inside the region
  • REGION_EVENT_Leaving// Event that triggers once when the region is left
  • REGION_EVENT_Outside// Event that triggers every second while being outside the region

    Since Rev8:120 you can also define up to 269 regions with the same
    functionality via source code (see CGPSCODE:: class) that you
    upload from your server into the module via CGPS::mSourceCode.
    Since Rev8:214 you can also define over 4000 regions in the FLASH
    memory of the module.
    Even though the total number of regions that can be monitored
    inside the module can go up to about 4319, you can of course
    have unlimited regions on the server side by having the module log
    a position for EVENT_StartMoving/EVENT_StopMoving events and
    then on your server you can decide what region the position is in.
    But you can of course also/additionally upload a new set of region
    definitions from your server that are closest to the current
    position whenever the area of an outer region is left.

    Region events in the module can only be triggered when:
    - the GPS receiver is turned on and delivers the current position
        determined from the GPS satellite signals received via the
        attached antenna.
            ***WARNING***    ***WARNING***:
        When the GPS receiver is turned off (like when you contunously
        execute ActionID 73 while the "Power saving mode is active"),
