        there is of course no GPS information every second to monitor
        live for region events to trigger any actions either.
        But even then every ActionID 39 or ACTION_GpsLog for any event
        will still temporarily turn the GPS receiver on and any
        information that comes out during that time that is usable for
        triggering region events will be used to do so.
    - a position is determined from a minimum number of GPS satellites
        of which usable signals are received to determine a fix from.
        By default at least 7 satellites, but you can override that
        with SETTING_MinimumSatellitesForRegionDetection (or in
        section 53 of the settings application).
    - a minimum GPS receiver estimated accuracy value for a position
        is reached.
        You can override the default minimum accuracy value with
        SETTING_MinRegionDetectAccuracyValue (or in section 53
        of the settings application).

    Due to the nature of the GPS system, determined information like
    position/speed/direction will be constantly changing, even when
    you are not physically moving at all.
    This is caused by factors like changes in the atmosphere that the
    signals of the GPS satellites have to penetrate, reflections
    via the surrounding and other disturbances from outside.
    Next to the minimum number of GPS satellites and estimated
    accuracy there additionally are the following two methods
    to filter out information not to be used for region detection
    to prevent false triggers:
    - for modules that have an internal Accel/G-Force sensor (see
        CGPS::CanGetAccelerationX() for more info), you can set your
        preferred minimum level of vibration/motion with
        SETTING_MinimumAccelSensorMotionForRegionDetection (or
        in section 53 of the settings application), that you require
        for region detection to be active.   
    - a stationary motion filter which determines from factors like a
        speed that must be at least a few seconds between 10kmh and
        200kmh to use GPS information for region detection or not.
        For Rev5 modules, this filter is always in use and can not be
        disabled.
        Rev8/9 modules have a next generation GPS receiver with more
        enhanced methods of minimizing the above mentioned effect
        and for them this filter is usually nor required and can be
        disabled with SETTING_DisableStationaryMotionFilter
        (or in section 53 of the settings application).
        This filter is not linked or related to the global motion
        detection system (see CGPS::GetShake()).

    While the received GPS positions are being used to possibly trigger
    region events (so not prohibited by one or more of the filter
    methods mentioned above), then the regions defined in the:
    - settings are checked every second, or every two seconds if any
        region events are defined via module source code.
    - source code are checked in blocks of 50 defined regions every
        two seconds, so with up to 50 regions, each region is checked
        every two seconds and with 269 each is checked every 11 seconds.

    Additional info and notes:
    - Do not create a region too small, to avoid false triggers due to
        the variable nature of GPS caused by changes in the surrounding
        and atmosphere.
    - Region 50 has a special feature in combination with digital
        output 4.
        From the moment that the state of digital output 4 is changed
        from inactive to active (e.g. with CGPS::mDigitalOutput4 /
        ACTION_Output4), the supplied region rectangle for region 50
        will be used as if it was centered around the last known GPS
        position that passed your region quality filter set in section
        53 of the settings application.
        (note that this filter defaults to a fix at minimal 6 satellites
        and that if for example the GPS receiver is switched off, or
        just turned on, or insufficient satellite signals were provided
        on arrival at the current location then you will of course not
        set your actual current location in the region either).
        So if you for example set region 50 to some area anywhere on
        earth like:
            Top-left: lat: 0.0003 / lon: -0.0003
            Bottom-right: lat: -0.0003 / lon: 0.0003
            (which is about a 66 square meters region at a place where
            you probably never will be)
        and as action for the "Leaving region" event of region 50
        enable the action Alert-SMS, then you would receive an SMS if
        you would leave that region.
        But every time that you (re)activate output 4, that region
        used as if it was centered at your current position.
        Doing that for a module built in your car/bike/boat/..., all
        you need to do is enable digital output 4 and you will
        automatically receive an SMS when it is leaving the location
        where you last (re)activated output 4.
        You could for example enable digital output 4 via "not moving"
        detection from your engine not running, or a switch that you
        wired to a digital input, or an option in your own LCD menu,
        or a (custom) module command that you send via SMS or ....
        And the Alert-SMS can of course contain any text you want,
        including live info:
        "Dear owner, i am now at lat:xxx.xxx lon:xxx.xxx at speed
        xxkm/h..., if you want me to activate the ignition inhibitor,
        then send me an SMS containing: IMMOBOILIZE".
Usage example:


    <?php
    //Set region 1 rectangle coordinates
    if( $pcGPSsettings->SetEventRegion( 1
            , LatitudeFloatToSmall(90.0), LongitudeFloatToSmall(-180.0)
            , LatitudeFloatToSmall(-90.0), LongitudeFloatToSmall(180.0) )
        ) print('The coordinates for region 1 event condition are now changed');
    else print('The following error occurred while setting the region 1 coordinates: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()));
    //Disable region 2
    if( $pcGPSsettings->SetEventRegion( 2
            , EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE, EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE
            , EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE, EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE )
        ) print('The coordinates for region 1 event condition are now disabled');
    else print('The following error occurred while setting the region 2 coordinates: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()));
    ?>


function GetEventAcceleration(Event, &rGforce, Get=true)
Retrieve the current event G-Force condition.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        G-force condition is to be retrieved:

  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in positive direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in positive direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XNmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XNmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Y-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Y-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Zmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Z-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Zmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Z-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.

    - rGeforce: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        floating point event condition G-Force value.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the condition in the
        rGforce variable will be used to overwrite the current
        condition instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - A G-Force value of 0.0 means that the event is disabled, a
        positive value is used to trigger events in the positive and/or
        negative direction depending on EVENT_ACCELERATION_... that
        is used.
    - The minimum and maximum events of the X/Y/Z-direction sensors
        work together as a hysteresis, so the maximum event can only
        trigger again after the minimum event has triggered first and
        vice versa.
    - Acceleration settings are ignored by modules that do not have
        acceleration sensors.
    - You can make the module include the current readings of the
        sensors every time you make it log its current position by
        setting SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType to type
        GLST_PositionAcceleration to have logs with Switch
        values like SV_PositionAcceleration,
        SV_KeepAliveAcceleration, SV_TimeAliveAcceleration
        and SV_InaccuratePositionAcceleration.
    - From module log records that contain acceleration sensor
        readings, you can retrieve them with the
        CGPS::GetAcceleration...() functions.
    - See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for orientation and
        G-force example values.
    - See also CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration().
Usage example:


    <?php
    $GForce=0.0; //Create a variable to receive the current event G-Force condition
    //Retrieve the event trigger condition value of the maximum event for the X-directions sensor in positive direction
    print('The "EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmax" event condition is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAcceleration(EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmax, $GForce)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if($GForce==0.0) print('Disabled<BR>');
        else print("$GForce G<BR>");
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');

    //Retrieve the event trigger condition value of the maximum event for the Y-directions sensor in both direction
    print('The "EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymin" event condition is currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventAcceleration(EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymin, $GForce)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if($GForce==0.0) print('Disabled<BR>');
        else print("$GForce G<BR>");
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventAcceleration(Event, Gforce)
Overwrite the current event G-Force condition.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions to which the
        G-force condition is to be written:

  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in positive direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in positive direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XNmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XNmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Y-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Y-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Zmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Z-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Zmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Z-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.

    - Geforce: The floating point G-Force value to change the event
        condition into.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - A G-Force value of 0.0 means that the event is disabled, a
        positive value is used to trigger events in the positive and/or
        negative direction depending on EVENT_ACCELERATION_...
        that is used.
    - The minimum and maximum events of the X/Y/Z-direction sensors
        work together as a hysteresis, so the maximum event can only
        trigger again after the minimum event has triggered first and
        vice versa.
    - Acceleration settings are ignored by modules that do not have
        acceleration sensors.
    - You can make the module include the current readings of the
        sensors every time you make it log its current position by
        setting SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType to type
        GLST_PositionAcceleration to have logs with Switch
        values like SV_PositionAcceleration,
        SV_KeepAliveAcceleration, SV_TimeAliveAcceleration
        and SV_InaccuratePositionAcceleration.
    - From module log records that contain acceleration sensor
        readings, you can retrieve them with the
        CGPS::GetAcceleration...() functions.
    - See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for orientation and
        G-force example values.
    - See also CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration()
Usage example:


    <?php
    //Making the module trigger an Ymax event (and re-allow a previous Ymin event to occur again)
    //when the Y-directons sensor measures a G-Force value that exceeds -0.45g or +0.45g.
    print('Setting the "EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymax" event condition to 0.40g in both directions: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAcceleration(EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymax, 0.45))
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');

    //Making the module trigger an Ymin event (and re-allow a previous Ymax event to occur again)
    //when the Y-directons sensor measures a G-Force value that goes below -0.40g or +0.40g.
    print('Setting the "EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymin" event condition to 0.40g in both directions: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAcceleration(EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymin, 0.4))
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');

    //Making the module log its current position as action for every occurrence of the Ymax event.
    //(the EventID value in such logs tells you that they are created by an occurrence of the Ymax event).
    print('Setting "ACTION_GpsLog" for "EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymax": ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymax, ACTION_GpsLog))
        print("OK<BR>\r\n");
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventReceivedSerialData(Event, &rConditions, Get=true)
Retrieve the current event port conditions condition.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        conditions is to be retrieved:
        EVENT_ReceivedSerialData
    - rConditions: A reference to a variable that will receive the
        value defining the event conditions with the following bits:
        Bit 0: Serial port 1 enabled or disabled.
        Bit 1: Serial port 2 enabled or disabled.
        Bit 2: Serial port 3 enabled or disabled.
        Bit 3: Serial port 4 enabled or disabled.
    - Get: If supplied and is boolean FALSE, the conditions in the
        rConditions variable will be used to overwrite the current
        conditions instead.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - A rConditions value of 0 means that the event is disabled.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('The "EVENT_ReceivedSerialData" event condition is currently set to: ');
    $ReceivedSerialDataCondition=0; //Create a variable to receive the current event conditions
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventReceivedSerialData(EVENT_ReceivedSerialData, $ReceivedSerialDataCondition)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if($ReceivedSerialDataCondition==0) print("$ReceivedSerialDataCondition ( = Disabled)<BR>");
        else
        {
            print("$ReceivedSerialDataCondition ( =");
            if($ReceivedSerialDataCondition&1) print(' Port1:Enabled'); else print(' Port1:Disabled');
            if($ReceivedSerialDataCondition&2) print(' Port2:Enabled'); else print(' Port2:Disabled');
            if($ReceivedSerialDataCondition&4) print(' Port3:Enabled'); else print(' Port3:Disabled');
            if($ReceivedSerialDataCondition&8) print(' Port4:Enabled'); else print(' Port4:Disabled');
            print(')<BR>');
        }
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventReceivedSerialData(Event, Conditions)
Overwrite the current event G-Force condition.
Function arguments:
    - Event: One of the following event definitions of which the
        conditions are to be overwritten:
        EVENT_ReceivedSerialData
    - Conditions: An integer value that defines the conditions to be
        set with the following bits:
        Bit 0: Serial port 1 enabled or disabled.
        Bit 1: Serial port 2 enabled or disabled.
        Bit 2: Serial port 3 enabled or disabled.
        Bit 3: Serial port 4 enabled or disabled.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - A rConditions value of 0 means that the event is disabled.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Changing the "EVENT_ReceivedSerialData" event conditions to: Port1=Disabled Port2=Enabled Port3=Disabled Port4=Enabled :');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventReceivedSerialData(EVENT_ReceivedSerialData, 2|8 ))
        print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetTimerPulseCount(Bitmask)
Set Timer conditions to count digital I/O-port pulses or seconds.
Function arguments:
    - Bitmask: Condition bitmask value for Timer1..8 (EVENT_TIMERS_...) to count I/O-port "becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 0: Timer5 (EVENT_TIMERS_5) counts "Digital output port 1 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 1: Timer6 (EVENT_TIMERS_6) counts "Digital output port 2 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 2: Timer7 (EVENT_TIMERS_7) counts "Digital output port 3 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 3: Timer8 (EVENT_TIMERS_8) counts "Digital output port 4 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 4: Timer1 (EVENT_TIMERS_1) counts "Digital input port 1 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 5: Timer2 (EVENT_TIMERS_2) counts "Digital input port 2 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 6: Timer3 (EVENT_TIMERS_3) counts "Digital input port 3 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 7: Timer4 (EVENT_TIMERS_4) counts "Digital input port 4 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    See also CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers()
    See also CGPSsettings::GetTimerPulseCount()
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting Timer1 (=digital input 1) and Timer7 (=digital output 2) to "count becomes active pulses", and the others to count seconds: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetTimerPulseCount(16+4)) print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetTimerPulseCount(&rBitmask)
Get Timer conditions info if they count digital I/O-port pulses or seconds.
Function arguments:
    - rBitmask: Reference to a variable that receives the condition bitmask value for Timer1..8 (EVENT_TIMERS_...).
        Bit 0: Timer5 (EVENT_TIMERS_5) counts "Digital output port 1 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 1: Timer6 (EVENT_TIMERS_6) counts "Digital output port 2 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 2: Timer7 (EVENT_TIMERS_7) counts "Digital output port 3 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 3: Timer8 (EVENT_TIMERS_8) counts "Digital output port 4 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 4: Timer1 (EVENT_TIMERS_1) counts "Digital input port 1 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 5: Timer2 (EVENT_TIMERS_2) counts "Digital input port 2 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 6: Timer3 (EVENT_TIMERS_3) counts "Digital input port 3 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
        Bit 7: Timer4 (EVENT_TIMERS_4) counts "Digital input port 4 becomes active" pulses instead of seconds.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    See also CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers()
    See also CGPSsettings::SetTimerPulseCount()
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Bitmask=0; //The variable that will receive the bitmask
    print('The conditions of the Timer events are currently set to: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetTimerPulseCount($Bitmask)) //Read the condition bitmask from the current settings into the variable
    {
        if($Bitmask&16) print('<BR>Timer1: counts "becomes active pulses" of digital input port 1'); else print('<BR>Timer1: counts seconds');
        if($Bitmask&32) print('<BR>Timer2: counts "becomes active pulses" of digital input port 2'); else print('<BR>Timer2: counts seconds');
        if($Bitmask&64) print('<BR>Timer3: counts "becomes active pulses" of digital input port 3'); else print('<BR>Timer3: counts seconds');
        if($Bitmask&128) print('<BR>Timer4: counts "becomes active pulses" of digital input port 4'); else print('<BR>Timer4: counts seconds');
        if($Bitmask&1) print('<BR>Timer5: counts "becomes active pulses" of digital output port 1'); else print('<BR>Timer5: counts seconds');
        if($Bitmask&2) print('<BR>Timer6: counts "becomes active pulses" of digital output port 2'); else print('<BR>Timer6: counts seconds');
        if($Bitmask&4) print('<BR>Timer7: counts "becomes active pulses" of digital output port 3'); else print('<BR>Timer7: counts seconds');
        if($Bitmask&8) print('<BR>Timer8: counts "becomes active pulses" of digital output port 4'); else print('<BR>Timer8: counts seconds');
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventOutputsStatusChange(BitmaskOfPortsToBeMonitored)
Set outputs to be monitored for the "Outputs status change" event.
Function arguments:
    - BitmaskOfPortsToBeMonitored: Condition bitmask value of the outputs that are to be monitored for the EVENT_OutputsStatusChange event.
        Bit 0: Digital output port 1
        Bit 1: Digital output port 4
        Bit 2: Digital output port 2
        Bit 3: Digital output port 3
        Bit 4: Virtual output port 1
        Bit 5: Virtual output port 2
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    See also EVENT_OutputsStatusChange
    See also CGPSsettings::GetEventOutputsStatusChange()
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the "When digital outputs change" event condition to monitor: Output1, Output3 and Virtual output 2: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventOutputsStatusChange(1+8+32)) print('OK<BR>');
    else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventOutputsStatusChange(&rBitmaskOfPortsToBeMonitored)
Get outputs that are monitored for the "Outputs status change" event.
Function arguments:
    - rPortsToMonitorBitMask: Reference to variable that receives a bitmask value of the outputs that are monitored for the EVENT_OutputsStatusChange event.
        Bit 0: Digital output port 1
        Bit 1: Digital output port 4
        Bit 2: Digital output port 2
        Bit 3: Digital output port 3
        Bit 4: Virtual output port 1
        Bit 5: Virtual output port 2
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    See also EVENT_OutputsStatusChange
    See also CGPSsettings::SetEventOutputsStatusChange()
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Bitmask=0; //Variable that will receive the bitmask
    print('The conditions of the "When outputs status change" event are currently set to monitor: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventOutputsStatusChange($Bitmask)) //Read the bitmask from the current settings into the variable
    {
        if($Bitmask==0) print('Nothing (Event disabled)');
        if($Bitmask&1) print('"Output 1" ');
        if($Bitmask&4) print('"Output 2" ');
        if($Bitmask&8) print('"Output 3" ');
        if($Bitmask&2) print('"Output 4" ');
        if($Bitmask&16) print('"Virtual output 1" ');
        if($Bitmask&32) print('"Virtual output 2" ');
        print('<BR>');
    } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetEventDigTachStatusChange(BitmaskOfStatusesToBeMonitored)
Set statuses of the digital tachograph to be monitored for changes.
Function arguments:
    - BitmaskOfStatusesToBeMonitored: Bitmask value consisting of
        combined DTDCEBM_... definitions describing the
        statuses to be monitored for changes to trigger the
        EVENT_OutputsStatusChange event in the settings.
        This bitmask value can be 0 if no statuses are monitored
        (then the event is disabled).
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    The advantage of having the module to monitor the statuses that a
    digital tachograph outputs every second is that you do not have to
    log (and transmit to your server) all data that is supplied.
    Instead you simply log all current statuses only when some status
    that you are interested in changes.
    That saves you a LOT of data while effectively having the same
    information.
    The code example below shows you how to change the settings
    accordingly with this function.

    See CGPS::GetDigTach1StatusChanges() for additional information
    and how to determine from the logged records which status has
    changed.
    See also CGPSsettings::GetEventDigTachStatusChange().
Usage example:


    <?php
    //
    //Set the "Tachograph status change" event to monitor for a couple
    //of status changes and as action when one changes log the current
    //position and a SV_DigTach1 record (and related ones).
    //
        //Setting the event condition
    print('Setting "Tachograph status change" event to trigger on status changes in Motion+Driver1workstate+Overspeed: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventDigTachStatusChange(DTDCEBM_Motion|DTDCEBM_Driver1workstate|DTDCEBM_Overspeed))
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
       
        //Setting the event action to log the current GPS position
    print('Setting the "Tachograph status change" event action to log the current position: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_DigTachStatusChanges, ACTION_GpsLog, true))
        print("OK<BR>\r\n"); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
   
        //Setting the event action to perform an ActionID instead of SMS-alerts
    print('Setting the "Tachograph status change" event action to perform an ActionID: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_DigTachStatusChanges, ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts, true))
        print("OK<BR>\r\n"); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
   
        //Setting the event action to perform ActionID 53 to log SV_DigTach1+VIN/VRN(/CARD1/CARD2) records
    print('Setting the "Tachograph status change" event action to perform ActionID 53: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventAction(EVENT_DigTachStatusChanges, ACTION_ActionID, 53))
        print("OK<BR>\r\n"); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetEventDigTachStatusChange(&rBitmaskOfStatusesToBeMonitored)
Get statuses of the digital tachograph to be monitored for changes.
Function arguments:
    - rBitmaskOfStatusesToBeMonitored: Reference to variable that
        receives a bitmask value of the statuses of the digital
        tachograph that are monitored for changes by the
        EVENT_OutputsStatusChange event in the settings.
        The returned value can be 0 if no statuses are set to be
        monitored (event is disabled) or a combination of one or more
        DTDCEBM_... definitions.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    The advantage of having the module to monitor the statuses that a
    digital tachograph outputs every second is that you do not have to
    log (and transmit to your server) all data that is supplied.
    Instead you simply log all current statuses only when some status
    that you are interested in changes.
    That saves you a LOT of data while effectively having the same
    information.
    The code example below shows you how to check the settings
    for the statuses that are monitored with this function.

    See CGPS::GetDigTach1StatusChanges() for additional information
    and how to determine from the logged records which status has
    changed.
    See also CGPSsettings::SetEventDigTachStatusChange().
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('The "Tachograph status change" event is set to trigger on the following status changes: ');
    $BitmaskValue=0; //Variable to receive the current bitmask from the settings
    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventDigTachStatusChange($BitmaskValue)) //Read the event condition into the variable
    {
        if($BitmaskValue) //Has it a value different than 0?
        {
            //The value is not 0, so one or more statuses are monitored.
            //This is of course always the case for a record that you specifically
            //logged when a status change is detected.
            //When logged via a timer interval, the value will of course usually be 0.
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Motion) print("<BR> - Change between: motion / no motion");
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Driver1workstate) print("<BR> - Change of Driver1 working state");
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Driver2workstate) print("<BR> - Change of Driver2 working state");
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Overspeed) print("<BR> - Over speed change (in)active");
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Driver1card) print("<BR> - Change of Driver1 card state");
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Driver2card) print("<BR> - Change of Driver2 card state");
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Driver1warning) print("<BR> - Change in Driver1 warning messages");
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Driver2warning) print("<BR> - Change in Driver2 warning messages");
            if($BitmaskValue & DTDCEBM_Ignition) print("<BR> - Change in Ignition status");
        } else print("<BR> - None, the event is disabled"); //Value was 0, so no statuses are monitored
    } else print('<BR> - ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()));
    ?>


function GetSetting(Setting, &rData, Get=true)
Read the current data from a setting.
Function arguments:
    - Setting: The 'SETTING_...' definition.
    - rData: A reference to a variable that is to receive the data for the setting.
    - Get: If not omitted and is boolean FALSE, then the contents of the rData variable will be used to overwrite the current data for the setting.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - See the description of the used 'SETTING_...' definition for a description of the data for that setting.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Data=0; //Create a variable to receive the data
    print('The phone number for the "SMS-alert phone number 1" setting is: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_SmsAlertPhone1, $Data)) //Read the setting data into the variable
        {
            if(!strlen($Data)) print('Not set<BR>');
            else print("$Data<BR>");
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('GPRS Access Point Name is set to: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_AccessPointName, $Data)) //Read the setting data into the variable
        {
            if(!strlen($Data)) print('Not set (=automatic)<BR>');
            else print("$Data<BR>");
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('GPRS primary server data transmission format is set to: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_GprsPrimaryTcpDataFormat, $Data)) //Read the setting data into the variable
        {
            if(!strlen($Data)) print('Not set (=Use evaluation server)<BR>');
            else print(str_replace("\r", '\r', str_replace("\n", '\n', $Data)).'<BR>'); //Print <carriage return> and <line feed> characters converted to \r and \n to make them visible.
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Automatic power-down power supply voltage level is set to: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_PowerDownVoltage, $Data)) //Read the setting data into the variable
            print("$Data Volt<BR>");
        else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Include GPS position with photo transmissions is set to: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto, $Data)) //Read the setting data into the variable
        {
            if($Data) print('Yes<BR>');
            else print('No<BR>');
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('GSM band scanning for available networks is set to: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_GsmAutoBanding, $Data)) //Read the setting data into the variable
        {
            if($Data==GAB_Automatic) print('Automatically scan all bands that the built-in GSM module supports<BR>');
            else if($Data==GAB_900and1800) print('Scan only 900 and 1800 bands for available networks<BR>');
            else if($Data==GAB_850and1900) print('Scan only 850 and 1900 bands for available networks<BR>');
            else print("Unknown setting ($Data)<BR>");
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Primary server IP is set to: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_PrimaryServerIP, $Data)) //Read the setting data into the variable
        {
            if(!$Data) print('Not set<BR>');
            else printf('%d.%d.%d.%d<BR>', $Data&255, ($Data>>8)&255, ($Data>>16)&255, ($Data>>24)&255);
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Minimum region detection accuracy in meters with a probability of 67% is set to: ');
        if($pcGPSsettings->GetSetting(SETTING_MinRegionDetectAccuracyValue, $Data)) //Read the setting data into the variable
        {
            if(!$Data) print('Module firmware default<BR>');
            if(($Data>=2)&&($Data<=21)) printf('%.1f meter<BR>', (float)((pow((float)1.1, (float)$Data)-(float)1.0)*(float)10.0));
            else print("Unknown setting ($Data)<BR>");
        } else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function SetSetting(Setting, Data)
Write data into a setting.
Function arguments:
    - Setting: The 'SETTING_...' definition.
    - Data: The data to write into the setting.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    - See the description of the used 'SETTING_...' definition for a description of the data for that setting.
Usage example:


    <?php
    print('Setting the phone number for the "SMS-alert phone number 1" setting to 06-12345678: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_SmsAlertPhone1, '31612345678')) //Write into the setting
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Setting GPRS Access Point Name to "Automatic": ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_AccessPointName, '')) //Write empty string into the setting
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Setting GPRS primary server data transmission format: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_GprsPrimaryTcpDataFormat, "GET /YourScript.php?YourVariableName=%s HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: www.YourHost.com\r\n\r\n"))
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Setting automatic power-down power supply voltage level to 11.5 Volt: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_PowerDownVoltage, 11.5)) //Write into the setting
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Enabling "Include GPS position with photo transmissions" setting: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto, true)) //Write boolean TRUE into the setting
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Setting "GSM band scanning for available networks" to 900 and 1800: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_GsmAutoBanding, GAB_900and1800)) //Write into the setting
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('Setting primary server IP to 11.22.33.44: ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_PrimaryServerIP, 11 + 22*256 + 33*65536 + 44*16777216)) //Write IP 11.22.33.44 into the setting
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    print('(Available "Minimum region detection accuracy in meters with a probability of 67%" options are: 0=Default');
        for($Option=2;$Option<22;$Option++) printf(', %d=%.1f', $Option, (float)((pow((float)1.1, (float)$Option)-(float)1.0)*(float)10.0));
    print(')<BR>Now setting "Minimum region detection accuracy in meters with a probability of 67%" to option 15 (for 31.8 meter): ');
    if($pcGPSsettings->SetSetting(SETTING_MinRegionDetectAccuracyValue, 15)) //Write the 31.8 meter option into the setting
        print('OK<BR>'); else print('ERROR: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()).'<BR>');
    ?>


function GetRegionCodeData(Region, AdditionalSettings, &rDataResult)
Encode a region from the settings as binary code Data
Function arguments:
    - RegionSpace: Region number (1..50) of the settings to get the information from.
    - AdditionalSettings: Array containing additional settings to encode in the data.
        Required array contents:
            - AdditionalSettings[0]: Region number to be encoded in the generated Data.
        Optional additional array contents:
            - Nothing (reserved for possible future purposes).
    - rDataResult: Reference to a variable that receives the generated binary Data.
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    See CGPSsettings::SetEventRegion() function documentation for
    background information about regions in general.
Usage example:


    <?php
    require('cgps.php');
    $pcGPSCODE=new CGPSCODE();
    //if($pcGPSCODE->AddSourceCode(@file_get_contents('SourceCodeFile.src')))
    //{
        //Set for example some region with preferred actions in the settings
        $pcGPSsettings=new CGPSsettings();
        $Region=1; //Using region 1 space in the settings data
        if(    $pcGPSsettings->SetEventRegion($Region
                , LatitudeFloatToSmall(0.1234)
                , LongitudeFloatToSmall(-0.1234)
                , LatitudeFloatToSmall(-0.1234)
                , LongitudeFloatToSmall(0.1234) ) )
        {
            if($pcGPSsettings->SetEventActionRegion($Region, REGION_EVENT_Leaving, ACTION_SmsAlert1, true))
            {
                //Now get current settings for region 1 as binary data for region 51
                $AdditionalSettings=array();
                $AdditionalSettings[0]=51; //Region 51
                $Data=''; //Variable to receive the binary data
                if($pcGPSsettings->GetRegionCodeData($Region, $AdditionalSettings, $Data))
                {
                    $Index=123; //Programming the Region 51 in the source code on Index 123;
                    if(    $pcGPSCODE->SetInstructionArgument($Index, MIA_Name, 'My region 51 definition') //Non required label
                        && $pcGPSCODE->SetInstructionArgument($Index, MIA_Type, 34) //Type 34: Region definition and action settings stored in Data
                        && $pcGPSCODE->SetInstructionArgument($Index, MIA_Data, $Data) //The region 51 data
                        )
                    {
                        //Display new source code
                        $SourceCode=$pcGPSCODE->GetSourceCode();
                        print($SourceCode);
                    } else print("SetInstructionArgument() error: ".$pcGPSCODE->GetLastError());
                } else print("GetRegionCodeData() error: ".$pcGPSsettings->GetLastError());
            } else print("SetEventActionRegion() error: ".$pcGPSsettings->GetLastError());
        } else print("SetEventRegion() error: ".$pcGPSsettings->GetLastError());
    //} else print("AddSourceCode() error: ".$pcGPSCODE->GetLastError());
    ?>


function SetRegionCodeData(Region, Data, &rAdditionalSettings)
Decode region from binary code Data in to the settings.
Function arguments:
    - Region: The region number (1..50) of the settings to store the region in.
    - Data: The binary code Data (or empty for default settings).
    - rAdditionalSettings: Reference to an array that will receive additional settings.
        Array will be filled with:
            - AdditionalSettings[0]: Region number as it was encoded in Data.
        Array may additionally be filled with:
            - Nothing (reserved for possible future purposes).
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSsettings::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    See CGPSsettings::SetEventRegion() function documentation for
    background information about regions in general.
Usage example:


    <?php
    require('cgps.php');
    $pcGPSCODE=new CGPSCODE();
    $SourceCodeFile='SourceCodeFile.src';
    if($pcGPSCODE->AddSourceCode(@file_get_contents($SourceCodeFile)))
    {
        //Source code is now in the code class
        $aIndexesWithRegion=$pcGPSCODE->GetRegions();
        $AmountOfRegions=count($aIndexesWithRegion);
        if($AmountOfRegions)
        {
            print("Number of regions in source code file '$SourceCodeFile' is $AmountOfRegions<BR>");
            $pcGPSsettings=new CGPSsettings();
            $Region=1; //Using region 1 storage of the settings to decode everything
            $aAdditionalSettings=array(); //Will receive additional settings
            foreach($aIndexesWithRegion as $Index => $RegionID)
            {
                print("--- Region settings in Index $Index ---<BR>");
                $pcGPSsettings->ClearSettings();
                if($pcGPSsettings->SetRegionCodeData($Region
                    , $pcGPSCODE->GetInstructionArgument($Index, MIA_Data)
                    , $aAdditionalSettings ) )
                {
                    print("Region number: ".$aAdditionalSettings[0]."<BR>");
                    $LatTopLeft=$LonTopLeft=$LatBotRight=$LonBotRight=0; //Create variables that will receive the region event condition coordinates.
                    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventRegion($Region, $LatTopLeft, $LonTopLeft, $LatBotRight, $LonBotRight)) //Read the coordinates into the variables
                    {
                        print('Top-left latitude: ');
                        if($LatTopLeft==EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE) print("Not set<BR>\r\n");
                        else printf("%f<BR>\r\n", LatitudeSmallToFloat($LatTopLeft));
                        print('Top-left longitude: ');
                        if($LonTopLeft==EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE) print("Not set<BR>\r\n");
                        else printf("%f<BR>\r\n", LongitudeSmallToFloat($LonTopLeft));
                        print('Bottom-right latitude: ');
                        if($LatBotRight==EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE) print("Not set<BR>\r\n");
                        else printf("%f<BR>\r\n", LatitudeSmallToFloat($LatBotRight));
                        print('Bottom-right longitude: ');
                        if($LonBotRight==EMPTY_REGION_COORDINATE) print("Not set<BR>\r\n");
                        else printf("%f<BR>\r\n", LatitudeSmallToFloat($LonBotRight));
                    } else print('GetEventRegion() error: '.htmlspecialchars($pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()));
                    $Setting=0; //Create a variable that will receive the setting
                    //Get all action settings you want from the Entering/Inside/Leaving/Outside events like:
                    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventActionRegion($Region, REGION_EVENT_Entering, ACTION_SmsAlert1, $Setting)) //Read the setting into the variable
                    {
                        if($Setting) print("When entering the region: No Alert-SMS is sent to phone number 1<BR>");
                        else print("When entering the region: An Alert-SMS is sent to phone number 1<BR>");
                    } else print("GetEventActionRegion(Entering-SmsAlert1) problem with the Data of Index $Index: ".$pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()."<BR>");
                    if($pcGPSsettings->GetEventActionRegion($Region, REGION_EVENT_Leaving, ACTION_SmsAlert1, $Setting)) //Read the setting into the variable
                    {
                        if($Setting) print("When leaving the region: No Alert-SMS is sent to phone number 1<BR>");
                        else print("When leaving the region: An Alert-SMS is sent to phone number 1<BR>");
                    } else print("GetEventActionRegion(Leaving-SmsAlert1) problem with the Data of Index $Index: ".$pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()."<BR>");
                    //...
                    //Retrieve with GetEventActionRegion() everything else you want for each REGION_EVENT_... and ACTION_...
                    //...
                } else print("SetRegionCodeData() problem with the Data of Index $Index: ".$pcGPSsettings->GetLastError()."<BR>");
            }
        } else print("No regions in source code file '$SourceCodeFile'");
    } else print("Error in source code file '$SourceCodeFile': ".$pcGPSCODE->GetLastError());
    ?>




|| *** Action definitions ***
|| These actions are available for every event with the CGPSsettings::GetEventAction...() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAction...() functions.

  • ACTION_GpsLog// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, temporarily turn/keep-on the GPS receiver and wait for a GPS-fix to come out (that passes your posed filter with settings like SETTING_MinPositionAccuracyValue, SETTING_MinimumSatellitesForPosition and SETTING_MaximumSpeedForPosition) and write a SV_Position... record (type depends on SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType) to the log with that GPS-fix information in it. If no GPS-fix becomes available within the timeout of 5 seconds (SETTING_KeepAliveTimeOutSecs) or 40 seconds while the power saving mode is active (SETTING_KeepAliveTimeOutSecsPowerSaving), then a SV_TimeAlive... or SV_KeepAlive... record (SETTING_UseSystemTimeForKeepAlive) is written to the log instead.
  • ACTION_Photo// When activated with a RACD_Photo_... definition for an event, that event will when it triggers, take a picture with attached camera (transmission/storage depends on SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto and SETTING_LogPhotos). NOTE: It is recommended to use ACTION_ActionID instead with an ActionID like 23/24/25/26/66/67/68/69.
  • ACTION_CountersLog// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, write a SV_Counters into the log. Unless suppressed with SETTING_DoNotLogHighestSpeedWithCounters, also a SV_CountersHighestSpeed is written to the log at the same time. If enabled with SETTING_AnalogInputLoggingWithCounters, also a SV_CountersAnalogInputs is written into the log at the same time.
  • ACTION_TransmitLog// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, initiate a start of transferring the contents of the log to the server. NOTE: This action is only useful if you have set the automatic transmission interval to anything else than every second default with SETTING_GprsTransmitInterval or if you disabled that auto transmission interval completely by selecting logging mode with GPS modem on with SETTING_ModuleDataLogging.
  • ACTION_ResetTimer1// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, reset the runtime count of Timer 1 so it will re-start counting from 0 again up-to the condition count you have set for the event of the timer before it can trigger the actions you have set for it.
  • ACTION_ResetTimer2// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, reset the runtime count of Timer 2 so it will re-start counting from 0 again up-to the condition count you have set for the event of the timer before it can trigger the actions you have set for it.
  • ACTION_ResetTimer3// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, reset the runtime count of Timer 3 so it will re-start counting from 0 again up-to the condition count you have set for the event of the timer before it can trigger the actions you have set for it.
  • ACTION_ResetTimer4// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, reset the runtime count of Timer 4 so it will re-start counting from 0 again up-to the condition count you have set for the event of the timer before it can trigger the actions you have set for it.
  • ACTION_ResetTimer5// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, reset the runtime count of Timer 5 so it will re-start counting from 0 again up-to the condition count you have set for the event of the timer before it can trigger the actions you have set for it.
  • ACTION_ResetTimer6// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, reset the runtime count of Timer 6 so it will re-start counting from 0 again up-to the condition count you have set for the event of the timer before it can trigger the actions you have set for it.
  • ACTION_ResetTimer7// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, reset the runtime count of Timer 7 so it will re-start counting from 0 again up-to the condition count you have set for the event of the timer before it can trigger the actions you have set for it.
  • ACTION_ResetTimer8// When actvated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, reset the runtime count of Timer 8 so it will re-start counting from 0 again up-to the condition count you have set for the event of the timer before it can trigger the actions you have set for it.
  • ACTION_SmsAlert1// When (ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts is disabled with Boolean FALSE and) activated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, initiate the start of sending an SMS text message to the phone number set with SETTING_SmsAlertPhone1. The contents of the Data field of Index 3 of your LCD/Source-code is used as template to generate the text message that is sent.
  • ACTION_SmsAlert2// When (ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts is disabled with Boolean FALSE and) activated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, initiate the start of sending an SMS text message to the phone number set with SETTING_SmsAlertPhone2. The contents of the Data field of Index 4 of your LCD/Source-code is used as template to generate the text message that is sent.
  • ACTION_SmsAlert3// When (ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts is disabled with Boolean FALSE and) activated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, initiate the start of sending an SMS text message to the phone number set with SETTING_SmsAlertPhone3. The contents of the Data field of Index 5 of your LCD/Source-code is used as template to generate the text message that is sent.
  • ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1// When (ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts is disabled with Boolean FALSE and) activated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, initiate the start of sending an SMS text message to the phone number set with CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1. The contents of the Data field of Index 6 of your LCD/Source-code is used as template to generate the text message that is sent.
  • ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown2// When (ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts is disabled with Boolean FALSE and) activated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, initiate the start of sending an SMS text message to the phone number set with CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy2. The contents of the Data field of Index 7 of your LCD/Source-code is used as template to generate the text message that is sent.
  • ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown3// When (ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts is disabled with Boolean FALSE and) activated with Boolean TRUE for an event, that event will when it triggers, initiate the start of sending an SMS text message to the phone number set with CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy3. The contents of the Data field of Index 8 of your LCD/Source-code is used as template to generate the text message that is sent.
  • ACTION_Output1// When actvated with a RACD_DigitalOutput_... definition for any EVENT_..., the event will when it triggers change status of digital output 1 accordingly.
  • ACTION_Output2// When actvated with a RACD_DigitalOutput_... definition for any EVENT_..., the event will when it triggers change status of digital output 2 accordingly.
  • ACTION_Output3// When actvated with a RACD_DigitalOutput_... definition for any EVENT_..., the event will when it triggers change status of digital output 3 accordingly.
  • ACTION_Output4// When actvated with a RACD_DigitalOutput_... definition for any EVENT_..., the event will when it triggers change status of digital output 4 accordingly.
  • ACTION_RebootModule// *** DEPRICATED *** Do !NOT! use this option anymore, use ActionID 64 instead.
  • ACTION_ClearGPSConfig// Boolean TRUE: Clear the GPS receiver's runtime tables, resulting in a cold start of the GPS receiver.
  • ACTION_ClearLog// Boolean TRUE: Erase the module's FLASH-memory that also contains its log.
  • ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts// When set to Boolean TRUE for any EVENT_..., that event expects the action to execute when it triggers to be defined with ACTION_ActionID instead of the six ACTION_SmsAlert... actions. NOTE: You *MUST* choose per event with this action type between the execution of an ActionID or sending an SMS text messages with the six ACTION_SmsAlert... actions, you can not combine the two.
  • ACTION_ActionID// When (ACTION_TYPE_PerformActionInsteadOfSmsAlerts is enabled with Boolean TRUE) for any EVENT_..., that event will when it triggers execute the ActionID number that you have set.

====



|| *** ActionID values that can be executed as action for any EVENT_... via ACTION_ActionID, or from your server via CGPS::mActionID, and various SMS/LCD/CODE-"Module Commands" ***
||     0. No action
||     1. [Rev8:161] Call the "SMS-Alert phone number 1" that is set with CGPSsettings::SETTING_SmsAlertPhone1, for open voice connection. For modules with voice phone hardware with a microphone and speaker attached, you can then listen and speak to the person on the other side answering the phone call.
||     2. [Rev8:161] Call the "SMS-Alert phone number 2" that is set with CGPSsettings::SETTING_SmsAlertPhone2, for open voice connection. For modules with voice phone hardware with a microphone and speaker attached, you can then listen and speak to the person on the other side answering the phone call.
||     3. [Rev8:161] Call the "SMS-Alert phone number 3" that is set with CGPSsettings::SETTING_SmsAlertPhone3, for open voice connection. For modules with voice phone hardware with a microphone and speaker attached, you can then listen and speak to the person on the other side answering the phone call.
||     4. [Rev8:161] Call the "Called by phone number 1" that is set for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1, for open voice connection. For modules with voice phone hardware with a microphone and speaker attached, you can then listen and speak to the person on the other side answering the phone call.
||     5. [Rev8:161] Call the "Called by phone number 2" that is set for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy2, for open voice connection. For modules with voice phone hardware with a microphone and speaker attached, you can then listen and speak to the person on the other side answering the phone call.
||     6. [Rev8:161] Call the "Called by phone number 3" that is set for EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy3, for open voice connection. For modules with voice phone hardware with a microphone and speaker attached, you can then listen and speak to the person on the other side answering the phone call.
||     7. [Rev8:161] Hang-up open voice connection or reject incoming phone call.
||     8. Perform event actions only when "Virtual output 1" is inactive. When you include this action together with others for an event, then when the event triggers it only execute the actions that you have selected if the digital state of virtual output 1 is inactive.
||     9. Perform event actions only when "Virtual output 1" is active. When you include this action together with others for an event, then when the event triggers it only execute the actions that you have selected if the digital state of virtual output 1 is active.
||     10. Perform event actions only when "Virtual output 2" is inactive. When you include this action together with others for an event, then when the event triggers it only execute the actions that you have selected if the digital state of virtual output 2 is inactive.
||     11. Perform event actions only when "Virtual output 2" is active. When you include this action together with others for an event, then when the event triggers it only execute the actions that you have selected if the digital state of virtual output 2 is active.
||     12. Deactivate "Virtual Output 1". This action changes the state of virtual output 1 to inactive which is for example useful for controlling actions 8 and 9, or in your own LCD/Source-code using system variable %S80.
||     13. Activate "Virtual Output 1". This action changes the state of virtual output 1 to active which is for example useful for controlling actions 8 and 9, or in your own LCD/Source-code using system variable %S80.
||     14. Deactivate "Virtual Output 2". This action changes the state of virtual output 2 to inactive which is for example useful for controlling actions 10 and 11, or in your own LCD/Source-code using system variable %S81.
||     15. Activate "Virtual Output 2". This action changes the state of virtual output 2 to inactive which is for example useful for controlling actions 10 and 11, or in your own LCD/Source-code using system variable %S81.
||     16. Log all attached 1-Wire devices as SV_1WireData1 records.
||     17. Log details attached 1-Wire and RF temperature sensor devices as SV_1WireData1 records from which you can retrieve the temperature with CGPS::Get1WireDS18B20celcius() and CGPS::Get1WireDS18B20fahrenheit().
||     18. Activate LCD backlight. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display module that supports turning LDC backlight on.
||     19. Deactivate LCD backlight. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display module that supports turning LDC backlight off.
||     20. Activate LED 1 of an attached display module. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display module that supports turning indicator LED 1 light off.
||     21. Deactivate LED 1 of an attached display module. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display module that supports turning indicator LED 1 light on.
||     22. Toggle LED 1 on an attached display module. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display that supports toggling indicator LED 1 light from off to on or vice versa.
||     23. Take 640x480 photo with camera (Rev5:468 OutputCamSwitch0 / Rev8:175 serial port 1 / First picture taken is directly used without camera tuning first, see also ActionID 66).
||     24. Take 640x480 photo with camera (Rev5:468 OutputCamSwitch1 / Rev8:175 serial port 2 / First picture taken is directly used without camera tuning first, see also ActionID 67).
||     25. Take 640x480 photo with camera (Rev5:468 OutputCamSwitch2 / Rev8:175 serial port 3 / First picture taken is directly used without camera tuning first, see also ActionID 68).
||     26. Take 640x480 photo with camera (Rev5:468 OutputCamSwitch3 / Rev8:161 serial port 4 / First picture taken is directly used without camera tuning first, see also ActionID 69).
||     27. LCD/source-code jump to Index 290. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     28. LCD/source-code jump to Index 291. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     29. LCD/source-code jump to Index 292. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     30. LCD/source-code jump to Index 293. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     31. LCD/source-code jump to Index 294. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     32. LCD/source-code jump to Index 295. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     33. LCD/source-code jump to Index 296. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     34. LCD/source-code jump to Index 297. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     35. LCD/source-code jump to Index 298. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     36. LCD/source-code jump to Index 299. This Index will be executed and continued from there, without automatically jumping back to wherever execution left off. So you may want to use SETTING_PostponeActionJumpWhileExecutingIndexBelow/Above to select an idle/safe Index range in your code to have the jump delayed until an Index in that range is being executed without having your other routines aborted.
||     37. Transmit SV_Acknowledge to server. This is an asynchronous transmission and executed first bypassing current log contents and does not make use of the GPS receiver or other components in the process.
||     38. Wake-up internal GSM modem from power-down for 3 minutes (temporarily overrides "Data logging with GSM off" mode from SETTING_ModuleDataLogging set to MDL_DataLoggingGsmOff).
||     39. Turn+keep internal GPS receiver on for 2 minutes (or different time set with advanced settings SETTING_Action39GpsPowerTimeMoving and SETTING_Action39GpsPowerTimeNotMoving) overriding during that time any possibly active ActionID 73 and/or SETTING_ turning+keeping it off while "power saving mode" is active from SETTING_PowerSavingVoltage.
||     40. [Rev8:109] Set output on serial port 1. This will make the TxD output of the port active high. So you could use the port as an output that provides a driving voltage to an external device. The 3Volt version of this port can even be used to directly power an external indicator LED because the port already has an internal serial resistor.
||     41. [Rev8:109] Reset output on serial port 1. This will make the TxD output of the port inactive low.
||     42. [Rev8:109] Set output on serial port 2. This will make the TxD output of the port active high. So you could use the port as an output that provides a driving voltage to an external device. The 3Volt version of this port can even be used to directly power an external indicator LED because the port already has an internal serial resistor.
||     43. [Rev8:109] Reset output on serial port 2. This will make the TxD output of the port inactive low.
||     44. [Rev8:109] Set output on serial port 3. This will make the TxD output of the port active high. So you could use the port as an output that provides a driving voltage to an external device. The 3Volt version of this port can even be used to directly power an external indicator LED because the port already has an internal serial resistor.
||     45. [Rev8:109] Reset output on serial port 3. This will make the TxD output of the port inactive low.
||     46. [Rev8:109] Set output on serial port 4. This will make the TxD output of the port active high. So you could use the port as an output that provides a driving voltage to an external device. The 3Volt version of this port can even be used to directly power an external indicator LED because the port already has an internal serial resistor.
||     47. [Rev8:109] Reset output on serial port 4. This will make the TxD output of the port inactive low.
||     48. [Rev8:110] Generate motion detection trigger (See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.)
||     49. [Rev8:129] Turn 1-Wire bus off and clear the lists with "attached" 1-Wire and RF devices without logging SV_1WireDetached records for devices on the list. NOTE: Only the 1-Wire bus is turned off, so "attached" RF devices will do that again triggering the EVENT_AttachIButton event and logging a SV_iButton record.
||     50. [Rev8:129] Turn 1-Wire bus on. 1-Wire devices already physically attached now or later to the 1-Wire bus will trigger the EVENT_AttachIButton event and logging a SV_iButton record.
||     51. [Rev8:152] Log SV_1WireDetached record for all 1-Wire bus and RF devices that are in the registered as attached in the internal lists and clears those lists. All devices still "attached" now or later will get enter the lists again, triggering the EVENT_AttachIButton event and logging a SV_iButton record.
||     52. [Rev8:151] Log SV_DigTach1 record. In this record, information determined by the MPM_DigitalTachograph driver enabled with SETTING_ModulePortMode1 for serial port 1 as received from an external tachograph that is connected to it.
||     53. [Rev8:151] Log SV_DigTach1+VIN/VRN(/Card1/Card2). In this record, information determined by the MPM_DigitalTachograph driver enabled with SETTING_ModulePortMode1 for serial port 1 as received from an external tachograph that is connected to it.
||     54. [Rev8:151] Clear tachograph motion/ignition input status. Clear the current last status determined by the MPM_DigitalTachograph driver enabled with SETTING_ModulePortMode1 for serial port 1 as received from an external tachograph that is connected to it.
||     55. [Rev8:153] Log SV_PositionTripMeters record. This action can be used independent (or even together) from the SV_Postion... record type you have selected in the settings with SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType to be used by the ACTION_GpsLog available for any event in the settings or the CGPS::mGpsLog member action from your server.
||     56. [Rev8:153] Log SV_PositionTravelledMeters record. This action can be used independent (or even together) from the SV_Postion... record type you have selected in the settings with SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType to be used by the ACTION_GpsLog available for any event in the settings or the CGPS::mGpsLog member action from your server.
||     57. [Rev8:153] Log SV_PositionAcceleration record. This action can be used independent (or even together) from the SV_Postion... record type you have selected in the settings with SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType to be used by the ACTION_GpsLog available for any event in the settings or the CGPS::mGpsLog member action from your server.
||     58. [Rev8:162] Log SV_PositionAnalogInputs record. This action can be used independent (or even together) from the SV_Postion... record type you have selected in the settings with SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType to be used by the ACTION_GpsLog available for any event in the settings or the CGPS::mGpsLog member action from your server.
||     60. [Rev8:152] Reset trip-meters counter. This action sets the travelled meters count since the "Moving mode" became active back to 0, so the result from CGPS::GetCounterTripMeters() will restart at 0.0. For background information on "Moving mode" see CGPS::GetShake().
||     61. [Rev8:161] Answer incoming phone call. This action is only useful when SETTING_IncomingPhoneCallAction is set to MIPCA_Ignore, so you actually can have the module "pick up phone" while it is receiving rings from an incoming phone call as detected with the EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy... and EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone events. But default SETTING_IncomingPhoneCallAction is set to MIPCA_Reject to already immediately reject every incoming phone call (but phone call will still trigger) which would also be the most logical setting for modules that do not have the voice phone hardware feature and microphone+speaker attached.
||     62. [Rev8:162] Restart automatic accel-sensor calibration/conversion if SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration is enabled. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for additional background information about accel-sensors.
||     63. [Rev8:170] Read contents of "Smart Card Type 1" via reader connected to port 3 set to mode "Serial output" (not "Input/Output") and record it in the log (see CGPS::GetLogDataType() Type 1).
||     64. Reboot module via watchdog. All active/pending actions will be terminated without finishing them and internal components also reset (like disabling the power supply for a few seconds without making changes to the firmware, settings and LCD/Source-code). Note that the internal GSM modem can't nicely unregister from the network first, so the provider of the network may cause some delay before allowing the modem+SIM combination to register themselves onto the network again.
||     65. [Rev8:172] Reset internal GSM/GPRS modem (useful for SMS text only capable SIM-card usage to enforce a renewed network registration daily).
||     66. [Rev8:175] Take 640x480 photo with camera on serial port 1 (internally 4 pictures are taken for camera tuning and best picture is used, see also ActionID 23).
||     67. [Rev8:175] Take 640x480 photo with camera on serial port 2 (internally 4 pictures are taken for camera tuning and best picture is used, see also ActionID 24).
||     68. [Rev8:175] Take 640x480 photo with camera on serial port 3 (internally 4 pictures are taken for camera tuning and best picture is used, see also ActionID 25).
||     69. [Rev8:175] Take 640x480 photo with camera on serial port 4 (internally 4 pictures are taken for camera tuning and best picture is used, see also ActionID 26).
||     70. [Rev8:176] Start ignoring the vibration sensor for motion detection triggers. This action starts a mode in which the SETTING_MinSensorDetectionStartMoving setting of the start value for triggering the "Moving mode" by the vibration sensor is ignored.
