||     71. [Rev8:176] Stop ignoring the vibration sensor for motion detection triggers. Use this action to undo previously executed action 70.
||     72. [Rev8:185] Activate power-down mode. !ADVANCED FEATURE! module including internal components will *ONLY* wake-up by itself again afterwards by the triggers of specifically programmed SETTING_WakeUpBy_... events (settings application section 65) or power returning again after fully being away. If a transfer of the contents of the log is in progress (or even if initiated together with the power-down request), it will wait up to 120 seconds for that to finish first. After/without that, it takes approximately 3 seconds to backup things like current status of processes and I/O, records counters and user counters (see CGPS::CanGetCounters()) into non volatile memory. Then it will power-down internal components from where if those include an internal GSM modem and SIM card with open socket and/or network registration those are closed first and waited allowed up to 25 seconds before powering those down anyway.
||     73. [Rev8:180] Power-down internal GPS receiver, but is only done while "power saving mode" is active (see SETTING_PowerSavingVoltage). So you can have ActionID 73 executed every second (like via a timer event or use SETTING_WhilePowerSaving_GpsPower=1 which has the same effect) and then autmatically have the GPS receiver turned+kept off while "power saving mode" is active and automatically turned+kept on while "power saving mode" is not active. Even all actions to log a record containing GPS receiver derived information like ACTION_GpsLog will also automatically temporarily turn+keep the GPS receiver and (temporarily) wait for it to establish a fix. Also ActionID 39 will temporarily turn+keep the GPS receiver on which you which you specifically want to do like once per half hour or so, to give the GPS receiver the chance to get its internal calculation tables in sync with the rapid changing situation of the GPS satellites, so every time it is turned on temporarily to wait for a fix it will be able to establish one *MUCH* faster and even can establish a fix with much satellites/quality.
||     74. [Rev9:314] Clear previously received CAN-bus data cache. (See also ActionID 75 which records the cache contents into the log first before it clears the data).
||     75. [Rev8:180] Record previously received CAN-bus data cache as SV_Port4Data records in the log, then clear the previously received data. The information stored in the records is what was previously was received via the MPM_CanBus driver from the CAN-bus interface. After the logging, the data is automatically cleared (like ActionID 74 would do too) so next time you log the data you automatically record only the data since the last time you (logged+)cleared the data.
||     76. [Rev8:180] Log user counters. The counters are recorded in the log as SV_CountersUser records. You can use these counters fromm your own LCD/Source-code with module commands like with module commands like INCR and USET.
||     77. [Rev8:192] Clear log contents. This action removes all records from the log that have not (yet) been transferred to the server. This action can take some time to complete depending on the contents of the log at that time.
||     78. [Rev8/9:247] Start transmitting to server via UDP using the same port and format set for TCP transmissions. When no proper acknowledge is received in return from the server to UDP transmissions the module automatically switches back to transmissions via TCP.
||     79. [Rev8/9:247] Stop transmitting to server via UDP.
||     80. [Rev8:193/Rev9:288] Record raw Modbus response to last MODB module command you executed in the log as SV_Port4Data records. Use CGPS::GetPortDataBytes() to retrieve the response bytes from those records.
||     81. [Rev8:231] Activate power to audio amplifier/microphone. Only useful for module types that have such a hardware feature.
||     82. [Rev8:231] Deactivate power to audio amplifier/microphone. Only useful for module types that have such a hardware feature.
||     83. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 1. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern1 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     84. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 2. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern2 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     85. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 3. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern3 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     86. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 4. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern4 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     87. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 5. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern5 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     88. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 6. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern6 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     89. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 7. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern7 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     90. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 8. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern8 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     91. [Rev8:232] Execute all actions that you have set for SETTING_ActionID91 [see also settings application section 55].
||     92. [Rev8:232] Execute all actions that you have set for SETTING_ActionID92 [see also settings application section 55].
||     93. [Rev8:232] Execute all actions that you have set for SETTING_ActionID93 [see also settings application section 55].
||     94. [Rev8:232] Execute all actions that you have set for SETTING_ActionID94 [see also settings application section 55].
||     95. [Rev9:232] Activate internal power supply to internal components and battery charger depending on the module type, also external 5Volt supply.
||     96. [Rev9:232] Deactivate internal power supply to internal components and battery charger depending on the module type, also external 5Volt supply.
||     97. [Rev8/9:233] Copy settings data from non-volatile memory backup to the log (see CGPS::GetLogDataType() Type 2).
||     98. [Rev8/9:233] Copy LCD/Source-code from non-volatile memory backup to the log (see CGPS::GetLogDataType() Type 3).
||     99. [Rev8/9:266] Copy settings data from run-time memory to the log (see CGPS::GetLogDataType() Type 4).
||     100. [Rev8/9:266] Copy LCD/Source-code from run-time memory to the log (see CGPS::GetLogDataType() Type 5).
||     101. [Rev8/9:233] Copy FLASH regions from non-volatile memory backup to the log (see CGPS::GetLogDataType() Type 6).
||     102. [Rev8/9:233] Copy FLASH regions from run-time memory to the log (see CGPS::GetLogDataType() Type 7).
||     103. [Rev8/9:238] Reset internal GPS receiver while preserving backup power. (For GPS receiver types with backup, the runtime calculation tables stay intact and therefore should usually very fast be able to establish a fix again like a hot start).
||     104. [Rev8/9:238] Reset internal GPS receiver including backup power. (The runtime calculation tables will be cleared and have to be rebuild and therefore it will usually it will take longer to establish the first fix again like a cold start).
||     105. [Rev8/9:255] Initiate GSM provider scan with internal Telit modem and store results in System Variables %SN0..%SO3 and %SP2 (takes about 2 seconds after closing a possibly open socket connection first). You can use the System Variables from your own LCD/Source-code in templates or to make decisions with.
||     106. [Rev8/9:293] Request a single FMI PVT packet from a Garmin navigation device. This action will have the MPM_GarminFMI driver that you have set for the serial port request a single PVT packet from an external Garmin device with FMI (Fleet Management Interface) support that you have connected to that serial port of the module.
||     107. [Rev8/9:296] Accident trigger to initiate a copy of the records generated by EVENT_AccidentRecording1/2 in the accident log into the normal log from the number of records logged before you executed the action with SETTING_AccidentRecordingHistoryRecordAmount up to the number of future records you specified with SETTING_AccidentRecordingFutureRecordAmount. [see also settings application section 20].
||     108. [Rev8/9:293] Activate LED 2 of an attached display module. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display module that supports turning indicator LED 2 light off.
||     109. [Rev8/9:293] Deactivate LED 2 of an attached display module. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display module that supports turning indicator LED 2 light on.
||     110. [Rev8/9:293] Toggle LED 2 of an attached display module. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display that supports toggling indicator LED 2 light from off to on or vice versa.
||     111. [Rev8/9:293] Play fixed "beep" sound on attached display module. This request goes via the MPM_LcdKeyboard driver to an attached display that supports playing a sound via it's internal speaker.
||     112. [Rev8/9:???] Reserved for different sound than 111.
||     113. [Rev8/9:326] Re-initialize accel/Gforce-sensor. This is already done automatically so you should actually never need to re-initialize it yourself.
||     114. [Rev9:???] Toggle between SIM-card sockets if multiple are available.
||     115. [Rev9:???] Select SIM-card socket 1.
||     116. [Rev9:???] Select SIM-card socket 2.
||     117. [Rev9:???] Dead-Reckoning forward. Tell GPS receiver with dead-reckoning support that the vehicle is moving forward.
||     118. [Rev9:???] Dead-Reckoning reverse. Tell GPS receiver with dead-reckoning support that the vehicle is moving in reverse.
||     119. [Rev9:334] Activate Sirf GPS power saving mode, consuming about 8 mA when supplying good quality signals from multiple GPS satellites. In this mode the Sirf GPS receiver while it is on, will automatically turn itself off a percentage of the time to save power consumption while still aiming to output a new fix on the GPS satellite every second. Like 0.3 seconds on versus 1.7 seconds off intervals and will automatically adapt this on/off duty cycle up to full time on, depending on determined signal quality. WARNING: This will of course give lower GPS quality output and using settings that filter minimum GPS fix may result in filtering all output of the GPS receiver.
||     120. [Rev9:400] Activate Sirf GPS deep power saving mode, consuming about 4 mA when supplying good quality signals from multiple GPS satellites. Works like the power saving mode described above, but instead aims to output a new fix on the GPS satellites every 4 seconds. Like 0.2 seconds on per 4 seconds for 5% duty cycle, but when the reception goes below 4 sats with at least 30db, it will temporarily turn on full power for a while. WARNING: This will of course give lower GPS quality output and using settings that filter minimum GPS fix may result in filtering all output of the GPS receiver.
||     121. [Rev9:334] Activate Sirf GPS full power mode, consuming about 14 mA when supplying good quality signals from multiple GPS satellites. In this mode the best quality position estimate is determined every second. This is already the default mode which you can use to switch back from a previously activated a power saving mode via ActionID 119 or 120.
||     122. [Rev9:355] Send RF ping with unique serial number (IMEI) using SETTING_RFport1_Channel/Speed/Power/Address settings for virtual RF port 1. Unless an acknowledge request is disabled with SETTING_RFport1_PingNoAckRequest, one is included with the ping and automatically (temporarily) listened+waited+retried for acknowledge in return and the serial number of each responding device is logged in a SV_iButton record.
||     123. [Rev9:370] Send RF ping with unique serial number (IMEI) using SETTING_RFport2_Channel/Speed/Power/Address settings for virtual RF port 2. Unless an acknowledge request is disabled with SETTING_RFport2_PingNoAckRequest, one is included with the ping and automatically (temporarily) listened+waited+retried for acknowledge in return and the serial number of each responding device is logged in a SV_iButton record.
||     124. [Rev9:370] Send RF ping with unique serial number (IMEI) using SETTING_RFport3_Channel/Speed/Power/Address settings for virtual RF port 3. Unless an acknowledge request is disabled with SETTING_RFport3_PingNoAckRequest, one is included with the ping and automatically (temporarily) listened+waited+retried for acknowledge in return and the serial number of each responding device is logged in a SV_iButton record.
||     125. [Rev9:370] Send RF ping with unique serial number (IMEI) using SETTING_RFport4_Channel/Speed/Power/Address settings for virtual RF port 4. Unless an acknowledge request is disabled with SETTING_RFport4_PingNoAckRequest, one is included with the ping and automatically (temporarily) listened+waited+retried for acknowledge in return and the serial number of each responding device is logged in a SV_iButton record.
||     126. [Rev9:370] Enable listening mode of the (optional on-board) RF hardware. This consumes about 12 to 13mA and allows receiption of RF-ping/data from an RF-tag or other module with RF hardware. Port settings to listen with can be switched with actions 152 up/to 155 and automatically turn on the listening hardware part.
||     127. [Rev9:370] Disable listening mode of the (optional on-board) RF hardware.
||     128. [Rev9:370] Log all RF-tag devices of which last receiption was within the delay defined via SETTING_iButtonRemovalDelay.
||     130. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver, using a fixed format including IMEI, EventID = Start Moving, standard message format (including altitude etc.).
||     131. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver, using a fixed format, including IMEI, EventID = Stop Moving, standard message format (including altitude etc.).
||     132. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver, using Data field contents of source code instruction with Index 282. It is expected to contain 3 numbers in the format: "<EventID>,<GPS log type>,<Include IMEI>". As <EventID> use a value identical to those you get from CGPS::GetEventID() on your server from normal transmissions. As <GPS log type> use value 0 for standard position transmission, 1 for the trip meters variant, 2 for the travelled meters variant, etc. to select from the GLST_... options list. For <include IMEI> use value 1 to include the IMEI in the transmitted data or value 0 to not include it and save data transmission size and cost if you already know at the server side which module is connected to that particular Iridium modem anyway.
||     133. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver as ActionID 132 but using Index 283 instead.
||     134. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver as ActionID 132 but using Index 284 instead.
||     135. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver as ActionID 132 but using Index 285 instead.
||     136. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver as ActionID 132 but using Index 286 instead.
||     137. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver as ActionID 132 but using Index 287 instead.
||     138. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver as ActionID 132 but using Index 288 instead.
||     139. [Rev9:377] Transmission via MPM_Iridium driver as ActionID 132 but using Index 289 instead.
||     140. [Rev9:387] ODB-II poll. Requests PIDs 0x05, 0xC0, 0xD0, 0x2F and 0x31 via ODB-II and stores the response in System Variables %SQ4, %SG7, %SG6, %SQ7, %SQ5 and %SQ6 which you can use from your own LCD/source-code.
||     141. [Rev9:387] ODB-II poll all. Requests PIDs 0..254 and records every response as a SV_Port4Data record into the log.
||     142. [Rev9:387] ODB-II poll freeze frame. Requests all items from 'freeze frame' and records every response as a SV_Port4Data record into the log.
||     143. [Rev9:389] Record Sirf GPS ephemeris data into the log (see CGPS::GetLogDataType() Type 8). You can use this data to assist a Sirf GPS receiver in another module to get a fix faster.
||     145. [Rev9:427] GSM scan of all cells of all networks with Quectel modem. The GSM cells that are detected during the scan are recorded in the log in SV_GsmCellScan records. If you are only interrested in GSM cells of the current network, then use ActionID 151 instead.
||     146. [Rev8/9:???] Flush untransmitted records in RAM log to FLASH. This action is performed automatically when needed like when the module reboots, powers down or internal backup-battery reaches empty level. Only if you disconnect the power and there is no internal back-up battery connected, then records still in RAM and not yet transferred to the server get lost. Executing this action before disconnecting the power will save those records (if any), but you do *NOT* want to do that when not needed at some automatic interval, because every write to the FLASH will get you one step closer to its end of its limited life of about 100000 writes.
||     147. [Rev9:428] Clear contents of input buffer for serial port 1. Useful when using the contents from your own LCD/Source-code using System Variable %SS1 while having the port driver mode set to MPM_SerialOut.
||     148. [Rev9:428] Clear contents of input buffer for serial port 2. Useful when using the contents from your own LCD/Source-code using System Variable %SS2 while having the port driver mode set to MPM_SerialOut.
||     149. [Rev9:428] Clear contents of input buffer for serial port 3. Useful when using the contents from your own LCD/Source-code using System Variable %SS3 while having the port driver mode set to MPM_SerialOut.
||     150. [Rev9:428] Clear contents of input buffer for serial port 4. Useful when using the contents from your own LCD/Source-code using System Variable %SS4 while having the port driver mode set to MPM_SerialOut.
||     151. [Rev9:437] GSM cell scan only the cells of the current network with Quectel modem. The GSM cells that are detected during the scan are recorded in the log in SV_GsmCellScan records. If you only up-to 6 cells found in a single receod, then use ActionID 156 instead. If you are also interrested in GSM cells of other networks, then use ActionID 145 instead.
||     152. [Rev9:448] Start RF-hardware listening using port 1 settings (enables SETTING_RFport1_Listen and disables the others but without changing (re)boot settings saved in the module. This action can be useful if you want to switch between different port settings/speeds/channels to scan them for possible receptions. The listen part of the RF hardware can be turned off again with ActionID 127.
||     153. [Rev9:448] Start RF-hardware listening using port 2 settings (enables SETTING_RFport2_Listen and disables the others but without changing (re)boot settings saved in the module. This action can be useful if you want to switch between different port settings/speeds/channels to scan them for possible receptions. The listen part of the RF hardware can be turned off again with ActionID 127.
||     154. [Rev9:448] Start RF-hardware listening using port 3 settings (enables SETTING_RFport3_Listen and disables the others but without changing (re)boot settings saved in the module. This action can be useful if you want to switch between different port settings/speeds/channels to scan them for possible receptions. The listen part of the RF hardware can be turned off again with ActionID 127.
||     155. [Rev9:448] Start RF-hardware listening using port 4 settings (enables SETTING_RFport4_Listen and disables the others but without changing (re)boot settings saved in the module. This action can be useful if you want to switch between different port settings/speeds/channels to scan them for possible receptions. The listen part of the RF hardware can be turned off again with ActionID 127.
||     156. [Rev9:437] GSM cell scan only the cells of the current network with Quectel modem stripped to fit in a single record. Up to 6 GSM cells that are detected during the scan are recorded in the log in SV_GsmCellScanTrim records. If you want possible additional found cells too, use ActionID 151 instead. If you are also interrested in GSM cells of other networks, then use ActionID 145 instead.
||     157. [Rev9:508] Simulate GPS module output (next to normal unaffected internal use of it, also) as incoming serial port 3 data for 10 seconds since you executed this action. Executing this action an interval of less than 10 seconds would give you a continous serial input stream. Having SETTING_ModulePortMode3/4 set to MPM_SerialInOut would record the data in the log into SV_Port4Data records for use at your server. But also MPM_SerialOut is possible for use in your own LCD/Source-code.
||     165. [Rev9:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 9. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern9 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     166. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 10. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern10 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     167. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 11. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern11 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
||     168. [Rev8:232] Start/prolong signal pattern 12. With this action you start the pattern for the outputs and LEDs you defined with SETTING_SignalPattern12 for the time you have set, or when the pattern is already/still running, keep it running for that time you have set. [see also settings application section 63].
====



|| *** Event definitions ***
|| Actions for these events can be retrieved/written by the CGPSsettings::GetEventAction...() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAction...() functions.
|| Some events additionally have programmable conditions that can be retrieved/written with their respective CGPSsettings::GetEvent...() and CGPSsettings::SetEvent...() functions.

  • EVENT_IO_1A// First event for the digital input/output 1 state (equivalent of 1st event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 1 or a voltage connected to Input 1 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput1 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput1. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_1B// Second event for the digital input/output 1 state (equivalent of 2nd event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 1 or a voltage connected to Input 1 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput1, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput1, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput1 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput1. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_2A// First event for the digital input/output 2 state (equivalent of 3rd event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 2 or a voltage connected to Input 2 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput2 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput2. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_2B// Second event for the digital input/output 2 state (equivalent of 4th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 2 or a voltage connected to Input 2 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput2, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput2, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput2 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput2. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_3A// First event for the digital input/output 3 state (equivalent of 5th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 3 or a voltage connected to Input 3 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput3 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput3. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_3B// Second event for the digital input/output 3 state (equivalent of 6th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 3 or a voltage connected to Input 3 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput3, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput3, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput3 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput3. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal IBST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_4A// First event for the digital input/output 4 state (equivalent of 7th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 4 or a voltage connected to Input 4 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput4 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput4. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal I4BST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_IO_4B// Second event for the digital input/output 4 state (equivalent of 8th event line in section 11 of the settings application) which you can program to a IOES_... type triggering for the digital state of Output 4 or a voltage connected to Input 4 of which you want the analog level behavior to be monitored with your analog levels set with SETTING_FilterLevelInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput4, SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayUpFlankInput4, SETTING_UseSettleDelayDownFlankInput4 and SETTING_SettleDelayTimeInput4. But if you want, you can virtually connect the input to some internal I4BST_... simulated voltage instead.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_1// Timer/Counter 1 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_2// Timer/Counter 2 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_3// Timer/Counter 3 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_4// Timer/Counter 4 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_5// Timer/Counter 5 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_6// Timer/Counter 6 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_7// Timer/Counter 7 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIMERS_8// Timer/Counter 8 event that triggers every time the (not)moving condition is reached. It then triggers an event and then resets itself automatically (unless suppressed with SETTING_SingleTriggerTimer) to automatically start counting all over again. For the programmable conditions and examples, see documentation of CGPSsettings::GetEventTimers() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimers() method functions.
  • EVENT_TIME_1// Time of day event 1. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTime() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTime() functions.
  • EVENT_TIME_2// Time of day event 2. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTime() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTime() functions.
  • EVENT_TIMES_1// Event that triggers every 2 seconds while between two day times. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTimes() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimes() functions.
  • EVENT_TIMES_2// Event that triggers every 2 seconds while between two day times. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventTimes() and CGPSsettings::SetEventTimes() functions.
  • EVENT_StartMoving// Triggers when entering "moving mode". See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • EVENT_WhileMoving// Triggers every second while "moving mode" is active. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • EVENT_StopMoving// Triggers when entering "not moving mode". See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • EVENT_WhileNotMoving// Triggers every second while "moving mode" is not active. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • EVENT_SPEED_Above// Triggers only once (see EVENT_SPEED_Below) when the lowest GPS speed of last 5 seconds is above the above-speed. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventSpeed() and CGPSsettings::SetEventSpeed() functions. See also SETTING_SpeedAboveEventSamples.
  • EVENT_SPEED_Below// Triggers only once and re-enables the EVENT_SPEED_Above when the speed becomes lower again than the below-speed. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventSpeed() and CGPSsettings::SetEventSpeed() functions.
  • EVENT_DISTANCE_1// Travelled distance event. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventDistance() and CGPSsettings::SetEventDistance() functions. See also SETTING_ResetDistanceEventPerGpsLog.
  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 4. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled, unless you also have SETTING_TriggerCalledByPhone1ForAnyNumber activated in which case the event will trigger to to a phone call with any CallerID event which you could use for example execute ActionID 27 up-to 36 to execute your own LCD/Source-code and decide how to act to incoming call of which the CallerID number is then in "System Variable" %S44. See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy1.
  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy2// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 5. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled. See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy2.
  • EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy3// This event triggers when the given phone number matches the CallerID of an incoming phone call (if no CallerID is included with the incoming phone call, EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone will trigger instead). Of the phone number you use as condition for the event with the CGPSsettings::SetEventPhone() and CGPSsettings::GetEventPhone() functions, actually the beginning is compared to the beginning of the CallerID, so if you for example enter only "1234" then the event will trigger to any phone number that begins with "1234". But if you use a full phone number in international format, you can also send SMS text messages as an alert to the number with ACTION_SmsAlertIncomingKnown1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlertCalledBy1 or with module mommand SACT and make a phone call to it by executing ActionID 6. If you set the phone number condition of this event to an empty string then the event is disabled, See also SETTING_DigitsCheckCalledBy3.
  • EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone// This event triggers on incoming phone calls that do not include CallerID (like when the CallerID feature of the telecom provider is disabled) or the CallerID contents does not match the number set as condition for the EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy... events.
  • EVENT_RestartModule// (Re)start of the module. You can for example ahve this event execute something like ACTION_Output1=RACD_DigitalOutput_Disable to make sure a digital output is set to a state you want instead of having allowing it to resume a previous state. It is advised to enable ACTION_GpsLog for this event to turn on the GPS receiver even though it may not determine position to go into that record in time, but can help to have position and time available as soon as possible afterward. More info at CGPS::GetUtcTime().
  • EVENT_PowerSaving// This event triggers every second while power-saving mode is active. Useful event actions for this event are ActionID 73 to turn/keep the GPS receiver off and ACTION_ResetTimer... to prevent timer events from triggering.
  • EVENT_PowerDown// Entering power-down status event (automatically power down in 3 minutes).
  • EVENT_ServerTransmitSuccess// Event that triggers for transfer of records to the server that resulted in a succesful acknowledge in return.
  • EVENT_HEADING_Degrees// Heading direction change event. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHeadingDegrees() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHeadingDegrees() functions and also SETTING_HeadingDegreesRelativity.
  • EVENT_VOLTAGE_Below// While power supply voltage below events. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventVoltage() and CGPSsettings::SetEventVoltage() functions.
  • EVENT_VOLTAGE_Above// While power supply voltage above events. Programmable condition: see CGPSsettings::GetEventVoltage() and CGPSsettings::SetEventVoltage() functions.
  • EVENT_AttachIButton// When an iButton gets attached event. NOTE: Even if no actions are set for this event, a SV_iButton record is logged unless disabled with SETTING_DoNotLog1WireAttach.
  • EVENT_DetachIButton// When an iButton gets detached event. NOTE: Even if no actions are set for this event, a SV_1WireDetached record is logged unless disabled with SETTING_DoNotLog1WireDetach.
  • EVENT_ReceivedGpsFix// When the GPS receiver determines a fix on the GPS satellites (usually every second).
  • EVENT_OutputsStatusChange// When the status of one of the selected outputs changes. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventOutputsStatusChange() and CGPSsettings::SetEventOutputsStatusChange() functions.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in positive direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XPmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in positive direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XNmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_XNmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the X-directions sensor for in negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Y-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Ymin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Y-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Zmax// The hysteresis-maximum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Z-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_ACCELERATION_Zmin// The hysteresis-minimum G-force value from 0.0g (disabled) up-to 6.0g to monitor the Z-directions sensor for in positive and negative direction. Use CGPSsettings::GetEventAcceleration() and CGPSsettings::SetEventAcceleration() functions and see also SETTING_AutoAccelSensorOrientationCalibration. See CGPS::GetAccelerationX() for detailed background information.
  • EVENT_WhileRoaming// [Rev8:127] Event that triggers every second while the (usually cheaper) GSM home network of the used SIM-card is not available for data transmissions to the server (e.g. out of the country).
  • EVENT_DigTachReceivedValidData// [Rev8:151] Event triggers every time the tachograph delivers data (usually every second).
  • EVENT_DigTachStatusChanges// [Rev8:151] Event triggers when one or more of the selected DTDCEBM_... status changes occur in the tachograph output data. See also CGPSsettings::SetEventDigTachStatusChange().
  • EVENT_DigTachWhileIgnitionActive// [Rev8:151] Event triggers every second while the "ignition state=on" is detected in the data of the tachograph.
  • EVENT_SPEED_DigTachAbove// [Rev8:151] Event triggers when tachograph speed exceeds this speed or exceeds the speed of its last trigger (process restarts after EVENT_SPEED_DigTachBelow has triggered). Value 0=event disabled.
  • EVENT_SPEED_DigTachBelow// [Rev8:151] After this event triggers once after EVENT_SPEED_DigTachAbove has triggered and the speed dropped again to at least the given value. Value 0=event disabled.
  • EVENT_GpsCurrentOutOfRangeStart// [Rev8:180] Event that triggers (only on supporting hardware) when the actual GPS current is outside the SETTING_GPScurrentMin / SETTING_GPScurrentMax range. This event is postponed from triggering again after EVENT_GpsCurrentOutOfRangeEnd triggered until the delay time of SETTING_GPScurrentDelay has passed.
  • EVENT_GpsCurrentOutOfRangeEnd// [Rev8:180] Event that triggers (only on supporting hardware) after EVENT_GpsCurrentOutOfRangeStart triggered and current becomes inside the SETTING_GPScurrentMin / SETTING_GPScurrentMax range again.
  • EVENT_GpsCurrentWhileOutOfRange// [Rev8:180] Event that triggers (only on supporting hardware) every second WHILE the actual GPS current is outside the SETTING_GPScurrentMin / SETTING_GPScurrentMax range. This event is postponed from triggering again after EVENT_GpsCurrentOutOfRangeEnd triggered until the delay time of SETTING_GPScurrentDelay has passed.
  • EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterAbove// [Rev8:233] Event that triggers every second while the pulses per second measured by the hardware pulse counter is above the supplied condition value. Condition value can be in the range of 1..65000 (=1Hz...65kHz) and value 0 disables the event. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHertz() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHertz() functions.
  • EVENT_HERTZ_PulseCounterBelowOrEqual// [Rev8:233] Event that triggers every second while the pulses per second measured by the hardware pulse counter is below or equal to the supplied condition value. Condition value can be in the range of 1..65000 (=1Hz...65kHz) and value 0 disables the event. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventHertz() and CGPSsettings::SetEventHertz() functions.
  • EVENT_InputPattern1// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #1 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.
  • EVENT_InputPattern2// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #2 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.
  • EVENT_InputPattern3// [Rev8:234] Input pattern event #3 that triggers to a digital active/inactive state pattern of an input/button. Programmable conditions: see CGPSsettings::GetEventInputPattern() and CGPSsettings::SetEventInputPattern() functions.
  • EVENT_AccidentRecording1// [Rev8/9:296] Event that stores records it generates via actions ACTION_GpsLog and/or ActionID 55...58 into a accident log in RAM instead of into the normal log. For the loggin interval use CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval() and CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(). Then whenever you execute ActionID 107 (like when an accident occurrs), the amount of history records specified by you with SETTING_AccidentRecordingHistoryRecordAmount up to the number of future records you specified with SETTING_AccidentRecordingFutureRecordAmount are copied into the normal log which from there can be transferred to your server or later exported from there via a settings cable. NOTE: If this event is in use on Rev8 series modules, then all photo camera related features will not function anymore.
  • EVENT_AccidentRecording2// [Rev8/9:296] Event that stores records it generates via actions ACTION_GpsLog and/or ActionID 55...58 into a accident log in RAM instead of into the normal log. For the loggin interval use CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval() and CGPSSettings::GetEventAccidentRecordingInterval(). Then whenever you execute ActionID 107 (like when an accident occurrs), the amount of history records specified by you with SETTING_AccidentRecordingHistoryRecordAmount up to the number of future records you specified with SETTING_AccidentRecordingFutureRecordAmount are copied into the normal log which from there can be transferred to your server or later exported from there via a settings cable. NOTE: If this event is in use on Rev8 series modules, then all photo camera related features will not function anymore.
  • EVENT_LoggedSerialData// [Rev8/9:296] Event that triggers when serial data is recorded into the log with a Switch value of SV_Port1Data, SV_Port2Data, SV_Port3Data or SV_Port4Data record. For serial data you do not record in the log, you will want to use EVENT_ReceivedSerialData instead.
  • EVENT_ReceivedSerialData// [Rev9:408] Event that triggers when data is received (but not necessarily recorded in the log as with EVENT_LoggedSerialData) via any of the serial ports that can be selected via CGPSsettings::GetEventReceivedSerialData() and CGPSsettings::SetEventReceivedSerialData().

====



|| *** Setting definitions ***
|| For use with CGPSsettings::GetSetting() and CGPSsettings::SetSetting() functions.

  • SETTING_PowerSavingVoltage// Enter power saving mode when main power supply drops below this voltage (module automatically uses overriding level set for SETTING_PowerSavingVoltageBackup while running from internal battery). See CGPS::GetAccu() for additional info.
  • SETTING_PowerDownVoltage// Power-down when main power supply drops below this voltage (module automatically uses overriding level set for SETTING_PowerDownVoltageBackup while running from internal battery). See CGPS::GetAccu() for additional info.
  • SETTING_PowerUpVoltage// Power-up again when the main power supply rises again above this voltage (module automatically uses overriding level set for SETTING_PowerUpVoltageBackup while running from internal battery). See CGPS::GetAccu() for additional info.
  • SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween// If set to boolean TRUE, delivers motion triggers while power supply voltage is between SETTING_MovingMinVoltage and SETTING_MovingMaxVoltage. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween2// [Rev8:127] If set to boolean TRUE, delivers motion triggers while power supply voltage is between SETTING_MovingMinVoltage2 and SETTING_MovingMaxVoltage2. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_MovingOnSensorDetect// [Rev5:300/Rev8:117] If set to boolean TRUE, motion triggers are given when the OPTIONAL internal sensor [Rev5:Vibration/Rev8:AccelGforce] detects movement. For Rev8 this setting also involves parameters in SETTING_MinSensorDetectionStartMoving/SETTING_MinSensorDetectionKeepMoving. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_MovingOnGpsDelta// [Rev5:300/Rev8:158] If set to boolean TRUE, deliver a motion trigger when GPS determined speed (lowest of the last 5 received fixes) is above a certain speed threshold. For Rev8 and above you can set your own speed threshold with SETTING_MinimumGpsSpeedForMotionDetection of which 10Kmh is the minimum advised speed threshold which is the also the fixed default for the Rev5 series. WARNING: without GPS signal or GPS switched off (like in power-saving mode) no triggers are possible. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_MovingInputDetection// Deliver a motion trigger depending on MMID_... definitions. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_MovingMinVoltage// Minimum voltage setting for SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween.
  • SETTING_MovingMaxVoltage// Maximum voltage setting for SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween.
  • SETTING_MovingMinVoltage2// [Rev8:127] Minimum voltage setting for SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween2.
  • SETTING_MovingMaxVoltage2// [Rev8:127] Maximum voltage setting for SETTING_MovingWhenPowerBetween2.
  • SETTING_MovingVoltageChange// Power supply voltage level change that will activate a "moving/not moving" state trigger. Use 0.0 for disabled. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_MotionDetectionSecondsTimeout// Timeout value in seconds to set runtime decrementing motion counter to when an enabled motion detection triggers. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_DoNotSendInternalStatusMessages// Boolean TRUE to not log the occurrence of a problem with GSM/SIM/server in informative log SV_InternalStatus1/2 records. Highly recommended to use Boolean FALSE (default) to do log and transmit internal status records otherwise you will not be informed about any problems and causes.
  • SETTING_AcknowledgeSmsToIncomingCallsAndSms// Boolean TRUE tells the module to send an SMS text message to the phone number of every incoming phone call or SMS text message.
  • SETTING_MaxBatchTransmission// The "Maximum batch size" that the module is allowed to combine available records in the log at transmission time to be sent batched together in a single transmission to the server. Allowed values are 1 (=minimum) up to 42 (Rev5 firmware older than 487 supports up to 16 maximum).
  • SETTING_DoNotOverWriteFullLog// If set to boolean TRUE, the module stops logging when the log is full (instead of overwriting it from the oldest log entry). See also SETTING_LogItemsLimit.
  • SETTING_DisableModuleIndicatorLEDs// If set to boolean TRUE, the module will not power the indicator LED's anymore from a minute after power-up.
  • SETTING_DisableGpsConfirmation// [Rev5 only] If set to boolean TRUE, then received GPS information will not be checked if it is valid and can lead to occasional wrong system date and time. Disabling this check is not recommended.
  • SETTING_DisableSpeedAboveEventRegions// ***DEPRICATED*** If set to boolean TRUE, "Speed above ..." events are disabled when inside region 1..25.
  • SETTING_FasterSocketClosing// [Rev5 only] If set to boolean TRUE, the GPRS socket closed faster e.g. for proper CallerID detection of incoming phone calls.
  • SETTING_MaximumPowerSaving// [Rev5 only] If set to boolean TRUE, everything in favor of less power consuming will be done (e.g. solar powered).
  • SETTING_ForceSpeedToZeroWhenNotMoving// If set to boolean TRUE, GPS speed will be patched to 0.0 while in "not moving" state. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_AlertSmsPositionFormat// If set to boolean TRUE, GPS position format of System Variables %S14 and %S15 in SMS text messages and other template output will be in 123N12'12" like format, instead of -123.12345.
  • SETTING_UseGsmPowerSaving// [Rev5 only] If set to boolean TRUE, GSM power saving is used for less power consumption. Do NOT enable this feature for IMEI 352228...
  • SETTING_SeparateEventIdTransmissions// If set to boolean TRUE, multiple events are not combined in to a single transmissions with a combined EventID.
  • SETTING_SubstituteTemperatureWithExternalDS18B20// If set to boolean TRUE, external DS18B20/DS18S20/DS1822 temperature on the 1-Wire bus is used in transmissions like SV_Position instead of internal sensor.
  • SETTING_SendSettingsWhenChanged// ***CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED*** If set to boolean TRUE, the module will transmit its settings date when changed via a SV_LogDataHeader followed by additional records containing the actual data. See function CGPS::GetLogDataBytes() for a background description.
  • SETTING_GsmAutoBanding// [Rev5:468/Rev8:175] GSM bands that are scanned when looking for available networks. See: GAB_... definitions.
  • SETTING_MinRegionDetectAccuracyValue// Minimum position accuracy in meters with a probability of 67% for GPS output used for region protection. All GPS receiver output with a lower accuracy value than this filter is set to will be ignored for region protection as if the receiver does not have a fix on the satellites. Value 0 disables the filter, the ONLY other possible values are 2 up-to 25 for which you can use the following formula to convert to meters "(float)((pow((float)1.1, (float)VALUE)-(float)1.0)*(float)10.0)". See documentation of CGPSsettings::GetSetting() and CGPSsettings::SetSetting() functions for an example for similar filter SETTING_MinPositionAccuracyValue that is used for all GPS receiver output.
  • SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto// If set to boolean TRUE, SV_PhotoGps/SV_PhotoGpsLog transmissions will be done instead of SV_Photo/SV_PhotoLog.
  • SETTING_MinimumSatellitesForRegionDetection// Minimum GPS fix satellites required to trigger region events. 0=Firmware default=minimal 7 satellites, possible user overrides 1 up-to 10. See CGPSsettings::SetEventRegion() function documentation for background information about regions in general.
  • SETTING_IgnoreSmsCommands// If set to boolean TRUE, the module will not perform commands that are received via SMS.
  • SETTING_ModuleDataLogging// Module data logging mode. Enable/disable server transmission. See MDL_... definitions.
  • SETTING_AccessPointName// APN name your provider supplies for your specific SIM card to be able to open a data session with in order to transfer data over the internet to your server. When supplying details that are not accepted by your provider, the module will (unless you enable SETTING_NoAutomaticApnOverride) automatically try various other common details too if those are accepted. To make sure you do not get extra delays and even extra data charges from your provider, you will always want to enter the correct details supplied by your SIM card provider.
  • SETTING_AccessPointLogin// APN login your provider supplies for your specific SIM card to be able to open a data session with in order to transfer data over the internet to your server. When supplying details that are not accepted by your provider, the module will (unless you enable SETTING_NoAutomaticApnOverride) automatically try various other common details too if those are accepted. To make sure you do not get extra delays and even extra data charges from your provider, you will always want to enter the correct details supplied by your SIM card provider.
  • SETTING_AccessPointPassword// APN password your provider supplies for your specific SIM card to be able to open a data session with in order to transfer data over the internet to your server. When supplying details that are not accepted by your provider, the module will (unless you enable SETTING_NoAutomaticApnOverride) automatically try various other common details too if those are accepted. To make sure you do not get extra delays and even extra data charges from your provider, you will always want to enter the correct details supplied by your SIM card provider.
  • SETTING_GprsTransmitInterval// Interval in seconds for automatic triggers to start process of transferring the contents of the log to to the server. 1=Every second=immediately when something is added to the log. A higher interval time allows multiple records to get accumulated in the log to automatically get combined as a batch (up to SETTING_MaxBatchTransmission size) and save overall data usage on your SIM-card. NOTES: This interval timer is disabled/ignored when a data logging mode is activated (SETTING_ModuleDataLogging) and then only triggers you specifically produce yourself with ACTION_TransmitLog start a transfer of the log contents to the server.
  • SETTING_PrimaryServerDomain// [Rev8:109] Optional domain name of the primary server. If a non empty string is supplied, for first transmission after start-up, the DNS server details from the SIM-card are used to connect+query that server to translate given domain name into an IP. If a usable IP is returned and turns out connection+transmitting data there results in a proper response, then the module will keep using that IP (until power-down/restart/problems), otherwise it will try with the IP you supplied instead. This can be useful if you do not have a static IP or you change IP in the future, but for projects in which you make the module power-down or reboot logically costs extra time, power consumption and data for every time finding the IP of a domain name and would be a waste if the IP the domain name is registered to never changes anyway.
  • SETTING_SecondaryServerDomain// [Rev8:109] Optional domain name of the secondary server. If a non empty string is supplied, for first transmission after start-up, the DNS server details from the SIM-card are used to connect+query that server to translate given domain name into an IP. If a usable IP is returned and turns out connection+transmitting data there results in a proper response, then the module will keep using that IP (until power-down/restart/problems), otherwise it will try with the IP you supplied instead. This can be useful if you do not have a static IP or you change IP in the future, but for projects in which you make the module power-down or reboot logically costs extra time, power consumption and data for every time finding the IP of a domain name and would be a waste if the IP the domain name is registered to never changes anyway.
  • SETTING_PrimaryServerIP// IP of the primary server. Set to value 0 to disable. See CGPSsettings::GetSetting() and CGPSsettings::SetSetting() function documentation for example.
  • SETTING_SecondaryServerIP// As SETTING_PrimaryServerIP, but for the secondary server. Module switches to this server if primary server does not properly respond for 5 minutes.
  • SETTING_PrimaryServerTcpPort// The TCP port number to be used to transmit to the primary server.
  • SETTING_SecondaryServerTcpPort// The TCP port number to be used to transmit to the secondary server.
  • SETTING_PrimaryTcpDataFormat// TCP transmit format to the primary server. %s will be replaced by data. HTTP server compatible example ("carriage return" and "line feed" in example are written as escaped characters): GET /YourScript.php?YourVariableName=%s HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: www.YourHost.com\r\n\r\n
  • SETTING_SecondaryTcpDataFormat// Same description as for SETTING_PrimaryTcpDataFormat, but for the secondary server. If you do not have a secondary server, then set this identical to SETTING_PrimaryTcpDataFormat.
  • SETTING_PrimaryTcpExtraDataFormat// TCP transmit format for extra data like photos to the primary server. Markers: %s=data, %d=size of extra data, %x=binary extra data in octet-stream format.
  • SETTING_SecondaryTcpExtraDataFormat// Same description as for SETTING_PrimaryTcpExtraDataFormat, but for the secondary server. If you do not have a secondary server, then set this identical to SETTING_PrimaryTcpExtraDataFormat.
  • SETTING_PrimaryServerUdpPort// ***CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED*** The UDP port number to be used to transmit to the primary server.
  • SETTING_SecondaryServerUdpPort// ***CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED*** The UDP port number to be used to transmit to the secondary server.
  • SETTING_SendGpsLogWhenRoaming// ***CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED*** Log transmission to the server (or not) when the SIM card is registered onto a network other than that of it's own provider. Contents: SGLWR_... definitions.
  • SETTING_SmsServerPhone// ***CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED*** Phone number of SMS-gateway/server or empty string for disabled. In international format, like 31612345678 for Dutch mobile phone number 06-12345678.
  • SETTING_SmsTransmitInterval// ***CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED*** Interval in seconds for automatic log transmission to the server. 0=Disabled, 1=Fastest.
  • SETTING_SmsAlertMinimumInterval// !!!DEPRECATED!!! All firmware versions since mid Rev5 series and all firmware and hardware versions ignore this setting.
  • SETTING_SmsAlertPhone1// Phone number 1 to which an SMS text message as alert can be sent as ACTION_SmsAlert1 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlert1 or with the SACT command. The phone number must be a string in international format like "31612345678" for Dutch mobile phone number "06-12345678" or an empty "" string to be disabled. See CGPSsettings::SetSetting() and CGPSsettings::GetSetting() documentation for an example. You can also initiate a phone call to the number by executing ActionID 1.
  • SETTING_SmsAlertPhone2// Phone number 2 to which an SMS text message as alert can be sent as ACTION_SmsAlert2 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlert1 or with the SACT command. The phone number must be a string in international format like "31612345678" for Dutch mobile phone number "06-12345678" or an empty "" string to be disabled. See CGPSsettings::SetSetting() and CGPSsettings::GetSetting() documentation for an example. You can also initiate a phone call to the number by executing ActionID 2.
  • SETTING_SmsAlertPhone3// Phone number 3 to which an SMS text message as alert can be sent as ACTION_SmsAlert3 for any EVENT_..., or from the server via CGPS::mSmsAlert1 or with the SACT command. The phone number must be a string in international format like "31612345678" for Dutch mobile phone number "06-12345678" or an empty "" string to be disabled. See CGPSsettings::SetSetting() and CGPSsettings::GetSetting() documentation for an example. You can also initiate a phone call to the number by executing ActionID 3.
  • SETTING_GmtOffsetInQuarters// Number of 15-minute time zone periods to add to UTC time in SMS messages. e.g. -40 for -10:00 Hawaii / 4 for +1:00 Central Europe / 48 for +12:00 New Zealand
  • SETTING_GsmDataPhone// ***CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED*** Phone number of GSM-data server or empty string for disabled. In international format, like 31612345678 for Dutch mobile phone number 06-12345678.
  • SETTING_GsmDataTransmitInterval// ***CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED*** Interval in seconds for automatic log transmission to the server. 0=Disabled, 1=Fastest.
  • SETTING_TransmitLogWhenGpsRecordsReaches// Transmit log contents when this number of records is reached. Contents: 0 for disabled, Rev5 1 up to 5000, Rev8 1 up to 50000. See also SETTING_LogItemsLimit.
  • SETTING_LogItemsLimit// Maximum number of items that the log can contain. When the limit is reached, unsent items are overwritten starting with the oldest item (unless disabled with SETTING_DoNotOverWriteFullLog). Possible values: 0 for disabled and use real hardware log, or value 2 up to 50000 for Rev8 and newer series modules, or value 2 up to 5000 for older module revision series.
  • SETTING_SocketTimeout// GPRS socket timeout in seconds, closes open connection to the server after this time without in/out-going GPRS data. 0=Firmware default timeout.
  • SETTING_KeepAliveTimeOutSecs// Time-out in seconds while "Power Saving mode" is not active, for action to log a record that include details from GPS-receiver output (like initiated with ACTION_GpsLog) not wait more than give time-out for data based on an assumed GPS-fix to come out of the GPS receiver (turning+keeping it on that time if needed). If the GPS receiver cant establish a fix withing given time-out, then instead of a SV_Position... record, a SV_KeepAlive... (or SV_TimeAlive... depending on SETTING_UseSystemTimeForKeepAlive) is recorded in the log instead. The timeout time in seconds by default is set to 0=Recommended firmware default timeout=5seconds.
  • SETTING_KeepAliveTimeOutSecsPowerSaving// Same as SETTING_KeepAliveTimeOutSecs, but this provided timeout in seconds is used while "Power Saving mode" is active (see SETTING_PowerSavingVoltage) and since assumed is that you in that situation also actively had the GPS receiver turned off, with the recommended default value 0=Recommended firmware default timeout=20seconds.
  • SETTING_RestartGpsTimeOutMins// [Rev5 only] Restart GPS when no position is available for xxx minutes. 0=Firmware default timeout (recommended).
  • SETTING_RestartGpsTimeOutMinsPowerSaving// [Rev5 only] Same as SETTING_RestartGpsTimeOutMins, but while in "power-saving" mode. 0=Firmware default timeout (recommended).
  • SETTING_CleanGpsInfoTimeOutMins// [Rev5 only] Clean GPS receiver runtime data (=cold start) when xxx minutes without a valid position. 0=Firmware default timeout (recommended).
  • SETTING_CleanGpsInfoTimeOutMinsPowerSaving// [Rev5 only] Same as SETTING_CleanGpsInfoTimeOutMins, but while in "power-saving" mode. 0=Firmware default timeout (recommended).
  • SETTING_PowerDownGpsTimeOutMins// [Rev5 only] Power down GPS receiver when xxx minutes without a position request. 0=Firmware default timeout (recommended).
  • SETTING_PowerDownGpsTimeOutMinsPowerSaving// [Rev5 only] Same as SETTING_PowerDownGpsTimeOutMins, but while in "power-saving" mode. 0=Firmware default timeout (recommended).
  • SETTING_RebootWithoutServerConnectionSeconds// Reboot internal GSM-module when no successful server transmission has been made within xxx seconds. 0=Firmware default value (recommended).
  • SETTING_RebootOnDelayedTransmissionInSeconds// Reboot module when server transmission is delayed for xxx seconds. 0=Firmware default timeout (recommended). 1..65400=seconds. 65401..65499=days. 65501..65536=weeks.
  • SETTING_SocketClosureDelaySecs// Maximum number of seconds to keep the connection to server open after a transmission. The next transmission will re-use the same connection when still open.
  • SETTING_ModulePortMode1// Mode for port 1. See MPM_... definitions.
  • SETTING_ModulePortMode2// Mode for port 2. See MPM_... definitions.
  • SETTING_ModulePortMode3// Mode for port 3. See MPM_... definitions.
  • SETTING_ModulePortMode4// Mode for port 4. See MPM_... definitions.
  • SETTING_ModulePortProtocol1// Protocol for port 1. See MPP_... definitions. !!!NOTE!!! protocol must be set the same for ports: Rev5: 1,2,3,4 / Rev8: 1&2 and 3&4.
  • SETTING_ModulePortProtocol2// Protocol for port 2. See MPP_... definitions. !!!NOTE!!! protocol must be set the same for ports: Rev5: 1,2,3,4 / Rev8: 1&2 and 3&4.
  • SETTING_ModulePortProtocol3// Protocol for port 3. See MPP_... definitions. !!!NOTE!!! protocol must be set the same for ports: Rev5: 1,2,3,4 / Rev8: 1&2 and 3&4.
  • SETTING_ModulePortProtocol4// Protocol for port 4. See MPP_... definitions. !!!NOTE!!! protocol must be set the same for ports: Rev5: 1,2,3,4 / Rev8: 1&2 and 3&4.
  • SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate1// Baud rate for port 1. See MPB_... definitions. !!!NOTE!!! baud rate must be set the same for ports: Rev5: 1,2,3,4 / Rev8: 1&2 and 3&4.
  • SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate2// Baud rate for port 2. See MPB_... definitions. !!!NOTE!!! baud rate must be set the same for ports: Rev5: 1,2,3,4 / Rev8: 1&2 and 3&4.
  • SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate3// Baud rate for port 3. See MPB_... definitions. !!!NOTE!!! baud rate must be set the same for ports: Rev5: 1,2,3,4 / Rev8: 1&2 and 3&4.
  • SETTING_ModulePortBaudrate4// Baud rate for port 4. See MPB_... definitions. !!!NOTE!!! baud rate must be set the same for ports: Rev5: 1,2,3,4 / Rev8: 1&2 and 3&4.
  • SETTING_PortDataBufferingTimeout// [Rev8:233] Buffer time in 160 millisecond units to gather incoming serial port data to store together in the same log record to save space and transmission overhead. Possible values are 0 for firmware default of 1 second, 1(=0.16sec) up to 15(=2.4sec) or since Rev9:413 1(=0.16sec) up-to 255(=40.8sec).
  • SETTING_AnalogInput1and2NOTdigital// [Rev5 only] If set to Boolean TRUE, digital input 1 & 2 hardware is modified to analog input 1 & 2 instead.
  • SETTING_AnalogInput3and4NOTdigital// [Rev5 only] If set to Boolean TRUE, digital input 3 & 4 hardware is modified to analog input 3 & 4 instead.
  • SETTING_AnalogInputLoggingWithCounters// If set to Boolean TRUE, the analog input levels are also included with every "ACTION_CountersLog" with a Switch value type: SV_CountersAnalogInputs.
  • SETTING_AnalogInput_LowPassFilter_Disabled// If set to Boolean TRUE, fast voltage changes (peaks and spikes) are not filtered from the analog input measurements.
  • SETTING_GpsLogSwitchType// Switch Value type to use with ACTION_GpsLog and CGPS::mGpsLog. See GLST_... definitions.
  • SETTING_NoGpsLogsWithUndefinedEventId// [Rev5 only] Do not create log items with undefined EventID value of 0 for ACTION_GpsLog and CGPS::mGpsLog. For more info see CGPS::GetEventID().
  • SETTING_UseSystemTimeForKeepAlive// If set to Boolean TRUE, SV_TimeAlive are created in the log instead of SV_KeepAlive when there is no GPS-fix is available.
  • SETTING_DoNotLogReceivedSmsEvent// If set to Boolean TRUE, no SV_ReceivedSMS is created in the log when an SMS is received.
  • SETTING_DoNotLogCalledByEvent// If set to Boolean TRUE, no SV_CalledByKnownPhoneNumber/SV_CalledByUnknownPhoneNumber is created in the log for incoming phone calls.
  • SETTING_LogPhotos// If set to Boolean TRUE, pictures will be stored in the log as SV_PhotoLog or SV_PhotoGpsLog (depends on SETTING_IncludeGpsPositionWithPhoto) followed by as many SV_PhotoLogData records for the data as required.
  • SETTING_HomeNetwork1// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_HomeNetwork2// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_HomeNetwork3// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_HomeNetwork4// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_HomeNetwork5// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_HomeNetwork6// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_HomeNetwork7// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_HomeNetwork8// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_MaxGprsCost// !!!DEPRECATED!!! Do *NOT* use this, keep this setting to default value 0.
  • SETTING_MaxGprsConnectTimeout// Value 0 for default or 2..255 for timeout in minutes. Network will be ignored if GPRS connection fails within timeout.
  • SETTING_SmsTimeout// Value 0 for default or 2..255 for timeout in minutes. Delay before GPRS connect attempt to allow the network to deliver pending SMS messages.
  • SETTING_ProhibitSettingsReadback// If set to Boolean TRUE, the settings data can not be read back from the module.
  • SETTING_1WireBusChangeEvent// Trigger EVENT_AttachIButton/EVENT_DetachIButton when on the 1-Wire bus: 0=first/last iButton is attached/removed. 1=Any change in number of attached devices.
  • SETTING_ResetDistanceEventPerGpsLog// When Boolean TRUE, also "Log GPS" actions with GPS-fix reset last internal "Travelled Distance" start point. See EVENT_DISTANCE_1.
  • SETTING_RestartGpsAboveSpeed// [Rev5 only] Restart GPS receiver at speeds above kilometers per hour: 0=disabled, 2..45=45kph, 46..91=90kph, 92..181=180kph, 182..361=360kph.
  • SETTING_ModuleIndicatorLEDsBrightness// [Rev8:000] The MILB_... definition brightness of the indicator LED's on the module when not disabled with SETTING_DisableModuleIndicatorLEDs.
  • SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput1// [Rev8:151] Input voltage above this level results in a digitally active state. Values: 0.1 Volt up to 25.5 Volt (0.0=Firmware default with results similar to Rev5 digital inputs).
  • SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput2// [Rev8:151] Input voltage above this level results in a digitally active state. Values: 0.1 Volt up to 25.5 Volt (0.0=Firmware default with results similar to Rev5 digital inputs).
  • SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput3// [Rev8:151] Input voltage above this level results in a digitally active state. Values: 0.1 Volt up to 25.5 Volt (0.0=Firmware default with results similar to Rev5 digital inputs).
  • SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput4// [Rev8:151] Input voltage above this level results in a digitally active state. Values: 0.1 Volt up to 25.5 Volt (0.0=Firmware default with results similar to Rev5 digital inputs).
  • SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput5// [Rev8:151] Input voltage above this level results in a digitally active state. Values: 0.1 Volt up to 25.5 Volt (0.0=Firmware default with results similar to Rev5 digital inputs).
  • SETTING_PowerSavingVoltageBackup// [Rev8:151] With optional backup battery and SETTING_PowerDownVoltage causes power-down: Enter power saving mode when backup power supply drops below this voltage. Use 0.0 value for recommended firmware default. See CGPS::GetAccu() for more information.
  • SETTING_PowerDownVoltageBackup// [Rev8:151] With optional backup battery and SETTING_PowerDownVoltage causes power-down: Power-down when backup power supply drops below this voltage. Use 0.0 value for recommended firmware default. See CGPS::GetAccu() for more information.
  • SETTING_PowerUpVoltageBackup// [Rev8:151] With optional backup battery and SETTING_PowerDownVoltage causes power-down: Power-up again when backup power supply rises again above this voltage. Use 0.0 value for recommended firmware default. See CGPS::GetAccu() for more information.
  • SETTING_Input4ConnectedToVSS// ***DEPRECATED*** use SETTING_Input4BehaviorSimulationType instead. Old description: [Rev8:100] If set to Boolean TRUE, external Input4 seems to be internally connected to VSS power supply, instead of the external connector.
  • SETTING_PretendInput4LikeOutput1Status// ***DEPRECATED*** use SETTING_Input4BehaviorSimulationType instead. Old description: [Rev8:117] When set to Boolean TRUE, Input4 (in)active status will be identical to (in)active status of Output1.
  • SETTING_MinSensorDetectionStartMoving// [Rev8:117] The minimum motion level required to start giving motion trigger for SETTING_MovingOnSensorDetect. A 16bit unsigned sensitivity value, which must be exceeded to activate "moving mode". With value 0, the internal firmware default is used at a level (4000) that a starting car engine usually exceeds. If you want to determine your own preferred values, then System Variable %S94 can be useful to monitor the live motion level value. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_MinSensorDetectionKeepMoving// [Rev8:117] The minimum motion level required to keep giving triggers for SETTING_MovingOnSensorDetect. A 16bit unsigned sensitivity value, which must be exceeded to keep the "moving mode" active. With value 0, the internal firmware default is used at a level (100) that a car engine running stationary usually exceeds. If you want to determine your own preferred values, then System Variable %S94 can be useful to monitor the live motion level value. See CGPS::GetShake() for detailed background information on motion detection.
  • SETTING_DisableStationaryMotionFilter// [Rev8:120] If set to Boolean TRUE (recommended since Rev8 module series), the filter is disabled for region detection. This filter ignores inside/outside region detection triggers while the moving mode (see CGPS::GetShake() for background information on motion detection) is not active. See CGPSsettings::SetEventRegion() function documentation for background information about region detection in general.
  • SETTING_DoNotLogHighestSpeedWithCounters// [Rev8:120] If set to Boolean TRUE, when logging the counters (e.g. ACTION_CountersLog) the additional SV_CountersHighestSpeed record is not included.
