By default (but can be changed with SETTING_LogRecordSimulateInputVolt), the input will simulate 0Volt if the log is empty, 1Volt for 1 record, 2Volt for 2 records, up to 30Volt for 30 or more records in the log. The voltage is approximate, so for example Input 3 to this simuation and its SETTING_DigitalLevelHysteresisVoltageInput3 to 0.5Volt and its SETTING_DigitalLevelVoltageInput3 to 6.0Volt will make the input have a digital active state when 7 or more records are in the log and digital inactive when less than that are in the log.

====



|| *** "Input 4 Behavior Simulation Type" definitions ***
|| Definitions for SETTING_Input4BehaviorSimulationType.

  • I4BST_Normal// [Rev8:001] Input 4 behavior simulation type: The Input 4 voltage/state is determined from external connected voltage on Input 4 (or else Input 5 since Rev8:186 if the module does not have a physical Input 4).
  • I4BST_ConnectedToVSS// [Rev8:100] Input 4 behavior simulation type: The Input 4 voltage/state is determined from the external power supply voltage.
  • I4BST_ConnectedOutput1// [Rev8:117] Input 4 behavior simulation type: The Input 4 voltage/state is determined from the status of Output 1.
  • I4BST_ConnectedToInput5// [Rev8:186] Input 4 behavior simulation type: The input voltage/state is determined from whatever is connected to Input 5.

====



|| *** "Module Indicator Leds Brightness" definitions ***
|| Definitions for SETTING_ModuleIndicatorLEDsBrightness.

  • MILB_Bright// Uses maximum power; Clear indication even in a (sun)light environment.
  • MILB_Dimmed// Little power saving; Clear indication in normal light environment.
  • MILB_Faint// Low power; Clear indication in darker environments.

====



|| *** "Serial Port Input Bytes Filter Mode" definitions ***
|| Definitions for SETTING_SerialPortInputBytesFilterMode12/34 to make the
|| module filter certain bytes or ranges from incoming data via serial ports.

  • SPIBFM_None// Do not filter incoming bytes
  • SPIBFM_Below0x20exept0x0Aand0x0D// [Rev8:161] Filter every incoming byte with a value below 0x20 value except for 0x0D and 0x0A. Useful for some RFID scanners that mix certain control characters with the output of the real serial ID number.
  • SPIBFM_Remove0x02Replace0x03with0x0D// [Rev9:367] Filter every incoming 0x20 byte and replace every 0x03 byte with a 0x0D byte. Useful for some RFID scanners that mix certain control characters with the output of the real serial ID number data which also ends with a 0x03 byte instead of a 0x0D byte.
  • SPIBFM_Remove0x0A// [Rev8/9:431] Remove 0x0A bytes from incoming data.
  • SPIBFM_Remove0x0D// [Rev8/9:431] Remove 0x0D bytes from incoming data.
  • SPIBFM_Replace0x43With0x0D// [Rev9:504] Replace every 0x43 byte (#) with 0x0D byte.
  • SPIBFM_6// [Rev9:527] Replace every 0x04 by 0x0D and remove every 0x00..0x03 and 0x05..0x1F.
  • SPIBFM_7// [Rev9:527] Replace every 0x04 by 0x0D and remove every 0x01.

====



|| *** "Module Incoming Phone Call Action" definitions ***
|| Definitions for SETTING_IncomingPhoneCallAction to make the module
|| automatically answer/reject/ignore incoming phone calls.

  • MIPCA_Reject// Reject every incoming phone call, but still trigger the EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy... and EVENT_CalledByUnknownPhone events. This is the default setting and also the only useful setting for modules that do not have a voice phone hardware option or have no microphone+speaker attached to it.
  • MIPCA_AutoAnswer// [Rev8:161] Automatically answer every incoming phone call. Useful for example if the module is used as an alarm device in a building and after an alarm message via SMS text or via GPRS to the server, you want to call it to hear for what sounds the attached Nokia HDC-5 compatible microphone(+speaker) picks up.
  • MIPCA_AutoAnswerIfKnown// [Rev8:???] !FEATURE NOT YET SUPPORTED! Automatically reject incoming phone calls for unknown phone numbers and automatically answer phone numbers (just like MIPCA_AutoAnswer) of which the detectable CallerID (must not be disabled by the caller) matches a number defined for SETTING_SmsAlertPhone1/2/3 or EVENT_PHONE_CalledBy1/2/3.
  • MIPCA_Ignore// [Rev8:161] Ignore incoming phone calls. On modules with voice hardware option you will then hear the "ringing sound" of the incoming phone call via the speaker attached to it. You can "pick up the phone" by executing ActionID 61 and later "hang up" (or immediately to reject the call) by executing ActionID 7 (for example via input(pattern) events wired to buttons or from your LCD/source-code menu).

====



|| *** "WakeUp IO Change Bit Mask" definitions ***
|| Definitions for SETTING_WakeUpIOchange to make the module
|| automatically wake-up from power-down mode when one of the following
|| events occur:

  • WUIOCBM_Input1// DEPRECATED, use SETTING_WakeUpIOchangeInput1 instead.
  • WUIOCBM_Input2// DEPRECATED, use SETTING_WakeUpIOchangeInput2 instead.
  • WUIOCBM_Input3// DEPRECATED, use SETTING_WakeUpIOchangeInput3 instead.
  • WUIOCBM_Input4// DEPRECATED, use SETTING_WakeUpIOchangeInput4 instead.
  • WUIOCBM_Input5// DEPRECATED, use SETTING_WakeUpIOchangeInput5 instead.

====



|| *** "SV_Network Record Handling" definitions (advanced setting) ***
|| Definitions for SETTING_NetworkRecordHandling to make the module
|| log or transmit SV_Network records in one of the following special ways:

  • SVNRH_Asynchronous// [Rev8:180] (Default setting) Transmitted directly to the server, asynchronously before any log contents is transmitted.
  • SVNRH_Disabled// [Rev8:180] No SV_Network records are generated/transmitted/stored at all.

====



|| #########################################################################
|| #########################################################################
|| #########################################################################
|| #################################### CGPSCODE class members and functions
|| #########################################################################
|| #########################################################################
|| #########################################################################
|| This class can be used to construct or verify code that can be executed by a module.
|| You can use this class to check and properly format source code properly before you
|| are uploading it with the CGPS::mSourceCode response action class member.
|| Usage example:

||
||     <?php
    $pcGPSCODE=new CGPSCODE(); //Create instance of the class
    if($pcGPSCODE->AddSourceCode(@file_get_contents($FileName))) //Feed source code to the class (for example from a file).
    {
        //The class accepted the source code, so it should be safe to upload it to the module.
        //This can be done via the mSourceCode member of the CGPS class.
        //But depending on what else that you also uploading at the same time via other members of the CGPS class,
        //a problem will occur if certain commands in your source code use the same resources during the upload
        //process from your server.
        //Using the mFirmware class member for example will make the module write to FLASH RAM and will give
        //a problem if your source code also leads to a write to FLASH RAM at the same time during the server upload.
        if(strlen($pcGPS->mSettings) && $pcGPSCODE->GetFirstServerUploadStallLine()) //New settings and source with FLASH write?
        {
            //Not safe to upload the settings now, do it the next time when the module transmits to the server.
            //Which won't be long, because the new settings upload will generate a SV_SettingsAccepted or SV_SettingsRejected.
        }
        else
        {
            //So we copy the source code in the action response member of the CGPS class.
            $pcGPS->mSourceCode=$pcGPSCODE->GetSourceCode();
        }
    } else $SourceRejectionReason=$pcGPSCODE->GetLastError()); //Class rejected source code, so get the error message.
    ?>
||
||

====
function CGPSCODE()
Class constructor
Notes:
    Function is automatically executed when a new instance of the class is created.
    This function automatically calls the CGPSCODE::Clear() function.
function Clear()
Clear class contents.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - None
Notes:
    All instructions, variables and commands in the class are removed.
function GetLastError()
Get the last error that occurred in the class as a text string.
Function input:
    - None
Function result:
    - Text string with description of the last error that occurred.
Notes:
    For displaying the text as HTML, use: print(htmlentities($pcGPSCODE->GetLastError()));
function GetInstructionIndexFromName(InstructionName)
Retrieve Index number of an instruction.
Function input:
    - InstructionName: text string containing the name of the instruction.
Function result:
    - Index value.
Notes:
    If not found, the result value is 0.
function SetInstructionArgument(InstructionIndexNumber, InstructionArgument, ArgumentData)
Set an argument variable of an instruction.
Function input:
    - InstructionIndexNumber: Index number of instruction slot (1 up
        to 300) to be changed.
    - InstructionArgument: the argument/parameter of the instruction
        slot that is to be changed:
        *** "Menu Item Argument" definitions ***

  • MIA_Name// Optional source only text name/label/description for an Index
  • MIA_Index// Index number of the instruction. Range of: 001 up-to 300
  • MIA_Type// Instruction type
  • MIA_Up// Up-button action
  • MIA_Down// Down-button action
  • MIA_Left// Left-button action
  • MIA_Right// Right-button action
  • MIA_Select// Select-button action
  • MIA_Cancel// Cancel-button action
  • MIA_Timeout// Timeout action
  • MIA_TimeoutUnits// Timeout in units of 0.1 second. 0=Jump directly, 255=Disabled, 1=0.1sec, 2=0.2sec, 3=0.3sec, ...
  • MIA_Data// The data/text that the instruction for example shows on the LCD or sends to the server.

    - ArgumentData: the data to be stored in the argument/parameter
        of the instruction slot.
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE or FALSE.
function GetInstructionArgument(Index, Parameter)
Get previously set argument/parameter of an instruction slot.
Function input:
    - InstructionIndexNumber: Index number of instruction slot (1 up
        to 300) from which to retrieve it.
    - InstructionArgument: the argument/parameter of the instruction
        slot that is to be read from:
        *** "Menu Item Argument" definitions ***

  • MIA_Name// Optional source only text name/label/description for an Index
  • MIA_Index// Index number of the instruction. Range of: 001 up-to 300
  • MIA_Type// Instruction type
  • MIA_Up// Up-button action
  • MIA_Down// Down-button action
  • MIA_Left// Left-button action
  • MIA_Right// Right-button action
  • MIA_Select// Select-button action
  • MIA_Cancel// Cancel-button action
  • MIA_Timeout// Timeout action
  • MIA_TimeoutUnits// Timeout in units of 0.1 second. 0=Jump directly, 255=Disabled, 1=0.1sec, 2=0.2sec, 3=0.3sec, ...
  • MIA_Data// The data/text that the instruction for example shows on the LCD or sends to the server.

Function result:
    - Argument/parameter contents (data type depends on the requested
        argument/parameter).
function GetHighestIndex()
Retrieve the highest Index value of the functions stored in the class.
Function input:
    - None.
Function result:
    - Index value.
Notes:
    Value 0 is returned if there are no functions stored in the class.
function IsIndexInUse(Index)
Determine if the instruction slot with the given Index is defined to
a certain Type-state or not.
Function input:
    - Index: Number of index to check.
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE or FALSE.
function GetUserVariableAllowableCharacters(UserVariableNumber)
Get a string with the characters that are not filtered
out of a user variable when formatted to output via a
template with a %Uxx marker will not be filtered out.
Function input:
    - UserVariableNumber: Number of the %Uxx user variable.
Function result:
    - String containing all characters that are allowed.
Notes:
    If in a template a %Uxx marker is used to format into
    output, then all characters that the variable contains
    that are not in the returned string of this function
    will be at runtime be filtered out in the process by
    the hardware module that is processing your code.
    All characters that are filtered out are not only
    filtered out in the output of the template but also
    in the contents of the user variable itself.
    Examples of the characters the only characters that
    will remain in the ranges of %Uxx markers:
        1 up to 39 : Only numbers with digits '0'-'9'.
        40 up to 69 : Only text with letters 'A'-'Z', numbers '0'-'9' and space.
        70 up to 99 : Most characters remain.
function SetUserVariableByName(UserVariableName, UserVariableData)
Set the contents of a user variable, referenced by its name.
Function input:
    - UserVariableName: The name of the user variable to set with the supplied UserVariableData
    - UserVariableData: The data to set the supplied UserVariableName with
Function result:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSCODE::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
function SetUserVariableByNumber(UserVariableNumber, UserVariableData)
Set the contents of a user variable, referenced by its number
Function input:
    - UserVariableNumber
        The number of the user variable to set with the supplied UserVariableData.
    - UserVariableData
        The data to set the supplied UserVariableName with.
Function output:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSCODE::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Usage example:


    <?php
    //This returns success with boolean TRUE
    $pcGPSCODE->SetUserVariable(3, '123456');
    //This returns failure with boolean TRUE (because there are more than 16 characters)
    $pcGPSCODE->SetUserVariable(3, '12345678901234567'); //Function returns error with boolean FALSE
    ?>


function GetUserVariableByName(UserVariableName)
Get the contents of a user variable, referenced by its name
Function input:
    - UserVariableName = The name of the user variable to retrieve the contents from
Function output:
    - Success: The contents of the requested UserVariableName.
    - Error: NULL type result.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Contents=$pcGPSCODE->GetUserVariableByName('%U03');
    if($Contents===NULL) print('The variable is empty/unset');
    else print('Contents of the variable is: '.$Contents);
    ?>


function GetUserVariableByNumber(UserVariableNumber)
Get the contents of a user variable, referenced by its number.
Function input:
    - UserVariableNumber = The number of the user variable to retrieve the contents from.
Function output:
    - Success: The contents of the requested UserVariableName.
    - Error: NULL type result.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $Contents=$pcGPSCODE->GetUserVariableByNumber(3);
    if($Contents===NULL) print('The variable is empty/unset');
    else print('Contents of the variable is: '.$Contents);
    ?>


function GetUserVariablesArray()
Get a copy of the user variables table.
Function input:
    - None.
Function output:
    - Array()
Notes:
    Array format example:
    array('%U01' => '123456', '%U40' => '1a2B3u', '%U73' => '1!2B3#');
function SetCommand(Command, Data, Line, Remark='')
Set a command
Function input:
    - Command = The name of the command.
    - Data = The data of the command.
    - Line = The source line number of the command.
    - Remark = Optional remark.
Function output:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSCODE::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Usage example:


    <?php
    $pcGPSCODE->SetCommand('MW', '001 000', 1, 'MenuWait: Make the runtime execution halt and wait up to 60 until (modified) code is stored in FLASH by CLIMS');
    $pcGPSCODE->SetCommand('MB', '001 012012012012', 100, 'MenuBitmask: Index 1,4,7,10-> 0=no change / 2,5,8,11 -> 1=Clear "Data" / 3,6,9,12 -> 2=Clear "Data" + Set "Type=0"');
    $pcGPSCODE->SetCommand('MG', '123 000', 101, 'MenuGoto: Jump directly to index 123');
    $pcGPSCODE->SetCommand('MS', '002 000', 102, 'MenuStore: Make a copy of current primary runtime code block into FLASH');
    ?>


function GetCommandArray()
Get a copy of the commands table.
Function input:
    - None.
Function output:
    - Array()
Notes:
    Array format example:
    array(<line>' => array('<command>', '<data>', '<remark>'));
function GetInstructionArray()
Get a copy of the function variables table.
Function input:
    - None.
Function output:
    - Array()
Notes:
    Array format example:
          Item title, idx, typ, up, dwn, lft, rgt, sel, can, tim, sec, [          reserved 7          ], Data
    array('Main menu', 001, 001, 900 901, 021, 102, 000, 000, 000, 255, 000, 000, 000, 000, 000, 000, 000, "Menu item data";
function GetInstructionSourceCode(Index)
Get the source code of instruction with the given Index number.
Function input:
    - Index: The index number of the instruction.
Function output:
    - Text string with the instruction source code.
Notes:
    An empty string is returned if the given Index does not exist.
function AddSourceCode(SourceCodeData)
Add source code to the class.
Function input:
    - SourceCodeData: Text string containing source code line(s).
Function output:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSCODE::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    Variable declaration and instructions with an index that are already defined in the class will be overwritten.
    See also: CGPSCODE::Clear()
function SetBinaryData(BinaryData)
Set binary data in the class
Function input:
    - BinaryData: Block of binary data containing the code.
Function output:
    Boolean TRUE to signal success.
    Or FALSE to signal a problem, in which case you can use the
    function CGPSCODE::GetLastError() to retrieve an error message.
Notes:
    This function clears the whole contents of the class and sets data
    in the class according to the information found in the given binary
    data.
    After that, the source code text of the binary data can be
    retrieved with CGPSCODE::GetSourceCode().
    That is even possible if setting the binary data resulted in a
    boolean FALSE result but then the code available in the class
    will of course also contain the errors of the binary data.
function GetSourceCode(Retrieve=0xFF)
Retrieved the full source code of the program in the class.
Function input:
    - Retrieve: If not supplied, all source code items are included.
        Or else (a combination of) definitions:
        GSC_Variables: Include user variable declarations.
        GSC_Instructions: Include instructions.
        GSC_Commands: Include commands.
Function output:
    - Text string containing source code line(s).
Notes:
    An empty string is returned if the class does not contain any of the requested types.
function GetFirstServerUploadStallLine()
Get the first source line number that requires a server upload stall.
Function input:
    - None.
Function output:
    - Line number value or value 0 for no stall.
Notes:
    When uploading via the action response members of the CGPS class, the module
    executes all these actions live during the actual reception from your server.
    Some actions temporarily keep the module from being able to process other actions.
    If this function returns a value other than 0, the code contains an action
    that can not be performed at the same time as some other actions.
    If you for example use the CGPS::mSettings class member, the module has to
    decompress and decode the received data and write it into its FLASH RAM.
    When at the same time the CGPS::mSourceCode class member is in use to upload
    something that results into a write to FLASH RAM too, then there is a problem.
    Simply stall that upload from your server to the module until the next time it
    transmits to your server so they are not uploaded to the module at the same time.
function GetCustomSmsCommands()
Get a list of custom SMS commands in the current program.
Function input:
    - None.
Function output:
    - Array(Index=>Command)
function GetIButtons()
Get a list of 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton) serial numbers.
Function input:
    - None.
Function output:
    - array('Serial number'=>Index)
function GetRegions()
Get a list of regions.
Function input:
    - None.
Function output:
    - Array(Index=>RegionEventID)
function CheckCurrentCode(&raErrors, &raWarnings)
Check the current code in the class and report warnings and/or errors
Function input:
    - raErrors: reference to an array to add a text string for each error that is found.
    - raWarnings: reference to an array to add a text string for each warning that is found.
Function result:
    - Boolean TRUE if one or more error/warning has been added to raErrors and/or raWarnings.
    - Boolean FALSE if no error/warning was detected.
Usage example:


    <?php
    require('cgps.php'); //Include required file containing CGPS classes.
    $SourceFile='FileName.src'; //File containing LCD/Source-code.
    $pcGPSCODE=new CGPSCODE(); //Create instance object of CGPSCODE class.
    if($pcGPSCODE->AddSourceCode(file_get_contents($SourceFile))) //Put file contents into class.
    {
        $aErrors=$aWarnings=array(); //Two empty arrays for possible error and warning strings.
        if($pcGPSCODE->CheckCurrentCode($aErrors, $aWarnings)) //Have class check the code for anomalies.
        {
            //Class detected errors and/or warnings, lets print them on screen...
            $Count=count($aErrors); //Size of array is number of errors detected.
            print("--- Errors detected in source code file '$SourceFile': $Count<BR>");
            foreach($aErrors as $Error) print("* $Error<BR>");
            $Count=count($aWarnings); //Size of array is number of warnings detected.
            print("--- Warnings detected in source code file '$SourceFile': $Count<BR>");
            foreach($aWarnings as $Warning) print("* $Warning<BR>");
        } else print("No errors or warnings found in source code file '$SourceFile'<BR>"); //Yippie ;-)
    } else print("Error in source code file '$SourceFile': ".$pcGPSCODE->GetLastError()."<BR>"); //Bad file?
    ?>


function RemoveDisabledInstructions()
Remove all instruction slots from the code in the class
that are set to a "Disabled / Deleted" Type and have an empty
Data field.
Function input:
    - None.
Function result:
    - Value of the number of instruction slots that were removed.
Notes:
    This function is useful if you for example have inserted a
    source code into the class that was read/received from a module
    including all instruction slots that are set to a
    Disabled/Deleted Type, which includes all instruction slots
    that have never been programmed before or were cleared during
    a source code upload in which only the instruction slots you
    used were programmed and all the others were cleared.
function RemoveBlankUserVariableInitialisations()
Remove all initializations for User Variables with blank contents.
Function input:
    - None.
Function result:
    - Value of the number of instruction slots that were removed.
Notes:
    This function is useful if you for example have inserted a
    source code into the class that was read/received from a module
    including all variables that were set to a blank contents or
    variables that were never programmed before.



|| *** Static functions ***
|| A set of functions that can be useful to check/convert data.
====
function Check1WireSerialNumber(SerialNumber)
Check the serial number of a 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton)
Function input:
    - The serial number text to be checked.
Function result:
    0: Invalid serial number;
        Does not consist of 16 upper case hexadecimal characters or
        evaluates to a bad CRC checksum.
    1: Valid serial number;
        Correct serial number, notated in the same byte order as the
        device physically delivers it.
    -1: Invalid serial number;
        Seems to be correct though, but in wrong byte order (usually
        imprinted as text on a device in this order).
Notes:
    This function input is case sensitive (e.g. OK: 0831C39500000027
    WRONG: 0831c39500000027).
    This function calculates and compares the CRC byte in the supplied
    serial number and returns a 0 (zero) value if they do not match.
    For 1-Wire devices that are big enough to have the serial number
    stamped/imprinted on its body, the serial number is usually in opposite
    byte order compared to how it electrically supplies its serial number,
    so a device that delivers serial number 0831C39500000027 has
    2700000095C33108 stamped/imprinted on its body.
    Therefore this function results:
    Check1WireSerialNumber("0831c39500000027"); //Function result value: 0 (=Bad: invalid characters or length)
    Check1WireSerialNumber("0831C39500000027"); //Function result value: 1 (=OK, correct number)
    Check1WireSerialNumber("2700000095C33108"); //Function result value: -1 (=wrong order)
    See also function ByteSwap1WireSerialNumber().
Usage example:


    <?php
    //Check a 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton) serial number for correctness.
    require('cgps.php');
    $SerialNumber='2700000095C33108'; //Upper case text of the serial number.
    print("The supplied serial number '$SerialNumber' is: ");
    $Result=Check1WireSerialNumber($SerialNumber);
    if($Result==0) print("invalid (characters or length)");
    if($Result==1) print("Correct AND in same byte order as the device itself electrically supplies it");
    if($Result==-1) print("In opposite byte order. ByteSwap1WireSerialNumber('$SerialNumber') swaps it into: ".ByteSwap1WireSerialNumber($SerialNumber));
    ?>


function ByteSwap1WireSerialNumber(SerialNumber)
The serial number of a 1-Wire device (e.g. iButton) to swap the bytes.
Function input:
    - SerialNumber: The serial number as upper case text.
Function result:
    - The supplied serial number text in swapped byte order.
        (or the supplied serial number text unchanged if it contains invalid characters or has a bad length).
Notes:
    For 1-Wire devices that are big enough to have the serial number stamped/imprinted on its body,
    the serial number is usually in opposite byte order compared to how it electrically supplies
    its serial number, so a device that delivers serial number 0831C39500000027 has 2700000095C33108
    on stamped/imprinted on its body.
    This function converts from one serial number notation form into the other.
    See also CGPS::GetIButtonSerialNumberText() and CGPS::GetIButtonSerialNumberTextSwapped().
